description:
Came in with the co workers and I'm surprised I've never been in this alley before... yet alone try the food! 

We had no reservations. Got seated right away and everyone is so friendly here! 

I got the steak salad and it was pretty bomb! Each table also gets complementary bread. 

I will be back. Everyone here speaks French (so you know it's authentic)!
author: Elaine C.

description:
When my friend who lives not far from here said we should go down this alley where they have all these different restaurants with a variety of types of food, I almost told him he was crazy!   I'm not comfortable walking down and San Francisco back alley, but I'm glad I did in this situation.  

This just happened to be the place where my friend proposed to his wife, and the staff remembered him and treated us like royalty!  On top of that, the meal was top notch.  Even the bread they brought out was great.  I had a sidecar to drink..expertly made and delicious.   The steak au poivre was amazing as well.  Both of my friends had the filet and I was lucky enough to get a small taste....it melted in my mouth.  

Charming service, great food and drink, nice atmosphere.  Definitely worth a trip down an alley to Cafe Bastille.
author: Bill T.

description:
Really great food, in a great ambiance. The staff were authentic and knowledgeable about the menu. The little alley that the restaurant is in is very charming with hanging overhead lights and the restaurant itself felt cozy and 'french' without being cheesy or theatrical. 

I've dined outside and inside now, and both times were great. I brought a special bottle of wine to share with a friend the first time I ate there and if I remember correctly the corkage was either free or very low.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Oh la laaaa! Super cute location! I had never been to Belden Lane before. Such an interesting little corner of the city! 

So, I had a living social voucher for Cafe Bastille for a prix fixe dinner for two. Went with the hubby and a friend who ordered a la carte. The prix fixe consisted of three courses, for each course you were able to choose between two to four dishes. I went with the French Onion Soup, the Coq Au Vin, and the Chocolate Mousse. The hubby had the soup as well, Boeuf Bourguignon and a raspberry mousse. My friend went for appetizers and chose the Foie Gras, Beet Salad and Escargot. We also sampled several of their cocktails.

First off: We had an amazing evening. Service was wonderful, our waiter so very friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. The ambiance is sweet, you feel like you're in a little Brasserie in Paris, I kid you not! Downstairs ia additional seating, so the place is much larger than it seems at a first glance.

The food was OK. I had the feeling, the prix fixe was a bit lackluster. The soup had almost no seasoning and was watery, cheese was a bit burnt, main course was cold (and the beef tough to chew). The dessert cake/mousse options felt like store-bought dessert with store-bought sauce. 
The Foie Gras was amazing though, I ate half of my friend's portion. Oops. My Coq was tasty (but again lacking salt - I never use the salt on the table in a restaurant, but this time I did) but unfortunately a bit cold. 

The baguette in the bread basket was a nice treat. Warm, crunchy, super good!
Cocktails were very good as well, they were definitely generous with the alcohol. I especially liked the Orange Blossom cocktail.

I will definitely come again and try the a la carte items. I feel like that's a much better choice compared to the prix fixe.
author: Alexa W.

description:
This place is solid!

Solid service!
Solid portions!
Solid atmosphere!
Solid outdoor space!
Solid flavor and courses!

Prix fixe is NOT dead!

There was a discrepancy as the menu uploaded to the website advertises the price as $39, the current menu at the restaurant is $42 = $3 more.

Three Course Dinner is:
1) Soup of the Day, French onion soupe gratinee (GET THIS!) or baby lettuce salade 
2) Boeuf Bourguignon, coq au vin, moules frites (GET THIS Normande is cream, bacon, mushroom)  or mushroom fettucine
3) Raspberry mousse or Pave chocolate mousse

We had the Soup of the Day (Lentil with bacon), the French Onion Soup was deeeeelicious, super hot and cheesy with a deep carmelized onion flavor! yum!

We both had moules frites in both versions:  Marinieres is classic white wine, shallots and parsley - MINE, the Normade was sooo good.  I like to open them ALL first so I can just eat them with a big spoon without stopping to open them - the cream - bacon and mushroom is also super garlicky - yummmmy!

For dessert, we got one of each and they were equally delicious as the chocolate has a hard layer of chocolate on top of the mousse.

With one drink each (red wine and Olivier's Side Car (cognac, cointreau, grand marnier, lemon juice, orange juice & orange peel) the tax was steep at $10 and the other mandatory SF tax of around $6 - the tab was right at $120.

We did have leftovers which the waiter gladly put together safely so that it would not drip or spill - thank you!

Thank you and we will be back!
author: Charlie B.

description: Yes yes yes ! Amazing. We had the groupon, but will definitely be back now that we know how great it is. Service was wonderful and food delicious. Also, GREAT playlist . The ambiance alone is worth five stars .
author: Kate H.

description: Loves this place. The service was excellent. The atmosphere was fun and classy without being stuffy, and the food was a lovey change of pace from the usual California cuisine. My lady and I had a wonderful time and will be returning in the future.
author: Ryan K.

description: We came here with a groupon and tried the prix fixe menu.  Our server was polite and attentive.  The bread was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside and was so delicious with butter.  We ordered the beef bourginon, mushroom fettuccine, onion soup, lamb sausages with couscous, and the mousse.  Everything was on the less salty side which we liked.  The onion soup was so good!  Each bite was cheesy and bready and oniony.  The beef in the bourginon was a little dry and tasted average.  The lamb sausages were kind of dry (lacked fat) and felt as crumbly as the couscous when it was chewed.  The mushroom pasta was good and smelled like truffle oil.  The mushroom pieces were chunky and looked like chicken pieces.  An overall decent restaurant with great service.
author: S Y.

description:
Very nice place. The food was very good, missing just a little bit of salt on some plates, but still amazing taste. Even though the tables are extremely close to each other, you can feel comfortable and it has a nice vibe and decore.
The chocolate mousse was amazing and the escargot
author: Andrea B.

description:
Cafe Bastille is a super cute place that is in an alley right across the street from Pagan Idol, super cool location for sure. They are French cuisine and reasonably priced. It was a cold night so we chose to sit inside vs outside but Cafe Bastille has both options. 

I ordered a glass of bordeaux and started with a french onion soup. The soup was fantastic and completely what you expect when ordering french onion soup, the cheese was nice and bubbly and of course was served in a cute little ceramic dish. For dinner, I ordered the special of the night which was a filet minon with garlic mashed potatoes and green beans served with a red wine reduction. It was amazing! The filet was cooked to perfection (I am a medium rare girl) so it was nice and tender and juicy. The garlic mashed potatoes were nice and smooth and had a nice rich mouthfeel. The green beans were tender and not overcooked. It was a fantastic meal! 

I really wish at that point I would have had room for dessert, sadly I did not. But the dinner was amazing and the server was wonderful as well. I would definitely go back. This would also be a great date spot with the dim lighting, soft music in the background, and super yummy food!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
3.5 stars

Had a prix fix (3 course dinner) Beef bourgeois (beef stew) was a little dry. Mussels were on point. Buttery with nice lemon zest (great for dipping the bread they give you). French onion soup lacked flavor. Salad was good. Desserts were lovely, rich but not overly done. I would go back and try other food. The people were great.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I will leave a 0 star. We arrived when there were only 4 other customers. The waiter sat us down.  We waited for more than 15 minutes and waived at him a few times.  He never come to take our order. So rude and will never come to this place again
author: Eileen T.

description:
This place is on Belden Street-alley. The street has multiple restaurants on it.  Many with outdoor seating. 
Had the riviera and soleil drinks. Both were very tasty and came out quickly

Had the prix fix dinner for $39. Choice of soup or salad, plus entree of beef bourguignon, mushroom pasta and one other dish plus raspberry or chocolate mousse cake. 
The french onion soup was delicious with flavors of sherry in the broth. The salad came with a flavorful dressing. 
The beef bourguignon was delicious. The meat fell apart in your mouth. It came with carrots, pearl onions and mushrooms. 
The mushroom pasta was very good although not as flavorful as the beef. The mushrooms were cubed. 
The raspberry and chocolate mousse cakes were light and very good. 

The reason for the four stars is the bill. The prix fix is $39 for a three course dinner yet we were charged for a salad and a dessert. You need to go over your bill very carefully here.
author: Bacon G.

description:
My review for Cafe Bastille is definitely overdue. I've been here a few times now, always for dinner. I recommend coming on a weeknight (the most recent time I went was last night- on a Tuesday) because it gets  little busy on the weekends. 

They serve all of the normal, traditional dishes you would expect- coq au vin, beef bourignon, escargot, etc. alongside delicious bread and a very reasonable wine list. It's situated in a cute little alley and their patio has heaters for those of us who want to sit outside on those chilly San Francisco nights (I mean, it almost dropped down to 60 last night! The horror! Haha...)

The service is good, but I've never seen more than two servers working at once, so it is a bit slower than other restaurants in the FiDi where they just want to flip the table as fast as they can. Last night I got the coq au vin and he got the beef bourignon, unfortunately, both of our meats were a little dry, but the sauce and the french onion soup made up for it! Recommend for a nice meal on a weeknight!
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
Cafe Bastille is a nice little place that is in an alley right across the street from Pagan Idol. 

They are French cuisine and reasonably priced. It was a cold night so we chose to sit inside vs outside but Cafe Bastille has both options.

Tried the Rata Crepe and Merguez Sandwich. Good picks. Total w/tip - $38.00
author: Marc M.

description: The service was amazing. Our server was very attentive, and made sure to give us heads up that the Happy Hour was ending, which was very nice of him considering it lowers the total bill, and benefits him in no way. The food we had was delicious and fresh, and came in perfectly-sized portions. I think I had one of the best rosés I've ever had as well...
author: Kyle B.

description:
Loved the atmosphere: dimmed lights, candlelight, and some pretty pleasant music. Real chill.
There is outdoor seating plus they have a downstairs dining area as well. They do have a bar. I had a rose brut and my friend had the sunrise (?). They were both good.
We had the prix fixe option. I had the onion soup, Beef Bourguignon, and chocolate mouse. My friend had the salad, Beef Bourguignon, and raspberry mousse. We were very pleased with our meal. It was very flavorful and delicious. I really really loved the chocolate mousse. 
The service was awesome! Reno (I hope I got it right) was our waiter and tended to us and made sure we were taken care of. In fact, everyone was very attentive and made sure everything was up to par.
Thank you for such a wonderful experience. I will be back soon.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Casual lunch/dinner spot in downtown San Francisco. Terrace seat is nice when the weather is good. Bread is served warm and it tastes great! I recommend crepe for lunch. Beef bourguignon and Coq au vin are not the best, they are kind of dry. Decent wines. 
It's good to come here with friends for brunch or casual drinks.
author: Lana B.

description:
Found this little gem on Groupon.  Cute little restaurant, in a hidden alley.  I called them before we came to get recommendations on where to park.  The man we spoke to told us 444 Stockton Garage, great deal $4.50 for 3 hours on a Saturday night!
This restaurant is very quaint, it has indoor and outdoor seating.  Located an a cute little hidden alley.  We did the dinner prix fixe.  Excellent French onion soup, BOEUF BOURGUIGNON,  COQ AU VIN, and MOULES.  Dessert was amazing!  Had the Lamb MERGUEZ for an appetizer, that too was yummy!  Good wine and cocktails!   The service was very good.  

So glad to have found this, we'll be back!
author: Terri M.

description:
I love this place! I often take out-of-town co-workers here because the menu has a lot of choices, full bar, excellent service and for myself I know I can eat here gluten-free without issue.

The hostess, whom I think may be the owner, and I forget her lovely name, is quite observant about the party and will make excellent beverage and menu suggestions. The drinks menu features signature cocktails that change occasionally, which is fun. The menu is mostly the same year-round, except for specials, and most of the fare is naturally gluten-free or can be made so with some adjustments.

They can accommodate large groups with multiple checks, but please be kind to the lovely hostess and speak to her about this before you place an order so that she can tell you what she can or can't do in regards to the bill. We once had a party of about 20 people. She took everyone's order and then when it came time to pay the check she allowed us each to pay separately but we had to go one-by-one with her to the cash register. I thought it was a brilliant solution and no one in our party minded doing it that way but I can see how to some it might be too fussy.

Anyway, I'll continue to patronize this restaurant for the excellent cuisine, super delicious cocktails and truly outstanding service!
author: Shannon B.

description:
Food was mediocre... had the prix fixe w onion soup (tasted bitter), beef Bourguignon (meat was over cooked), & chocolate mousse (good!).
We were there on wet, drizzly night so restaurant was shut tight making it stuffy and unpleasant... maybe on a nice evening when you can sit outside it will be better.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Had lunch today with my French friend. Although we were originally headed somewhere else, he suggested that we go to Café Bastille instead. Why not, I thought! 

We started with the escargot. Butter, snail, yum!

For our main courses, he had the Lamb Merguez Sausage with Couscous and I had the Salmon with Olive Tapenade and Ratatouille. He's the lamb expert and said it was "so good." I thought his dish was just ok. My salmon was surprising delicious though. It had the right amount of crispness and it was still moist. The olive tapenade did not overpower the more subtle taste of the salmon.

Lunch for two with no drinks was $70. A bit pricey for sure.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Totally disappointed in Cafe Bastille.  Dinner prix fixe not worth your money.  Choices are limited and practically the same.  Made the mistake of ordering the boeuf and chicken bourguignon which is exactly the same, difference is meat and chicken comes with noodles. Dessert is also practically the same. Prix fixe with a half bottle of red came out to around $150 not including gratuity. 

Service was awful. Waiter spilled water on me when he dropped off our glass and didn't even noticed it until I grunted. Our wine didn't come until we were done with our first course and only because we said something. 

Two stars maybe too much for this place. Handful of French restaurants much better than Cafe Bastille to spend your money.
author: Naty D.

description: I felt as if we were really in a ally restaurant in France while dining here. The food was delicious. You can tell that they took pride in presenting each dish with the highest quality and taste. Our servers Sabrina and Victor could not have been more wonderful. They both made sure all our wants and needs were met. I highly recommend this place and can not wait to come back to try some of there other menu items.
author: Shaneel R.

description: Tucked in an alley near the Financial District of Downtown San Francisco the place looks like a restaurant in France  servers speak French  once you enter the restaurant it might look small but they have a basement which can accommodate more people.
author: Bambi F.

description: I love being able to sit outside and enjoy a good meal. The prices here are fair and the menu has a large selection of items from traditional French dishes, mussels, frites, pates, cheeses, steak, vegetarian pasta, and even a burger. They offer cocktails and wine so on a nice night, you can have a glass and hang out. I had a dirty Ketel martini and the Rabbit. Martini was made well and the Rabbit was delicious. The dish had some veggies and potatoes in a cream sauce. It was perfectly seasoned and I dipped my bread and soaked up the remaining bits. My friends had the Coq au Vin and Duck Confit. All were good and had a nice presentation. The service was fine. We got our waters filled whenever the glass was empty and the server was around if we needed anything but he left us to talk and took our order when we signaled.
author: Jen L.

description:
Five stars purely for the Beef Bourguignon. I had it last night (Thursday), and I can't stop thinking about it. Please never let that chef go. I had the same dish a few years ago, and it was super bland, so I was hesitant to stray from my usual moules mariniere. I am so glad I did. Bread was great, soft, fresh, and perfect for dipping in the bowl. Waitstaff was lovely, helping 2 girls on a budget pick a good wine to go with the beef Bourguignon and even packing me a little extra bread in my to go box so I could keep mopping up the stew juice?broth?sauce?
This place is great for a long lunch or a quick dinner. Go for the beef Bourguignon or the moules. Guard your bread with your life cause you'll wanna dip it in either bowl.
author: Sarah W.

description: It's just okay. It's a nice venue with cool vibes, but just wasn't really impressed with the food. I got the bastille burger, which came with really crunchy fries (I like mine crunchy on the outside, soft in the center). I found the burger pretty dry, and the half melted cheese didn't help it much either. I did try my first escargot (tasted like butter and garlic with the texture of a mushroom lol), and my friend's eggplant sandwich smelled and looked divine.
author: Ke C.

description: Wonderful service and excellent food. We had the Duck Confit Cassoulet, Trout, and Rabbit in a mustard sauce. The beet salad and charcuterie to start were also excellent. The people next to us had the Beef Bourguignon, which smelled delicious. We didn't have reservations and we sat indoors.
author: Stuart W.

description: We had a really nice dinner after shopping at Union Square.  The waiter was perfect-knew the wines and food.  The drinks and food were delicious.  We had escargots, pate fois gras, filet mignon and boeuf bourguinon and pommes frites (couldn't resist).  Whole experience 8 on a scale of 10.  Belden Alley is fun too.
author: Cindy M.

description:
This review is strictly for the Prix Fixe menu which is what you can get with the groupon.

First, the service was excellent. Our waiter was very attentive but not overbearing and paced the courses well. The bread and wine was delivered quickly and was delicious and our water was filled repeatedly.

We started with the french onion soup, which as many other reviewers have said, it was quite sweet and not very rich. We had the coq au vin and the beef bourguignon, both were in need of seasoning and were quite bland. The chicken was overcooked. On to the desserts, we had both the raspberry and chocolate mouse. The raspberry was definitely the better of the two although neither was particularly good.

Perhaps ordering off the main menu would have provided a better experience.
author: Lori S.

description: Great service - loved my meal. Had the steak sandwich. Definitely a great spot to eat outside on a nice day.
author: Peter S.

description:
Located in a charming alley that is next to other restaurants, Bastille is a tucked away French spot that is good to dine for a nice, casual lunch or dinner as well.  The outdoor seatings are great for lounging on a warm and sunny day!

I got their lamb sausage entree and it was spot on.  Their cordon bleu was good, but not the most delicious one that I've had to date. Desserts are of the norm and they use Nutella for their crepe! Sure win in my books when using Nutella!

Staffing was attentive wth energy. 

This place and like the ones next to each other, has a laid back feel to its surroundings.  

If you want to hideaway, this place is to be!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Considering how expensive most dining is in San Francisco, the menu provided for lunch here at Cafe Bastille is pretty reasonable. 

Belden Place is really a gem of SF Downtown that few know about and Cafe Bastille is one of the better options offered in this tiny alleyway. 

Food:
Very good! Reasonably priced and portioned. 

Atmosphere:
It's like I'm in a Paris Brasserie again. The decor was kind of busy, but evoked a feeling of Americana Road trip...cept with a bunch of Euro branded placards/posters. The servers all spoke French and addressed you as Monsieur which was neat. Here, you can actually practice the french you'd forgotten from high school w/o feeling like a tool. Merci beaucoup! Je vous dois combien? Ouvoir!

Summary:
Perfect place for a lunch/dinner date. Especially great if you wanna pretend to be more cultured than you actually are. :P
author: Jacky C.

description:
I came here on a Friday evening around 7:30 pm with a coworker. We didn't have a reservation, but the concierge at the Ritz Carlton recommended Belden Place, the alley where the restaurant was located, and told us to show the restaurant his card to get seated quickly. The alley is pedestrian only and had a very European feel to it; it was wonderful to walk through it and feel like I was being briefly transported to Montpellier or Nice. There were a lot of cool looking restaurants nearby, and it looked like all of them had both indoor and outdoor seating. However, since it was a cold evening in December, most of the outdoor seating was empty.

I was in the mood for French food so we picked Café Bastille; it's a little way into the alley but there was a little lit-up sign that pointed to the door, which was handy. There weren't a lot of people sitting outside but the inside was busier. We also heard there were a few large groups downstairs that night. The hostess asked if we had a reservation, but we were seated pretty quickly after presenting the hotel concierge's card. The restaurant was very heavily decorated with colorful French posters and a French flag hanging from the ceiling. There was a very quaint, charming ambiance that I enjoyed a lot. The service was quick and attentive and I appreciated that my water was refilled quite frequently.

As an appetizer we got the beef carpaccio, which is one of my favorite French apps; it was very tasty here and even my coworker, who is not very adventurous, thought it tasted great and had half the plate. The complimentary bread was delicious and warm and paired well with the carpaccio. I got the lapin à la moutarde as my entrée; it was pretty big and came with a generous helping of veggies, including carrots and pearl onions, which were so juicy and flavorful. The lapin jus was also really tasty. The dish came with pancetta, but I found that to be mostly superfluous. The rabbit meat was very tender and fell off the bone nicely. My coworker got the trout and really enjoyed it, although he finished it really quickly and started eating more of the complimentary bread after, so it might not have been enough food. I found my dish to be more than filling enough.

I really enjoyed eating here and am glad to have stopped by. For me the upsides were the flavor/quality of the food and the lovely European ambiance both inside and outside the restaurant. The bill, however, was hefty--for 1 app and 2 entrées our total bill came out to be about $85 including taxes/tip (no dessert or drinks). The restaurant was conveniently located about 2 blocks from our hotel, and really close to a lot of other restaurants and cafes both in and out of the Belden Place alley.
author: Connie L.

description:
Best stop of a great trip! We arrived for Saturday Brunch as they opened at 11:30. It was SF Restaurant week, and the dining room was entirely booked with reservations, but they found us a spot for two at the dining bar, and the staff was accommodating in every way.

Great atmosphere: small and cozy, tucked in an alley with a few other places that looked great to eat at, and walls decked with French advertisements and promotional signs. 

We got French Toast from the Brunch Menu (perfect) and the Roasted Beef Au Jus from the Lunch Menu (simple, but as good as we've had). They were able to sub as a side some mashed potatoes that were featured on the SF Restaurant promotional menu, which made the meal even better. Bottomless mimosas for $13 and good coffee.

We can't wait to come back!
author: Brett S.

description:
Redeemed a fixed prix Groupon deal here yesterday. Expect to pay an extra $25ish for tax & tip, but you definitely won't leave hungry.

The bread is very good. You could see and feel the steam coming out, and it was served warm enough to directly melt the butter. A bit too much crust for my liking though.

We both ordered the french onion soup to start off with, and that itself was a feast. A generous helping of bread, carmelized onions, and toasted cheese top were soaked in an extremely savoury soup. 

We also helped ourselves to a side of pommes frites. Wow. Surprsingly fantastic. Could not stop eating. Who knew the french could make the best french fries?!

I had the mushroom fettuccine which was a very large portion with very chunky mushrooms. It was OK but did seem to lack wow factor. 

Boyfriend ordered the coq du vin, a very savoury chicken noodle stew with giant carrots and pearl onions. There was a bit too much going on here, and not easy to eat, but I suppose that's tradition.

So full at this point but chocolate cake!! So chocolately without being too sweet, love love LOVE. Layers upon layers of love. 

Service was great, seated right away, lots of check-ins and water refills without ever being too intrusive. They proactively checked the heater as soon as we mentioned our outdoor seating. Their indoor space is huge too.
author: Katy Q.

description: Enjoyed the prix fix meal with wondetful onion soup.  It was a meal in itself.  Hot, melty cheese with bread, and sweetness of the onion.  Yum!  Beef bougonouf had chunks of meat and sticks of carrots and mushrooms.  I ate all the veggies and wished there were more.   Lastly the chocolate mousse cake.  The chocolate was so dense, not really mousse, so chocolatey.   Loved it and savour every bite. We had an extra dessert, crene brulee.  Didn't see vanilla beans but it had the best thin caramelized sugar on top. It was very creamy filling.  Great service,  attentive.  Great music.  A bit close tables.  Saw great drinks.  Every dish looked so good especially the mussels.  The bread hit the hungry spot when we got there.  Great French food!
author: Helen L.

description:
A salesperson at Gump's referred the 3 of us to this small and somewhat hidden gem for lunch before our matinee at SF Playhouse. The food was top notch, ample and reasonably priced. The service was friendly and adequate. ( Waitress was there when we needed her, but not fawning. She was quite busy.)
Truly the food, location and atmosphere will remind you of a French bistro.
author: Casey S.

description:
Came for a business lunch and sat inside since its a little crowded outside for a business lunch.  Service was excellent and the mussels were fantastic.  An absolutely huge bowl of wonderful and tender mussels. 

I liked the Plouf coconut broth better but this was a great choice nevertheless. Nice bread and sweet butter.  One of my guests spoke french which made it more authentic. 

I'd definitely come back.
author: Frank T.

description:
I wish I could remember our server's name because she was a delight and really saved the day. I was dying outside on a rare, hot SF day. She moved us downstairs even though it wasn't set for service and we were the only table down there, so she has to keep climbing the stairs. It was nice and cool and I was able to enjoy my brunch! Thank you SO much. 

The food - omgoshhh. Rarely do I find eggs poached perfectly to my liking. Runny yolk, absolutely no wiggly white parts! The Bastille Benedict was perfection. Husband had steak frites with a to die for peppercorn sauce. Steak was perfect and incredibly tender. Truly one of the best meals I've had in SF and such a charming feel to the place as well. Love!
author: Scarlett W.

description:
Ate here a long time ago (so good for them for still being in business!)...came here for dinner with a friend who had purchased a coupon/deal from one of those discount sites. 

Ordered the prix-fixe meal, as required. Had the salad which was just a bunch of spring lettuce (could have prepped this at home myself) with a few cornichons and olives thrown in...dressing didn't add much value. (When I spend money to eat out I want to eat something good that I can't or won't make at home.) 

For the entree had the boeuf bourgignon (against my better judgement to cut back on beef consumption but was tired of eating chicken at home & didn't care for the other choices)...beef was tender, with some potatoes, carrots, pearl onions...wasn't anything special. 

Lastly, had the chocolate mousse (cake, not mousse as advertised on menu), which was the best part of the meal -- that was very good. 

Service was good/friendly. Decent ambience. Tables were THISCLOSE so it was a little tight.
author: D L.

description:
We were in the area and decided to try this restaurant and were not disappointed.  Overall everything was great from the ambience to the food, value for the $ as well.

The 3 course prix fixe $39 menu is, for SF at least, nowadays considered to be a bargain.  The soupe a l'oignon, boeuf bourgignon, and mousse au chocolat were all tasty and prepared well.  In addition, they offer a choice of house wine by the carafe which, though common in France, is very very uncommon in SF.  Wine by the carafe was also a bargain.

If in the area again we'll return for sure.
author: Luisa T.

description:
This is my second visit to this super charming  place nestled in a pedestrian alleyway. It has a lot of character to it which is visually stimulating. 

I had to return to this place because it was so damn good the first time.

For appetizers we tried the escargots... omg the lovely butter pesto sauce was AMAZING and oh how tender the meat was! After that we tried something that absolutely surprised my tastebuds.  Savory bread pudding with goat cheese and balsamic vinegar. Now I rarely eat dairy or bread but had to taste this little number. I expected sweet but got this mouth watering savory flavor. Th goat cheese with balsamic just added to the right flavor and texture!!

I ordered the filet (rare of course) with the fresh veggie medley. First I have to say it was the largest filet I ever had... I expected a small portion but was surprised on the serving size. It just melted in my mouth hardly had to use my knife!  Yes there was a veal sauce on top normally I'm not a veal girl but it was sinfully good. The veggies were absolutely fresh and crisp how I like them. 
My coworker ordered the trout with lemon almond sauce it was absolutely delicious and I'm definitely getting that next time.  
My other coworkers ordered the mussels ... they said they were fantastic... I took their word for it so not a mussels fan!

If you're looking for charm great food definitely the right choice here 

It is a bit pricey so not your everyday place to eat
author: Traci W.

description: I have always liked this place it's been a couple of years since I've been here and it was yummy like always :) The service was very good quick and nice :) I had the red snapper and it was awesome :) I will be back soon :))
author: Joe K.

description: Fabulous atmosphere and great service.  I had the French Onion Soup...fab flavor and a  Cesar Salad...big enough to share ....reasonable prices.
author: Hyker J.

description: Was there on a Friday afternoon during the holidays. My friend said this place is a great warm up if you are visiting Paris, so decided to go here. The service was friendly and the menu was flexible for vegetarians. The bread was so so good! Not many vegetarian options but we worked something out, and it was rather tasty. I tried the chocolate drink, everyone who tried it loved it. But for the lack of vegetarian options, this was a cool experience.
author: Akhil K.

description: Food and service were enjoyable!  We tried it for restaurant week on a Sunday morning.  They were willing to seat us a little early, before they were open.  Already had fresh bread ready for us.  The restaurant week deal was two courses and let us sample a delicious beef stew and fancy chocolate dessert. Portion was big enough to fill me up and price was reasonable for the great quality, but keep in mind it was a special deal price. The restaurant is cozy and decorated, but bathroom is a bit dirty like old city.
author: Yishan X.

description:
Hubby and I always try a new restaurant during our twice yearly trips to San Francisco and decided on Cafe Bastille after purchasing a Groupon for the 3 course Prix Fixe Dinner and I am so glad that we did! We had a 5pm reservation but arrived a few minutes early and decided to sit outside even though it was a little chilly (the heaters were turned on and made the dinner very pleasant). 

The server was very nice and I immediately let her know about the Groupon and we placed our order. We both got the French onion soup (very good, lots of flavor), hubby ordered Coq Au Vin (smokey flavor, tender chicken stew) and I had the Mushroom Fettuccine (the noodles were very tender, the mushrooms had a smokey taste and it was a very good dish). We had Pave Chocolate Mousse for dessert and it was rich chocolaty deliciousness! We ordered a carafe of wine and was served warm baked bread.

We loved the food, the service and sitting outside, no complaints! We would definitely eat here again!
author: Vikki J.

description: It's one of my favorite spots in the city. Love the food. Love the atmosphere. Can't wait to come back to the city and eat there again soon!
author: Colleen C.

description:
I want coq au von! Killed me a bit on the inside when they told me it was sold out. I had coq au von at Eat Drink SF and been wanting to eat it again. 

I got the prefix menu: appetizer, entree and dessert. Since there was no coq au von, I ordered the moules (big bowl of mini mussels) and omg that was so yummy and they gave me so much! Also, came with a side of crispy fries. My friend got the beouf bourguignon ( beef brisket stew) and the meet was so tender. It just melts into your mouth and stomach. The chocolate mousse was good and the chocolate was rich, so it was a bit to sweet for me. 

The staff is super nice and accommodating because I had to change the reservation multiple times. Can't wait to come back for the coq au von!
author: Eva O.

description:
Found Café Bastille when searching for places to eat while in San Francisco, and after checking out some reviews my friends and I decided to give them a try!

They are in alley way of Belden Place, and it does give you the feeling of being in a European café.

To start off with I ordered Le Parisien, a flute of champagne, raspberry coulis and passion flavored cognac, this was a great drink, and very pretty.

After checking out the menu I went with the Croque Monsieur, it was ham, gruyere between two slices of bread, topped with a béchamel sauce and lightly fried, it was just what I was craving!

I knew I wanted to try some of there of desserts so gave the menu a glace and went with Ile Flottante, or floating island, it was a sweet meringue floating on top of crème angaise with caramel on the bottom of the bowl and topped with sliced almonds, this was a very decadent dessert, light, sweet and filling.

I also went with a cappuccino, and again this too was perfect!

Service was great and friendly and the meal was perfect! Next time I am in the Bay Area, I will be back!
author: Monica O.

description:
Bonjour future customer of Café Bastille!
 
I have been to this restaurant many, many times and this is the first time I am writing about it.  I first went there in high school and my time was memorable ... I don't think Yelp was around yet.  But now visiting Café Bastille after a few years along with a trip to Paris under my belt - I love the restaurant even more.  The ambience, the food, and service keep it as a San Francisco gem. 
 
Also, the location has a hint of romance tucked in Belden Alley and it is dimly lit.  Along the walls are colorful French signs with white marble tables.  I think this place would be a great first date or in my case multiple dates.
 
During my most recent visit, I enjoyed their pork chop.  It was huge for one person, so I recommend sharing or if you're not that hungry - don't order this.  The sauce poured on top of it was rich and robust.  There was obviously a healthy amount of wine, but who's complaining?
 
Secondly, I am a pomme frites fanatic.  So, per usual I ordered for the table and it is a MUST for any other first-time guest.  It comes with a simple aioli that is perfect with the thinly fried potato.  I recommend pairing it is ideally paired with one of their white wines.
 
All the food was delivered in a timely manner.  Just like my last trip to Paris, where I learned that the cafes and bistros allow you take your time eating.  Eating and drinking is a patient experience.  At Café Bastille, they do not rush you and they ask you if you're ready for the next part of your meal.  It's not all brought out at once unless requested.  They want you to enjoy the food and experience everything they have to offer.
 
Bonne appetit!
author: Angela D.

description: Great French restaurant in San Francisco. It's in that little alley with all the restaurants by Kearny between Bush and Pine. The beef bourgeoise was good, and so was the steak although a tad salty. Cozy atmosphere too.
author: Peter K.

description:
Came here for Brunch on Saturday. Fairly empty location, plenty of open seating both indoors and outdoors. The atmosphere itself isn't the best. Indoors has very low lighting and a bit on the dirty side. Outdoors is in the middle of an alleyway so there's dust and loud noises.

The food here is definitely very filling. I got a salmon benedict and it came with a salad, couple slices of an orange, a generous portion of potatoes and half a loaf of bread (which is refillable). The taste itself was okay, didn't really stand out or seem that memorable. I did really like the strawberries in the salad though! 

If the other brunch locations in the area are busy, this definitely isn't a bad place to go to but it wouldn't be my first few choices.
author: Cassie Z.

description: Cafe Bastille was everything I love in a cafe. The seating was outdoors, the waiters were perfect, and the menu pricing was reasonable. The ambiance is charming and everything I ate was so good! I ordered the plain crepe and was blown away by its taste. I'd definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for French cuisine or just somewhere cute to have lunch.
author: Bidisa M.

description: I love the service, well served, moderate price, casual and pretty comfortable. Most of all, I felt happy and relax to have dinner there.
author: Jane D.

description: Cafe Bastille is the closest to a Paris restaurant I have found in the United States.  The simple menu of French classic dishes and a good wine list.  I come here when I am in San Francisco. The server remembered my wife from last year. It is close to the French embassy so expect foreigners.  My favorite is the pate selection and a quarter carafe of the house wine.
author: Art H.

description:
I went to Cafe Bastille on a friends recommendation and I was not disappointed at all - it's not a fancy place and the seats outside are not the best if you are tall but the overall experience was wonderful ! 
I had the mussels and the others in my party had the duck confit and the coq au vin- All three dishes were very very good.
I would not recommend it for a romantic dinner (the tables are very very close to one another) but if you're looking for a great meal with friends it's perfect.
We had made reservations so I can't comment on wait times since our table was waiting for us. The place was full by mid evening
author: Jean-Paul D.

description: We have been here 3 times now and each time is a treat!   I'm not a huge French foodie, but the food here is delicious and the service is friendly.  Our server did a great job of making sure that my boyfriend understood what the entree he ordered (the tripe sausage). My beet salad was beautiful and very yummy.  My beef Shepard's pie( my translation) was divine.  If I could have crawled inside, I would have.  This is a great neighborhood French bistro.  It's not fancy or pretentious, just good old country French food.
author: Bridget M.

description:
Cafe Bastille came off as a satisfactory place to have lunch if one is craving French cuisine. Does the food blow you away? Hardly. 

I came here for lunch with a new coworker on an impromptu visit, and while it took a little while for the waiter to have us seated with menus (they seemed understaffed at the time), that wasn't the reason for the A-OK rating. For me, it's always the food. 

Chicken Cordon Bleu ($21, I believe): For those who aren't familiar with the dish that bears the same name as that one culinary school in the Bay Area, this is ham and Swiss cheese wrapped in chicken prior to being cooked. My dish in particular came out well-cooked for the most part, save for a few spots where it was still cold. The dish also came with cooked potato slices and a salad, which I enjoyed slightly more than the chicken itself. When one enjoys the sides more than the main part of the meal, that's not a good thing at all. 

Service was a little long, but I've had worse experiences, so that's not a huge knock on them. 

Overall, while Bastille is a decent restaurant, you can definitely find a better French restaurant to dine in than this place.
author: Viet N.

description: Great place for dinner in the financial district. Fast service and the prix fixe menu is a great deal for two! If you're looking for something cozy yet great for people watching, try the outdoor seats under the heat lamp.
author: Nancy W.

description:
Food was all right, service was all right, price was a RIPOFF!!!!

We went here with a Groupon of $49 on a $76 meal. Well, read the fine print because they tax on the $76 and put an automatic 18% gratuity. 

So be prepared to spend $25 after buying the Groupon.
author: Dimitri Jim A.

description: Went here for brunch on a weekend and loved it! Got their bottomless mimosa deal and an ahi tuna salad. I finished ALL of it! The server was generous with the mimosas and even gave us a carafe after we took care of the check and were looking like we were ready to leave. Overall, I love this place and will be back with more friends!
author: Louise C.

description: Simply the best. Authentic French cuisine and friendly staff ... and selection of wine and spirits is phenomenal.
author: Vika S.

description: The food here was ok. I had the COQ AU VIN and the chicken was pretty dry and over cooked. The sauce could be better and tasted pretty blan. The service was pretty slow for a restaurant that doesn't seem that busy. Not really worth the money. I had a glass of wine, salad, with the chicken, and a dessert and it was about $60 per person. My friend had about the same thing, but he had beef instead. The beef was under cook and kinda dry as well
author: C N.

description:
Got some mushroom crepes and a yummy beautifully presented raspberry dessert. 

French ambience,cool posters,quick and helpful service.Nice outside seating space.You'll feel like you are in Paris.
author: Priyanka L.

description: The whole trout was light and flavorful. Boneless was a nice bonus. Capers, spinach and of course butter to finish off the fish was perfect. Escargot was not bad. The sauce plus bread was a hearty appetizer.
author: Khoo K.

description: The food here is absolutely amazing. I had the French Onion soup & Steak Tartare. Both of the dishes were mouth watering. It felt like I was eating my meal in Paris. Friendly and prompt service. Definitely a must try when in San Fran.
author: Ann S.

description:
I will give 3.5, I came for onion soup, Google said this is one of the best place to have.  It taste better than it looks, looks a bit separated, burn, taste was good, I suspect they may have Maui onion in it, it was very sweet, most other places are typically to salty, not here, here is sweet.  Wish there were more cheese though.
The lamb sausage was average, nothing spectacular.  Service was good, slow may be but I was not in any rush.  When I ask for Dijon mustard, I was offered a reddish spicy sauce, I was explained what it was, what it use for, etc. nice gesture.  Too bad I forgot it.  Overall decent, not high end.  I wish they have duck confit for lunch too.
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
Finding a reasonable decent restaurant in the Financial District still challenges me.  This was a lucky happy find.  

The decor could be updated and spiffed up, but everything else was superb. 

Excellent service, delicious and varied food.  Really good portions. The duo of salmon appetizer is particularly recommended. 

Price was downtown reasonable.

Great place for unpretentious French Bistro fare in the Financial District.
author: Ghengis G.

description:
Came here for team lunch and the food was okay. The service was great, but the food took forever to come so we were all hangry. 

Cheese plate was very good, and so were the desserts. We asked for "blue rare" steak, but the steak that was served was so overcooked they were almost well done. 

I did enjoy my mussels quite a bit though :)
author: Christina N.

description:
Came here with a couple friends after work one day, and made a reservation through Open Table. We were seated right away, and happened to get here right before the dinner rush came in a little after 6:00. We sat on the outside patio, which had a really nice ambiance, and really made it seem like we were at an authentic French restaurant. Surprisingly although this place sits in somewhat of an alley, it didn't smell or have any strange people walking nearby.

We started of with an order of the escargot for the table. This was my first time trying it, and since I'll eat mostly anything I was excited to see what it was like. My first impression was that it was delicious! For those who have never had it, it has a pretty similar texture and consistency to a clam, and the sauce its made in is to die for! Highly suggest dipping the fresh french bread they bring you in the sauce because it pairs so well.

For my entrée, I wanted to try something new, so I ordered the coq au vin. It definitely did not disappoint! I'm usually not a fan of ordering chicken dishes at restaurants because they tend to be pretty basic and I always feel like I can make it better myself, but this chicken had so many delicious flavors and elements going for it that made it special. The sauce was really potent, and you can actually taste the wine in it which I really loved. 

It was also my friend's birthday a few days prior, so I let the waitress know and she was kind enough to knock off the price of the corkage fee for the wine we brought ($15), and in return told us to pick a dessert for her. We got the chocolate pear tart which was delicious! It had a tasty whipped cream on top, which was almost like an ice cream. So good!

Overall, I'd highly recommend this place if you're looking for authentic and quality French food in the city. There's actually a lot of options in the area but I suggest trying this place if you can!
author: Jaymie S.

description: Expensive but nice. Took my team out for a celebratory dinner and it was super fun.  Wine bottles are well priced but a lack of vegetarian dishes made me feel A bit left out!!!
author: Rashmi V.

description:
Business Lunch Meeting 
Menu was as small as possible. (Items)

You can be seated inside or outside. Prefer only outside. Its very hard to sit inside for groups.
I tried Grilled Poulet which was chicken sandwich with bacon and pesto sauce. 

very good place for wine and dine.
author: Siva Sankar G.

description: I went there a few times and enjoyed food each time, the staff is nice and the place is cozy. However the last time we were here was for Bastille Day, there was a prix fixe menu, the food was tasteful but It was overpriced. They did not have enough staff that night, the waiters were so confused that we were offered the check before the desert, which was included in our meal. I would recommend the place for a week night dinner.
author: Julien B.

description: Loved the location & the ambiance, but the food was terrible, over sauced and expensive for what it was. Also, for a French restaurant, the wine list really could have been better. The server was kind and patient, but she clearly had too many tables going because we waited forever to place our order. Oh and just for the record, pretty sure fettuccini Alfredo isn't French so it was strange that it was featured on the menu ;)
author: Janine T.

description: I brought my daughter here a few years ago for her school's French Club field trip to SF. We ordered the Croque Madame for lunch and loved it! We returned today to celebrate my daughter's 18th birthday for dinner. She was bummed to find out they did not have Croque Madame on the dinner menu. However, they made it for us and we were soooo happy!!!! It was cooked to perfection!
author: Miss M.

description: Authentic French cuisine and atmosphere. It's not cheap but the food is good. Special kudos for the fries. They can really call themselves French. I mean if fries could call themselves nothing. Very friendly staff. Talks French and English of course
author: Ron H.

description: Cute little French bistro, homie food and very comfortable ambiance. Excellent service.
author: Jane L.

description: This is a nice French Restaurant located on Belden Alley.  Located in the east side of San Francisco's "French Quarter".  The customer service and food for this restaurant is very good. I enjoyed my previous dinning experiences there.  I highly recommend their Prix Fixe menu.  It is even better if you use a Groupon for it. I liked their French Onion Soup. It was well made. It had a nice layer a cheese on top. It had the right flavor to it.  I also enjoyed their Coq au Vin.  It was flavorful and the meat was perfectly cook.  I also tried their Boeuf Bourguignon (beef stew). It too was also flavorful and well made.  You cannot go wrong picking one or the other.  The bread service was also memorable. The bread was warm and toasty with ample butter.   For dessert, I really enjoyed the Pavé Chocolate Mousse.  It was creamy and had a strong chocolate flavor.  I also recommend their Cafe Latte.  It was served in a bowl (which is how they drink it in France.) and came with a piece of chocolate.  It was well made.  It was not too bitter. Furthermore, I recommend dinning outside in the alleyway. It was not too cold for me and provided a nice European dinning ambiance.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
Excellent food and customer service. I had the boeuf bourguignon, onion soup, pate (duck, pork, and campagne), and chocolate Souffle.

I will certainly be back to try the other dishes on their menu. I would definitely recommend Cafe Bastille!
author: Vicki G.

description:
Every once in a while, while in the confines of your office in San Francisco, you want to go on a mini adventure.  Let's go to Paris!  Café Bastille is secretly tucked away in Belden Lane in a small alleyway that's easy to miss.

It may not look like much when you go inside, but all signs (there are many in the café) point to a very casual setting.  Most of the waiters have this French accent and if you parle un peu français, you can strike up a conversation with them!

Took my boss here for her much belated birthday lunch, and her go to order every single time is the open faced salmon sandwich with a side of salad.  I ordered the steak tartare, which came with a side of house salad and french fries.  The tartare goes great with the complimentary bread they serve.

It's a nice getaway spot for lunch if you want to be whisked away to a breathe of fresh air, even more so when it's a sunny day outside where you can grab a table outside!
author: Kevin C.

description: Brunch here is great! The bottomless mimosas are a must. The outside seating is nice. Recommend!
author: Gayane S.

description:
My friend and I really enjoyed this French delight! We went on a Groupon and will definitely return. My friend had the steak and fries which was really delicious! I had the coq au vin and the signature French dish was so superior in taste and heartiness! Yes, very hearty indeed! The restaurant is nestled away off the main street in between tall buildings of the FiDi which added to its allure. The staff are French and very friendly. Overall, great little place. Can get very busy in the evening. They do have an outdoor seating area which is how you enter the restaurant. Very cute place. 

However, parking, be prepared to pay around $30-$40 for area garages if you're driving. It's to be expected downtown SF. Definitely give this restaurant a try!
author: Tiffany M.

description: We had steak tartare, frisée aux lardons, escargots, and the trout. Wonderful sauces and nice portions for sharing. Everything was tasty and authentic. Staff was friendly and accommodating. My favorite spot in Belden alley so far.
author: Caroline M.

description: Great place. We arrived today at 11:10 & we were able to be seated even though service would not start for 20 minutes. Server Sabina was friendly and we were able to order Bloody Mary's while we waited for the kitchen to open. We started with the Duo of Salmon which we thoroughly enjoyed. I ordered the grilled lamb merguez sausage w/ratatouille & couscous. My wife had the mushroom spinach & goat cheese crepe & both were awesome. The music that played made the experience even better. Ran into this spot just walking around the city & we were really glad we turned down the alley it was in. I'd recommend to a friend & I'll be back to try the Boudin Noir blood sausage.
author: Eric W.

description:
We came here for a birthday lunch.  I got a chicken sandwich.  The chicken was juicy and it wasn't burnt as the case with most grilled chicken sandwiches.  The bread was nice and crunchy too.  

For dessert, I ordered the ILE FLOTTANTE, or floating island.  It's basically meringue floating in custard.  Super yummy and not overly sweet.

Service was friendly.  We sat inside because I don't like dining with the flying rats aka pigeons.
author: Wendy H.

description:
We found it by chance and had a good surprise
We are french but leaving in US and it tasted like home! Really good clean and fast
author: Lna R.

description:
We had a groupon for a pre-fix meal, but was unable to redeem it due to arriving at lunchtime. So, we were given the value paid of $49.00 (standard practice) instead of receiving the pre-fix meal. Unfortunately we were charged 18% gratuity (also medical/outdoor dining fee) at a rate of the pre-fix meal instead of the value paid. We both ordered a sandwich and a appetizer to share which was under the value paid of $49.00, but the bill somehow was padded to $70.00.
Unethical and please make sure to receive your pre-fix meal since your definitely being charged for it.
author: Patricia W.

description:
Location is so charming and unique, its in an alley between three or four other restaurants. Overall great ambiance and great service. 

The menu has a good selection of french food. I recommend the french onion soup, mussels, and chocolate mousse ganache! The bread they serve is delicious, fresh and warm! All portions and prices are great. 

Wine selection was good too, ended up getting a Sonoma County wine. I didn't check if they actually had french wines.
author: Allie G.

description: An unpretentious French restaurant that has a very low-key, cozy, neighborhood feel to it. The prices are reasonable and they offer a good variety of traditional French dishes. I came here slightly buzzed from House of Shields. We started with lamb merguez, of which the couscous with golden raisins was divine. Unfortunately, I was not too crazy about my lapin (rabbit) a la moutarde, but I am more than willing to return and try the coq au vin and boeuf bourguignon. Incredibly cute interior decor.
author: Christina S.

description: This place is great. The staff is super friendly and their food is as authentic as it gets. (I'm French)
author: Thomas B.

description: The moules/frites are outstanding.  Their frisee salad with the poached egg est magnifique!!!  My husband loved his lamb shank and their soupe l'oignon....superbe!!!  Love this little alley (Belden Place) and this restaurant never disappoints.
author: Annie P.

description:
- The Food
*French Onion Soup | Tasteless and with no flavor whatsoever. It's hard to say that but I felt like I was just drinking water. Maybe I was unlucky but the only good thing I remembered about the soup was "eating" the Gruyere cheese.
*Escargots Bourguignon | I love snails. I do. The escargots were well cooked but I wish the garlic and the parsley butter had a more pronounced flavor. That's only a personal preference so overall, the snails were not bad at all. I would get that again for some appetizers! 
*Crêpe complète | Egg, Cheese, and Ham. I wish that was not a crêpe, but a galette. Just realized my mistake of ordering and eating this. Do not order this here. It was bloody disgusting. I apologize but It felt like the crêpe was not fully cooked yet, and that made it somewhat gross to eat. I'll get something else next time.

+ Service
Nothing fancy. Decent. I, however, do like the atmosphere of the place with Parisian and French decorations. Makes me feel like I'm almost back home.

- Overall
I cannot recommend anything, sorry Cafe Bastille. I would have to come again and perhaps try something else and then update my review because the food I ordered were not good at all that day. For now: Much disappointed. I just did not have a great experience that day.
I see that if you actually speak French to the Chef, you may get some good stuff. Maybe I'll try that next time. 

J'aimerais bien un Steak Frites... Ça a l'air pas mal.
author: Alex L.

description:
Luv'd this place!

Ambiance is terrific, topped only but great service. Friendly and fast so nice. 

Groupon lured us in and we'll be back!

Delicious, warm bread. Good French onion soup. Ordered more bread. 

Nice French lager on draft. 

Good coq au vin. Better beef bourginon. Heavenly chocolate mousse.
author: Benny M.

description:
We came here with a Groupon deal that included appetizer, main course and dessert per person for 2. Me and my boyfriend both got the onion soup as appetizer which was really good and filling! For main course I got the cassoulet as a substitute to what they offered on the deal ($5 surcharge for substitution), it was delicious especially the duck confit! For dessert, I had the raspberry key lime mousse, I liked the perfect balance of tart and sweetness.

There is a different ambiance between inside and outside of the restaurant. Outside was more of a casual atmosphere better for 4 or more people. If you want a more quiet and intimate ambiance, opt for inside seating.
author: Dianne P.

description: I really enjoyed my meal here, my boeuf bourguignon was delicious.  The decor was charming and service wonderful.
author: L L.

description: I was very disappointed in the quality and flavor of my meal. No one else at the table 'raved' about their food. Good things, nice wine list reasonably priced, warm baguette and soft butter. The French onion soup did not have the depth of flavor that comes from multiple caramelization of the onions; just broth, onion, bread and some cheese. At one point I thought it tasted like dishwater-perhaps missing seasoning. The mussels are a huge bowl, probably over 3 dozen. I began to dig in and soon found that they were so small-the meat inside was about the size of a dime. Most were overcooked and disintegrated when I put a fork to them (I also didn't get a small fork so the salad fork destroyed them). Many shells were empty. I wonder if this is a bag of frozen mussels warmed in the broth. Usually I dig into mussel broth (ordered the white wine broth option) with bread, but again, no seasoning or flavor here. I left half the bowl. The fries were pretty good, though lots of salt. The desert on the prix fixe menu clearly had been setup ahead of time and refrigerated. It was ok but the plate and desert were too cold. The menu is full of your expected French favorites, duck confit, beef Bourgogne, coq au vin, steak frites, etc. the execution was poor.
author: Ginger B.

description:
Does anybody remember this little exchange in Mel Brooks' "History of the World, Part One"?...
Madame DeFarge: "We are so poor, we do not even have a language! Just this stupid accent!"
Fellow Revolutionist: "She's right, she's right! We all talk like Maurice Chevalier!... Au-haw-haw!"
Crowd: "Au-haw-haw!" 

That's how I feel when I go to French restaurants. Au-haw-haw. I haven't said a complete sentence in French since Miss Amble's class in high school. But somehow a place like Cafe Bastille makes me think I should talk like Celine Dion with a lot of wild arm gestures: "Eet eez a pleazure to be here and I am sure a privilege for vous...since I am the greatest singer in the world!" Funny thing was that I was with a full-fledged French person when I visited here last week, and her fluency and natural élan made the dining experience so much better than it would have been had it been just me with a Berlitz food dictionary. Since my dining companion is a working mother of a toddler, I thought she might like lunch in a bistro from her days of yore.

But it wasn't all about her. I really wanted a reason to order French Onion Soup given the intense cold snap we've been having of late. For $7.95, they serve a warm little crock gooey with Gruyère over toasted baguette slices (see photo). I have to disclose that the broth was a bit too watery to be completely satisfying, but the overall warmth did the trick. This was followed by the pleasing $12 Frisée aux Lardons, a nice size bowl swimming with curly endive in a warm shallot dressing, peppered with hearty chunks of pancetta and crispy croutons, and topped with a breaded poached egg (see photo). Now that was delicious in that oh-so Parisian way that makes me think I am Ina Garten with her often absent Jeffrey at a sidewalk cafe. How good is that?

We shared the last dish, her recommendation of a $12 appetizer portion of the Quenelle de Lyon, a dish completely foreign to me but something she makes at home. Quite a nice treat as it was a quartet of fish dumplings in a nantua sauce, which is a Béchamel blended with heavy cream and crayfish butter (see photo). Decadent? Oh I'd say so but tasty as it was baked in a dish like a calorific lasagna. She mentioned that she had never seen it prepared that way, that most people simply pour the Béchamel over the dumplings without the final step of baking it. I have to admit I rather liked that final touch. Three appetizer-size dishes and we were quite satiated. So much so that I felt like singing... "Neeeeear.... faaaaaar.... wheeeeere-evuhhhh you arrrre!"

FOOD - 4 stars...a weak broth marred an otherwise lovely bistro dejeuner
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...ah, it is Belden Place, so faux-Europe awaits here
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...hearing the French dialogue between my companion and the server with no subtitles made me wish Miss Amble was there to hit me with her lesson ruler
TOTAL - 4 stars...been a long time since my last visit to the Bastille but I'm glad I came... au-haw-haw
author: Ed U.

description: Excellent!! We got to sit on the patio and the weather was beautiful. The waiter was exceptional and very attentive. I went with a party of eight and everyone's food was out of this world. I would highly recommend this restaurant for A nice romantic date or even a meeting.
author: michelle b.

description: It doesn't get more authentic than this.  The staff are (very friendly & attentive) French the ambiance is the French metro and the food... Delicious!  From the homemade hot bread to the chocolate mousse dessert the food was beautifully prepared and delicious.  The French Onion Soup was amazing.  Has a rich sweet flavor, toast and tons of melty cheese.  The cow au vin was roasted with rosemary and lots of perfect young potatoes and pearl onions and tiny mushrooms. We ordered a bottle of  Bordeaux, which paired with the meal all the way through.
author: Cathie R.

description: We were a group of 12 that included friends of 40 years and our 20 something children.  We sat outside which was excellent.  A wide selection of food and everyone was pleased with their dishes.  My rabbit was the best I have ever had.  Very good wine, cocktail, and beer selection.  Convenient to the BART so SF and Oakland people were happy.  I thought the service was excellent.  I would go again.
author: Hardin C.

description: Great place, really good food. As a Frenchmen I recommend this place it reminds me of the good food from home. You need to try the cassoulet, delicious dish from Carcassonne, ca fait peter sous les chaumières !
author: Benjamjn R.

description:
We came here for the prix fixe meal (there was a deal on Groupon). Overall, the meal was very disappointing, but the service and ambiance were delightful. 

After all is said and done, the Groupon is not a great deal. They tax on the pre-Groupon total so we ended up paying an extra $25 on top of what I already paid for the Groupon. Had the meal been cheaper, I might have given 3 stars, but the quality of food was so poor for a place that supposedly specializes in French food and comes out to $70 AFTER a discount.

Food:
-The bread was the best part of the meal. Perfect crust, soft on the inside, warm...yum! 
-French onion soup: the cheese was yummy, but the broth and onions didn't have any flavor. Another Yelper said it was like water which I thought was a pretty harsh comment...until I tried it. 
-Baby lettuce salad: my tablemate finished this and had no complaints. It was pretty much lettuce with some little pickles on the side. 
-Beef bourguignon: I really wanted to like this but the meat was chewy, the broth didn't have any flavor, and the potatoes were so overcooked they were almost mealy. 
-Mushroom Fettuccine: This smelled like truffles and looked beautiful. But sadly, the flavor was lacking in the sauce, the mushrooms, and the spinach. After I added a lot of salt and pepper we were able to enjoy it a little more. Also, this dish came out barely warm. 
-Raspberry mousse and chocolate mousse: these were okay, but I won't be craving them in the future. 

Service: No complaints here. The waitress and assistant waiter kept our waters full, brought bread quickly, boxed our food and desserts, and were friendly. 

Ambiance: loved sitting outside. Even on a cool night, the heaters were just perfect.
author: Susan G.

description:
A great place to experience the flavor of France with an excellence in service.
One can forget you are in san francisco and not Paris as soon as you sit down.
The food is so much better then you could taste in Paris for much less.
Always made welcome and accommodated for every desire
author: andrew t.

description:
I had the Prefix consisting of salad, fettuccine and desert.  My dinner guest had the Onion soup, beef Bourguignon and soup.  I found the food to be OK but nothing special.  

The most offensive aspect of the meal was the cigarette smoking occurring at one of the tables outside.  The restaurant obviously knew that this was occurring and ignored it because the smokers were regulars.
author: Dennis W.

description:
We came here for the 3-course Prix fixe menu on "date night".  The restaurant looked old-school, with unpretentious cosy North Beach decor, and warm lighting.  Service was excellent and the food did not disappoint.


---- DRINKS ----

Sidecar: 4.5 stars


---- FOOD ----

French Onion Soup: 4.5 stars
Thinner broth and wasn't too salty or rich. Perfect cheese-to-broth ratio. Delicious and had an unusual slightly sweet taste.

Chicken Tajine: 4.5 stars.
A hearty stew in pottery.

Mussels: 4.5 stars
Holy steamed mussels, Batman! There was so much here, two of us filled plates with shells and had to let maybe a dozen extra mussels go to waste cuz we were just too full. Served with a big basket of crispy fries in an oily creamy sauce.


---- DESSERT ----

Raspberry Key Lime Pie mousse: 2 stars
The only disappointment of the night.  This was more soggy cake than mousse.

Chocolate mousse: 4 stars

Would definitely come back for another date night!
author: Letitia L.

description: Groupon and this place have a great scheme going on. Groupon is for 49$ but you end up paying 25 more (in taxes + mandatory 18% gratuity -read fine print- plus some mandatory SF thingy). So, essentially this is not a deal at all coz final bill is anyways gonna be 76$. Very nasty move - Groupon+Cafe Bastille. NOTE: Free passive smoking services available. People smoke all the time within 5 feet of the place and by the end of the meal you have passively smoked cigarettes for an entire fortnight.
author: Sharath Chandra Y.

description: Seared Tuna sandwich was really good. The salad was light and the dressing not overpowering. I would get it again. This is a cluster of nice alley restaurants in this area. I would come back for more.
author: Ben L.

description:
Cocktails were delicious! Salad was over dressed and unbalanced in flavors. Their coq au vin was poorly made, the flavors were off and missing many components. I've never had it on pasta before either,it  usually is served on a bed of potatoes. Red wine used in this dish wasn't of good quality.. it was poorly executed. Dessert was ok..but Service was really good.

 I wouldn't recommend this place to have dinner at but I would probably recommend this place to meet up for a cocktail or two.
author: Tru T.

description:
Two words: beef carpaccio. Get in my mouth!!!!

I visited this establishment for a lunch get together during the Dreamforce convention. I was very impressed with the service from the get go. Give me a handsome man with an accent who takes his job seriously...whew. Done. 

The food was delicious...I had dish envy when everyone's food was delivered to the table, but that all disappeared when I had my first bite of the carpaccio. Unbelievable. It's really a shame that this dish is not on more menus because I have hankerings for it all of the time.

The only thing I'd say recommendation wise would be to pump some sort of smell good into the basement (where we were seated). It smelled very strongly of sewer which is not an appetizing smell at all. I noticed it outside when I was walking down the alley, too, so it may not be something they have a lot of control over, but some sort of scent to combat it might help.
author: Emily P.

description:
Even though this place isn't what I would call vegetarian/vegan-friendly, you can definitely get by if you are one.  I came here for a joint birthday dinner and was accommodated by the wonderful waitstaff here. 

My waitress was super friendly, and I asked her what she would recommend and gave me a rundown of my options.  There was one main dish that was meatless, but she also suggested getting a plate of all the sides LOL which is what I did and it was delicious.  

It consisted of sauteed cauliflower with pesto sauce, sauteed green beans, and some delicious garlic mashed potatoes. 

AND

It was way cheaper than everyone else's meals and I was stuffed.  I also got a way larger portion than most peeps.  All the girlz were jelly. 

OH I forgot to mention the bread here is CRAZY delicious.  It's served warm, and it was commented that it was legit french bread because it has a "holy" inner appearance when sliced (like sourdough).

The Frenchies were going berzerk over the bread I'm not even joking, apparently good bread is hard to find in San Francisco.  One girl hogged the basket to herself because she missed good french bread so much. 

Alsooooo

Eating outside is super duper disgustingly cute because it's in an alley way with a bunch of other restaurants, but we had the whole downstairs to ourselves which was chill too.
author: Christina L.

description:
French food cooked by...well, not by anyone French. This is our favorite cuisine, but the balance and skillful technique don't exist here. Sooo close...but in the end, a miss. This is not Gaspar or Chapeau, sadly. We had:

Soup du jour, supposedly potato-leek. I use the words "supposedly" because it tasted more like cauliflower-leek to me. Spouse found it salty and thin-tasting, even though it was creamy. 

Frisée aux lardons, one of my favorite salads...but not here. Café Bastille's version had old frisée that was chopped, and way too much cider vinegar. The only good part was that the egg was at the right temperature. This salad is quintessentially French -- balance is everything. Although I love pork, there were too many lardons, making this a salad of excess instead. Not the worst Salad Lyonnaise I've had, but far from the best.

Merguez with cous-cous. We were happy to find the merguez the traditional thin, chewy, gamy sausage we love. Many restaurants have switched to the D'Artagnan brand, which is fat, fine-grained, and so ridiculously mild it could be mistaken for a beef knackwurst instead. The cous-cous was fine, mixed with dried fruit. 

Roasted marrow, a generous dish of three long halves. Liked the spicy bread crumbs, appreciated the unbuttered croutes. Marrow is so rich it needs no additional fat with it.

Blanc noir (blood) sausage. Good, but the sauerkraut was ridiculously salty with too much bacon. 

Daily special: wild halibut in white wine-butter sauce. Fish wasn't fresh, was pan-browned too long with too much black pepper on it, it wasn't salted at all, and had a strange mushy texture on the inside. The sauce was light on the lemon but too heavy on the butter. It made the dish over-the-top, cloyingly rich. A terrible combination with a mushy fish whose crusty exterior was so tough I had to use a steak knife to saw through it. The portion was generously sized, but the quality and execution were third-rate at best.

Crepes Suzette. Perfunctory tableside service, sloppily performed. The orange sauce is already in the pan. The waiter pours the liqueur (Cointreau?) over and then lights it. The flame is low and weak, not really enough to properly warm the sauce. Little or no butter. 

Bastille in the end was sadly average, meaning mediocre French. We liked the merguez and the marrow, but neither dish requires much thinking or training from the kitchen. When it came down to actually executing a balanced array of flavors in a Gallic bistro standard, Bastille's kitchen gets a "D".

Service was very good and efficient, but they weren't crowded on a Thursday evening.
author: Jean K.

description:
We've been looking around for a decent French restaurant for a while now, and decided to give this one a try.  They have a groupon with a pre-fixed menu, though there are a few choices each for appetizer, main course, and desert. 

The French onion soup was particularly good, especially with the provided bread.  The beef bourgnion was great too, as well as both of their desert choices.  Both the food and outdoor seating area were great, and left us very satisfied.  Excellent service as well, especially from the busser.  We will surely come back.  

Just be warned, even with the groupon it is pricey, perhaps a little too much.  It turned out very well for us though, so we didn't mind.
author: Lars T.

description:
Had a Groupon coupon so stopped by Cafe Bastille before our theater date. Wait staff was very aware of our time and made sure food came out timely.
Location was great with really fun out door seating. Food was delicious and portion sizes were so generous. Had plenty to take along home. Will visit again but forget the Groupon. It was NOT a good deal
author: M B.

description: Stopped in for lunch at Cafe Bastille and fell in love with the cozy atmosphere.  I ordered escargot and fries for my meal, which I enjoyed, and my fiancé enjoyed his chicken sandwich.  The service was attentive & kind.  I would definitely return.
author: Michelle R.

description: One day f my fave spots tucked away on an alley called Belden Ave. great food, ambience and location. Sit outside under the umbrellas and load up on pate', mussels, bread and bottomless mimosas if you catch it right. You'll enjoy making friends with people at the adjoining tables.
author: Eric D.

description: Absolutely fabulous food. The rabbit, braised beef & mashed potatoes, and crusty bread loaf were the best we've had.  The French Sangria was refreshing & staff friendly and attentive.  The place is very small with tiny tables close together so you get to know your neighbors pretty well but it can be fun to meet new folks in a quaint new place in SF.
author: Greta S.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed a little sojourn here for lunch. We sat inside, downstairs - which was perfect because SF was baking in 80 degree weather. Not only did my party of 5 enjoy comfortable temperatures, but it was delightfully quiet and not cramped. I felt like we were winning at work lunching. 

Service was very friendly and a bit slow, but the pace made me feel like we really might be in France, taking our time at lunch instead of racing through. 

The food was very good. I had a mushroom and cream crepe, and added a poached egg. Hadn't eaten breakfast, and felt no need to eat dinner. Kind of perfect.
author: Alicia O.

description:
The first thing you'll notice about Cafe Bastille is the atmosphere, it really feels like a European cafe! I like the fact that they have outdoor seating, which my friends and I were able to enjoy in December... a real treat for someone coming from Michigan!
