The cafe offers beer, wine and cocktails, and everyone was happy with their choices (I tried a sauvignon blanc). For dinner, I had trout and it was fresh and perfectly cooked. My friends tried beef stew and rabbit.
The best part: dessert! We split a chocolate pear tart and creme brulee, both were fantastic!
author: Allison S.

description: I liked the cafe's location, and it was luckily one of the few places open when my friend and I were looking for somewhere to have brunch/lunch. It wasn't busy when we went, but it was very loud anyway due to the other customers. The staff was friendly, but probable could have been more attentive. The food (seared tuna sandwich with a green salad) was a good, sizeable portion, but I found it lacked some flavour. Overall, the experience was meh, but I'd be willing to give it another shot the next time I'm around
author: Bianca C.

description: Efficient friendly service. Prix-fixe salad was good, dessert OK, but coq au vin very disappointing -- small amount of chicken, sauce lacked taste and richness, and served on a bed of uninspiring noodles. NOTE: for Groupon deals, gratuity (an automatic 18%), sales tax and 4% SF Mandate, is based on regular prix-fixe price ($76 for two people), not on deal price. Your final bill will be much larger than you may expect! Also, in our case, we were overcharged $4 on the sales tax which unfortunately I only noticed after we were home. Their computation was entirely wrong and is likely built into their system so people are being overcharged on a regular basis.
author: Geoff L.

description: Disappointing. It was the most crowded restaurant on a Friday night at 10pm so we assumed it would be good. First off the waitress was really pushy and rushed us to order. I had the steak and my boyfriend had the casserole. The steak was pretty bad. The sauce was too thick and chunky and a weird flavor. French fries were also meh. My boyfriend enjoyed his casserole but it was pretty lame that it didn't come with any sides. The complimentary bread was good at least.
author: Jane H.

description:
I have been there for happy hour in the past so I was looking forward to having dinner there. 

I had the cream of mushroom, escargot, and salmon/ratatouille dish with champagne.  Nothing was memorable and generally lacked in flavor.  Don't think I'll be back.
author: Sumy K.

description:
Love this friendly place. Olivier is a great host. The team is nice. The food is good. 
Looove the outdoor space.
author: Carole G.

description: Wonderful customer service, excellent cuisine and the ambiance was sweet. Can't wait to go back!
author: Anna M.

description: Came for brunch on Saturday. Awesome, friendly service. Definitely not stingy with the bottomless mimosas. Never saw the bottom of my glass. The food was amazing. Very fresh ingredients. Awesome fruit and side salad. The salmon Benedict was excellent. The most melt in your mouth lox. Would come back! Also enjoyed the decor and the hidden feeling of the location.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Had dinner there recently, definitely will not be going back ... not worth it. Had the salad - tart and swimming in dressing, onion soup - ok, not great. Mushroom fettucini was underseasoned, and the boeuf bourguignon was unimpressive.
Desserts were okay, I'm guessing not made in house.
Finally, did not appreciate that they added the service charge to the bill rather than leaving it to my discretion.
There are other bistros in town that are better.
author: Patricia O.

description:
During the middle of the night, I checked my phone and saw that I was awarded ROTD for San Francisco. I must say, I was super excited and went back to bed excited for the many congratulatory compliments from Yelpers around the world.

Then I woke up.

It was a dream. When you begin dreaming about Yelping then you know you have problems. And given that it's been nearly two years since my last ROTD it's obviously been on mind.

I blame Cafe Bastille.

Last night was one of those rare warm San Francisco evenings, so we made plans to meet up with friends in the City hoping to take full advantage of the beautiful weather and dine al fresco. Belden Lane was on top of our list and upon arrival found plenty of open seating at Cafe Bastille. Our hostess seated us at a nice table close to the entrance. It was just after 7:00 and with the temperature still hovering around 72 degrees, we were very happy to score such a great table.

The service was good and our server was helpful with suggestions. My wife and I started by charing the frisee salad which we both loved. The crusted soft boiled egg with plenty of bacon bites made this dish very enjoyable.

I was torn for my entree and solicited our server for his thoughts, he suggested the Beouf Bourignion which is one of my all time favorite French dishes. I ordered a side of French fries, but our server was nice enough to point out that my wife's dish came with "unlimited" fries and that there would be plenty of fries for the both of us. Gotta give him props for that.

I am sad to report to my dish didn't really live up to my expectations. The beef was a little dry, the carrots were not cooked enough and the sauce not at all flavorful and lacked even a remote hint of red wine. I didn't hate it, but probably not something I would get again. But with this being said, there are plenty of other tasty options to be had here and would definitely come back and check those out. 

The French fries? They were a hit and the bernaise dipping sauce was perfect. 

We sat at our table for over 3 hours and never felt rushed. It was our table for the night just like you would find in France.
author: Rene C.

description: European atmosphere in the middle of the financial district. I love going to Belden Lane on a nice summer day for lunch and sitting outdoors.  Cafe Bastille makes a delicious tuna Niçoise salad. The fish was lightly seared on the outside and it was tender. Good quality fish was used. It's rare in the center. The fish was served in thick slices over a bed of spring salad mixed greens, with lightly blanched green beans and a couple of halved hard boiled eggs. The dressing was absolutely divine perfect and it tied all the ingredients together. My friend ordered fries to share. The fries were crispy and it came with a lemon-infused  mayonnaise sauce.  The service was very good too!
author: Lucy L.

description:
My first restaurant on Belden Place, I came her with a colleague of mine a couple of nights ago. Service was good but the food was just OK and not memorable IMHO.  I had the prix fixe menu and got the following items.
french onion soup -  have had better
beef bourguignon- ditto
chocolate creme brulee- definitely the best part of the meal

They have both indoor and outdoor seating which is always nice.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Came here for lunch during work. The inside brought me back to Europe and felt genuine. The servers spoke with a French accent adding to their authenticity. I was feelin their outdoor patio but it was raining monkeys and bananas so we did not sit outside. 

I tried their escargot. Boy oh boy....oh boy. Let see if I can accurately describe what I put on my palette. It was slimy, not in a terrible way like a tongue felt but not in a perfectly good way like you would think a worm tastes like. Slimy enough to know that you're feasting on a snail, but at the same time not slimy to know that you're not eating a snail. In all, it was a new experience that I'm glad experimented with. The steak taretare was very taretare. The disliked the kobe beef mainly cause I got beef with kobe. He a scrub and so are the lakers. 

For my my entree, I got he pork blood sausage because I watched vampire diaries the other night and it had me feeling some type of way. After eating it, I was feeling all types of not yummy way. Bad choice on my part.

The price was reasonable for FiDi. $15-25 so can't complain
author: Andrew C.

description: Great quality food, good portion, customer service was great and very accommodating, which we really appreciated for our family with a little girl traveling with us.
author: Cat Rox L.

description:
We came on a Groupon coupon for the fixed price menu.  I went to France last year so I was looking forward to good French food. After I read the reviews on this restaurant, it seemed that most people liked the beef bourguignon, so I ordered that.  To my disappointment, the beef was so dry and overcooked.  In fact the beef pieces were burnt on one side.  The French Onion soup was also a disappointment, not enough cheese.  If you want really good French Onion soup, go to Perry's or Liverpool Lil's.  Fortunately, the only good course was the cream brulee dessert.

Even with the Groupon coupon (which barely covered the price of the meal and wine), the price of the unsatisfactory meal was overpriced.  There are French restaurants in the City at comparable prices with a better atmosphere.  My favorite French restaurant is Jeanne D'Arc, which is not too far from this restaurant.

I will not return.
author: Chilly W.

description: Our server, Reno, was extremely attentive and accommodating. We sat on the outside patio at night with the heaters on because someone in our party brought their dog and Reno brought the dog a bowl of water- very thoughtful! The food was delicious - especially the mussels (both ways), French onion soup, and the roasted salmon with ratatouille- very unique flavors.  The only criticism- and this is not under their control- is that the neighboring restaurants were closing up and it was a bit noisy, then again you could view it as adding to the charm as it is very much like a cafe or restaurant with a patio that you would see in Europe. Definitely recommend checking this place out!
author: Katie B.

description:
My friends and I did a triple date here for Dine About Town. 

I ordered the Nicoise ( ahi tuna, green beans, fingerling potatoes, hardboiled egg) and Pate a la Normande (fettucini with mussels, shrimp, smoked salmon in a mushroom and garlic cream sauce). It was so fresh and yummy. Everything was cooked perfectly. For dessert, I ordered the chocolate crepe. It was yummy but I wish it had a little more than just chocolate sauce inside a crepe. Maybe ice cream, hehe. 

My BF ordered Kobe Beef Carpaccio and Steak with french fries. I tried the carpaccio and it was delicious! Perfect balance of sweet and sour and salty. The steak was ok. 

The service was friendly and helpful with the menu. 

I'd come back to try other items on the menu.
author: Jean T.

description:
Delicious, especially if your willing try the more regional dishes.

We stopped in for lunch on Saturday and started with the escargot and onion soup. Surprised to say they were just okay. Totally forgettable really... the escargot was covered with too much breading and the onion soup was bland.  Will skip these hors d'oeuvres next time and go with...

The Os a Meolle (bone marrow) and Quenelle de Lyon (fish dumplings) were great.  I'm not sure if bone marrow can be screwed up...so fatty and tasty.  However, the dumplings are more of a thick fish cake swimming in delicious Nantua Sauce... mmm...mmm...

Moules Frites are fantastic.  Took me back to Nice... I'll be back to two orders of this next time I miss Cote d'Azur cooking.  Lots of fresh tarragon in the dish gives the broth wonderful flavor.  Ask for bread to dip.

The Provencal Pulled Pork sandwich is great.  It's not the American style pulled pork, so if that's what you're thinking when ordering this sandwich, you'll be disappointed.  The pork was so good, we didn't even bother with the bread.

Service is fantastic and our server was great with our daughter.  I'm a fan of Cafe Bastille and now looking forward to trying the dinner menu.
author: Zoran L.

description:
Came here with a party of 12 for a birthday and had a great experience. The hostess/server was wonderufl and so accomodating. Me and the birthday boy came in early and she and 3 options of where we could sit our large party, really amazing. The food was wonderful and she split the checks about 9 ways without a pause. Will definitely return.

What we ordered:
House red: Good, standard. No complaints.
Appetizers(totally enough for our 12 people): CHARCUTERIE PLATE and FROMAGE PLATE (three cheese)
Main: BOEUF BOURGUIGNON (delicious and so flavorful) for me and the Filet Mignon for the birthday man (he loved it and I loved picking at his.)
Dessert: Creme Brulee (delicious, could have used a touch more vanilla but still great)

All around great experience!
author: Sonia M.

description:
I've been wanting to come back here and it's just as amazing today than it was long ago. Crepe mushroom & chicken and fish dumpling, even the bread, to die for. Andrew F is a sweetie.

Oh and the bottomless mimosa!
author: Tell It Like It Is ..

description:
Bone marrow is fatty as fuck, but if you're gonna go, go hard.

The texture was beyond amazing - again, my friends and I are a food loving bunch who affectionately refer to a perfectly done bone marrow dish as "meat butter". The serving size was generous here. I do prefer bone marrow on softer bread to sop up all the juices, but the toast slices it came with were pretty good too.

I would like to come back for dinner and try more food... and hopefully some wine!
author: Aivy C.

description:
Love my banker friend's $25 dinner stipends. Used it to get:

* POTATO GNOCCHI - 4 stars
(with mushroom, cream and truffle sauce, $17)
YUM, very strong truffle sauce, very creamy and rich and thick and soft. Loved it. The bread is fantastic as well, super crunchy and hard shell with a very soft filling. You can tell it's fresh.

* HARICOTS VERTS - 2.5 stars
(green beans with garlic and parsley butter, $4)
Meh, only got this to stay under the $25 limit. Overly oily, not much flavor, very bland.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I made plans to meet up with my aunt for lunch near Montgomery & she had a few places in mind.  She took me through to the alley way of Belden & after reviewing the menu at Cafe Bastille we decided to dine here.  First impressions: Tre Francois!  Cute little restaurant, with I'm guessing what is another dining area downstairs for bigger parties.  I liked the outdoor seating (though it was too cold to sit outside).  The tables are really close together inside though, a little too close for the American lifestyle!  

I ordered the Croque Madame since I've always wanted to try this French sammie staple, and she ordered one of the daily specials, a sun dried tomato & mushroom quiche with frites.  Both of entrees came with a side of salad.  And of course we munched on a baguette with butter.  The salad needed more dressing, it was very faint tasting, but maybe that's Euro style?  My Croque Madame was yummy but a little rich for me.  Loved how the yolk ran when I pierced it.  Portion sizes were just right.  We both loved her quiche though, it was very tasty, I think I found a love of sundried tomatoes after trying it.  The frites could have been a little crispier though.  

Friendly service & real Frenchies working here (at least a couple of them were).  The food wasn't OMG great but not bad either.  Would maybe come back when they have their Coq Au Vin daily special since this is like my favorite French dish!
author: Cat C.

description: I like coming here with business partners. Friendly staff, usually no wait, reasonably priced, and located in a nice little alley.
author: Jibé C.

description: Very Excellent beef stew(my fave), rabbit, escargot, wonderful warm and fresh baguette. Used groupon and had a great deal! Classic French bistro with the atmosphere to go with it. Get a glass of rosé to enjoy with the meal. Staff was efficient and attentive enough without smothering . Would definitely return to this cute quaint cafe, a hidden gem!
author: Lilian L.

description:
A charming French restaurant in the Belden Place alley tucked away in the Financial District. Cafe Bastille, like most of the restaurants here, has a cute space for outdoor dining (a must!). 

Interestingly enough, while French restaurants are reputed to serve tiny portions, Cafe Bastille's portions were anything but. I ordered the chicken tagine, which had an amazing spiced aroma. Two large chicken pieces were served atop moist couscous with incredibly rich flavor. Overall a healthier option on the menu, the portion was large enough for two meals. We also tried the cognac creme brulee. While tasty, the cognac flavor in the otherwise vanilla-flavored dessert was not very apparent. Great food overall though, and a wonderful dining experience in what seemed like a world removed from SF.

P.S. Park in the St. Mary's Square parking garage that is barely 1/2 block away. After 6pm, it's only $1/hour.
author: Mansi A.

description:
I do love me some Cafe Bastille! Ive been going for years. 

Pros:
-Atmosphere: authentic. love the antique signs on the walls. Love the outside seating. Inside feels warm and cozy and intimate.
-Pommes Frites: yum! Delicious side aioli.
-Mussels are fantastic
-Os À Moelle was superb! Hard to find. 
-Owner was extremely hospitable. Checked on us a few times and made us feel very well taken care of. 
-My favorite part: As the end of the end of the evening died down, the entire restaurant staff gathered at the bar for a quick shot/cocktail. Made me feel like I was back in college in Europe. Where life stops for little things, like a drink. Service may slow down,but you are expected to understand. 

Cons:

-They got rid of the Coq Au Vin! Bummer.
- Boeuf Bourguignon was overcooked, cold and dry.
-Bread could  be yummier!
author: Lana S.

description: I'm French. I have been living in NY for the past 2 years. This is the first time I eat in a restaurant that actually tastes like home. (I had the boudin noir)
author: Flo R.

description:
A fabulous downtown dinner spot! 

We started with the bone marrow and carpaccio appetizers, both of which were excellent. I had the Steak Frites as my main course, and I'm not sure it could have been better - the steak was perfectly done and the fries were nice and crispy. My boyfriend had the Beef Bourguignon, which he raved about. They have an extensive and varied wine list, and we ordered a bottle that we enjoyed. 

It felt like a little piece of Paris in San Francisco! I'd go back again in a heartbeat.
author: Molly P.

description: Delicious!!! A quaint romantic bistro! French onion soupe au gratinee was liquid gold! I had the moules marinieres (mussels) which were perfect! My boyfriend had the rabbit LAPIN À LA MOUTARDE braised rabbit, pancetta, potatoes, baby carrots, whole grain mustard, rabbit jus. First taste of rabbit the sauce was a perfect juxtaposition to the rabbit.
author: Megan R B.

description:
Had my first French food experience here. We were seated outside and the weather was lovely! The restaurant was a little hard to find, hidden between the narrow streets of the financial district, but I loved the setting. It felt very private, so much so that I almost forgot  we were in such a busy city. 

I had the pate a la normande, a pasta made with fresh mussels, shrimp, salmon, and mushrooms. The portion size was very large so I'm glad I split it with a friend! Definitely would recommend this dish to all the seafood lovers out there!
author: Kim Z.

description:
I was actually surprised how good the food is here! I had no expectation and just walked by. Wow totally surprised! Very good food! 
Coming back for sure!
author: Lizy W.

description:
What's not to like?! An absolutely adorable little place with lovely ambience, great food, and friendly service.

We started off with the Os a Moelle, a wonderfully prepared bone marrow served with crostini. Just divine. Our entrees soon followed -- Sole in a lemon butter sauce, and Chicken Tajine. Both were beautifully presented and tasted wonderful. And how can I forget the warm sourdough bread? Piping hot, nice and crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. Heaven!
author: Liz I.

description:
Great food!
I went there for lunch with a friend on a Saturday. 
Everything on the menu looked really good, it was hard to chose.
She had onion soup and crepe, the onion soup was very good (I tried!) and said that the crepe was really good also.
I had the lamb sausage with white beans. It was delicious! Very well cooked and well displayed on the the plate.
The place has a good atmosphere and I'll definitely go back there!
:)
author: Victoria C.

description: I made reservations at this restaurant on Valentine's Day at 10 o'clock because I didn't get off work until 9:30pm. They had reservations online until 11pm so I assumed a reservation at 10pm, an hour before the last available reservation, would be fine. When I arrived there were still a few tables eating dinner, but I wasn't greeted as I walked through the restaurant. I had to walk to the back to find someone to ask about my reservation. The waiter I first spoke to was very kind and explained to me that their special valentine's day menu was about 80% sold out so they only had a few options left. This didn't phase me at all and I understood it was late and they were running out of supplies. As one can expect at 10pm on Valentine's day in SF. But as I was speaking to the waiter, who profusely apologized they did not have the whole menu, the other staff mentioned multiple times to me that I was "the last table of the night." As if to remind me of how much of a nuisance I am for making them stay later to serve me even though they had reservations open until 11. The whole staff stood around and listened to our conversation to see if they would have to stay and serve me or if they could peel out early because I changed my mind. The male waiter gave me a menu and put stars next to the remaining food options which was very helpful. I explained to him I was going to step outside and ask my party if they were still interested in eating there with the limited menu, as some of the party was vegetarian and the altered menu left little options for this. As I was on the phone, with the menu of the available options in my hand, a second female waitress walked out and interrupted my phone call to remind me that 80% of the menu was gone even though she had witnessed the first waiter explain this inside. I said "yes I understand I'm speaking with my group to see if they're still interested in eating here." And then she preceded to interrupt me to ask "are your friends going to show up?" She was clearly hoping to sway me from eating there so she could take the rest of the night off and go home by interrupting me. She insisted on reminding me about the menu and pestering me about whether "my friends" were going to show up. This whole traumatic experience caused me to leave promptly and go to the restaurant Sauce a few doors down which was open until 1am and had amazing service. Long story short, the staff bullied me into not following through with my reservation so they could all take the night off. A suggestion, don't provide reservations late into the night if you don't want to stay open past a certain point. It puts your costumers in VERY uncomfortable situations and makes your staff look AWFUL.
author: Karol S.

description:
We celebrated my friends birthday dinner here. It was a nice cozy table that we had.   After reviewing the menu, majority of us chose the pre-fix menu. It came with unlimited chardonnay or shiraz wine.

My first was the salad. It was a refreshing start. We also started with the pate sampler and steak tartare.  The steak tartare needed more flavor to liven the dish. The pate sampler was duck rillettes, country pate, and chicken liver pate. My favorite was the duck rillette and liver pate.   

My entree was the boeuf bourguignon.  It was a very savory dish.   From eating the starters and the salad I was full. But I still progressed eating all the beef and vegetables.   Leading myself to the dessert course. Thats when my second wind came and I devoured the triple chocolate mousse.The mousse completed the sweetness I needed after dinner.

Overall a nice experience.
author: Marck N.

description: It is located in the International Food Court.  Is located in a small street nearby Kearney street near China Town.  Belden Street is a small street in the alley (got to park your car to be able to access Belden Street).  Great environment, excellent customer services, nice warm fluffy French bread, but the main dishes and dessert were OK.  The French soup was good.
author: Kim N.

description:
Ok prices, average food. Came here on a Friday night. 

Butternut squash soup- Ok, creamy, but tasted more cream than the actual squash.
Duck coq au vin- Ehhh.... would not order again. This dish had way too many beans. 

Nice hidden location in downtown, but not worth the price or calories.
author: Carrie Y.

description:
Food was mediocre and service the worst.   

We ordered the tagine which is supposed to be this amazing dish full of flavor ... I have no idea who concocted this dish but it was the worst tagine I've ever had.  We ordered the hachis parmentier it was edible but flavorless. The French Onion was okay but inconsistent in the preparation. One soup cooked well done and the other tepid in temp with unmelted cheese.  The merguez we had was good.  

By the way, the surrounding couples were also complaining about service, messing up the bill, etc. So many amazing restaurants in this town ... It's too bad.
author: Roni R.

description: We don't appreciate being billed a service charge of 18% - which we believe is a result of using Groupon. We ended up paying $25 more in addition to the $42 for $70 prix fixe Groupon. It wasn't really a good deal for us and we won't be going back. The desserts were good and the onion soup okay, but my friend and I were really disappointed at the mussels, the meat of which had shrunk and become really small for a lack of nutrients due to unfreshness. Although portion sizes were generous, a few of the mussels were unopened so they're inedible. The only thing that was good was the dessert and the service.
author: Molly J.

description:
Mussels - great. Some of the appetizers were great. The beef stew was mediocre to bad and they found a way to stretch the meal to 3 hours. 

They did a good job accommodating my son's dairy allergy, which is good.

Basically, don't go there unless you have no time limit, but it's pretty good if you avoid the beef stew.
author: Duke N.

description:
This place is my go-to for date night when we are so sick of what's available in our neighborhood. The food has always been excellent, as well as the service. The ambience is perfect. I've never dined inside, I always choose to sit outside under the twinkling lights & heaters. Last night, I chose the special, which is what I usually do, & am never disappointed. I had the filet mignon, & we shared the salmon appetizer. The complimentary crusty baguette is perfection!  

See you soon, Cafe Bastille!
author: Priscilla M.

description:
We met up with some friends for brunch on Sunday. I made the reservation that morning so our options were pretty limited, and thus we ended up at Cafe Bastille. 

We arrived around 11:30am and definitely did not need a reservation, there were just 2 other tables filled. They have an outdoor area as well, but no heat lamps :-(

We had to wait a while for the other couple but no one in the restaurant seemed to mind. We ordered a mimosa and coffee to get started and sat sipping happily watching the volleyball on TV.

I did notice that although the paper on our table had clearly been replaced before us, the tablecloth itself had bits of stuck on food which was gross. 

I ordered the prosciutto and cheese sandwich. Maybe I was just spoiled by the prosciutto sandwich I had on Friday, but this one did not compare at all. 

Service was very attentive throughout and the atmosphere is cute - very French.

A note on parking: The sutter/stockton garage is very reasonable on Sundays ($3/hr) and only 2-3 blocks away.
author: Rachel E.

description:
A little taste of Paris in a San Francisco alley!  This quaint restaurant is on a charming alley packed with other international-themed restaurants.  The whole experience is reminiscent of a row of Parisian cafes.  There is indoor and outdoor seating.  Our group of 10 was seated in the downstairs area, which is perfect for larger parties.  They had just updated their menu, including the signature cocktails.  We tried three of the four cocktails, and all were well-received.  

I can honestly say the French onion soup is the best I've ever tasted.  The broth was rich, and the onions were tender.  As a main course I had the beef bourgogne.  The beef was tender, the sauce superb, and the vegetables and potatoes were not overdone.  For dessert, a creme brulee of course, accompanied by a snifter of Armagnac.  The brulee was thick, and the creme perfection.  

I would recommend this restaurant to any who loves French cuisine, as well as those merely curious.  I can't remember having finer Franco fare, even in Paris itself.
author: Joshua B.

description: My Family and I were here over the Labor Day weekend. First off. We loved the cute alley that restaurant was located on.  The food here is amazing. I convinced my girlfriend and daughters to try the Escargot witch we all loved! My girlfriend and I had the Beef Bourguignon. Can I say Amazing!! Even my daughters kept dipping their bread in the sauce lol!  They had no kids menu but the owner was very accommodating and made them garlic pasta with checkin. Our waitress was very nice!!  Cafe Bastille was the Bomb.com!
author: Lawrence R.

description: The staff is wonderful, everyone from the hostess to the buss boy. They are friendly and constantly make sure that you have everything you need (but not too much where you're annoyed). The food is the best I've ever had. The steamed moussles are the best. And they have a wonderful 3 course meal option for $35. I highly recommend this place. And we plan to make many more trips to San Francisco because of this place.
author: Chrissy M.

description:
Food was dissappointing.  Overall taste was bland and lacked creativity.  Two stars for offering outdoor seating and friendly servers.


French onion soup:  bread not toasty, cheese not melty and no flavor.  Soup itself was like canned beef consommé. 

Cassoulet: the duck confit didn't have the rich cured flavor I'd like in confit.   Instead, it was like over baked duck. The white beans was bland and pasty. 

Beef stew: no surprises, faint taste of red wine in the sauce.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
I had a wonderful dinner here with friends. For a Thursday night, I was surprised how quiet Belden was, so we ended up getting a nice table outside under the heat lamp and great service from our waiter. They were doing Dine About Town, but we decided to order ala carte instead since the DAT menu was limited. 

The three of us shared the bone marrow gratine, the ratatouille, the ahi tuna salad, the duck casoulet, and the normande mussels with all-you-can-eat fries. This was my first time having bone marrow; I was pretty excited! The cut the bone into three pieces for us. One friend got the piece with the most marrow. The other two pieces had less marrow and was mostly breadcrumbs which overpowered the subtle taste of the marrow. The flavor was still good and went well with the complimentary hot bread. This was also my first time having salad nicoise; the seared ahi tuna was fresh and delicious! 

Our server was great and staggered our courses so we had time to finish each course before the next one arrived. The duck and mussels arrived piping hot, just the way I like my food! I normally would order the white wine mussels, but my friend wanted the cream one so we got that. The cream broth was so good that we got spoons to drink the soup :) With Plouf next door, I was surprised that their mussels were deliciously plump and fresh (I later read that Bastille and Plouf are owned by the same people). They also weren't kidding about the all-you-can-eat fries, we were getting full but got another half order since the fries were so good.

The only dish that I didn't really care for was the duck confit cassoulet. I confused cassoulet with casolette (having tried a tasty baked fromage bacon cassolette in Paris recently), so I was surprised that the cassoulet was a white bean dish. The beans were flavorless while the duck was salty (usually the case with duck confit that I've tried). I ended up eating the duck with the ratatouille, which tasted better than the beans.

For dessert, our server recommended the ile flotante (floating island) or the creme brulee. I was actually looking at the new key lime mousse, but went with his first choice of the ile flotante since I've never have meringue. My friend, who said she was too full to have another bite, ended up loving the dessert. It was ok to me since I'm not a fan of the candied almond foam, but I enjoyed the soup. 

All in all, Cafe Bastille was a wonderful French dining experience, and I look forward to returning, esp. to try the beef bourguignon. I'm not sure if their website is up to date, but it shows a 3-course prix fixe for $30 which is cheaper than Dine about Town and with more options.
author: Diana B.

description:
Eating outside on the covered patio, squeezed next to other diners, Cafe Bastille offers a wonderful diversion from the hubbub of the city.  Unfortunately, the quaint atmosphere here doesn't make up for the bland food.

FRENCH ONION SOUP: Without a solid foundation, a soup fails.  The bread was fine and there was a ton of Gruyere, but the broth was almost flavorless.  Fail.  

MOULES FRITES: The mussels were pretty good and the broth was fine (could've used a bit more acid and garlic), but the fries tasted like the kind you'd get from a cheap, late night burger place.  

SERVICE: The busboy came by an awful lot more than the waitress.  The sound of French being spoken didn't make up for the indifferent service.
author: Chris C.

description: We came here with a Groupon for prefix dinner for two - the food was OK, there is a lot better French food in the city better than here. We had the onion soup,the beef stew, mushroom fettuccine and desserts. The bill total was another $40 on top of groupon-- they charge a 18% gratitude plus sales tax and mandate SF health fee. So, 18% gratitude is based on $76 value -not based on Groupon price-- making the dinner close to $90 for two - very pricey for mediocre French food. Service was OK, not very friendly.
author: Julie T.

description: One memorable afternoon with delicious Hors d'Oeuvres and bottomless mimosa. Highly recommend the carpaccio and steamed mussels. Friendly staff.
author: Tom P.

description:
I had a fantastic experience at Cafe Bastille yesterday. It's one of the restaurants that we take interview candidates to for lunch, and I'm looking forward to my next visit.

I started off with the soup of the day - cauliflower soup, completely vegetarian, with a nice creamy texture and really good flavor. I finished it pretty quickly, and almost wanted to order another.

For the entree, I was first going to get the 'grilled portabello and peppers'. But I asked the waiter what the best vegetarian dish was, and he said that quite honestly, he thought the ratatoille crepe was the best one. So I decided to trust him and go with that, and I'm so happy I did. The crepe was excellent - perfect texture, a nice side salad, and it left me wanting more. I finished off the meal by splitting a chocolate nutella crepe, for an overall great experience. I need to call them and figure out the next time the soup of the day is cauliflower, because when it is I'm coming back.
author: Amaresh S.

description:
This is so unprofessional and just plain rude:

eric k. messaged me on 12/20/11 with the following:

Yes and yes we did fuck up no excuses
The waiter did get fired for the bad service
The cook did get kill for the bad food
And your card did not get charge because we are not worthy
I still hope that you will have a great and happy holiday s
Tell you friend as well to accept your apologys for your bad
Lunch if you ever want to talk my name is Olivier my cell
415 713 0736 or oliviercafebastille@yahoo.com


-------------
Fortunately the server messaged me on 12/21/11 with the following:

Message from Anatoliy A.

    This message is from the person responsible for your unpleasant experience at Cafe Bastille on December 19th at lunch time.
    I am truly sorry for what had happened. However, I hope while I have caused this distasteful incident, I am able to see where I went wrong.
    Optimistically, acquiring this insight would allow me to learn and grow and prevent similar issues in the future.

Sincerely Yours
your waiter @ Cafe Bastille
author: Fannie S.

description:
Great food - have been very happy all three times I visited.  Though I don't eat beef, my friends are in love with the beef carpaccio. I loved the pate sampler - a must get if you like pate.

In terms of the main course, I have had the rabbit and the the truite, and really liked both of them.  I think I'm a bit more partial to the truite, though.  

Service is very nice as well - can't go wrong with Cafe Bastille!
author: Sandeep K.

description:
Received the Groupon voucher ($40 for $75) and came here randomly (no reservation) on a Friday night. The place was half packed and reminded me of old school Paris. Great ambience and decorations of older French signs, I loved it. The groupon had the prefixe option:

The servers were very nice and recommended the french onion soup (very good, but lotsa cheese).

For entrees we ordered bacon, mushroom mussels = very good, tons of delicious cream, TONS of mussels, you won't go hungry. Big fan, but so filling.

The 2nd entree we ordered the duck confit. It was a smaller piece of duck leg, but it was cooked perfectly. Crispy on the outside, nice and soft on the inside. The white bean stew it came in was awesome as well. The various types of suasage bites inside were a miss though, all were soggy and lacked flavor, still a very good dish.

For dessert we got both the rasberry cheesecake and the chocolate brownie cake. I was  stuffed, but I hear they were very good.

Also ordered two glasses of red wine $~10, which were average. Neither hit the spot. Without the groupon factored in, paid an extra $60 after tip and tax. 

A great filling meal, I'd recommend it. It's not Paris, but it'll do justice for SF.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Located in Belden Place, Café Bastille offered the perfect escape for a catch up dinner with a friend.  There's outdoor seating, and two levels of indoor seating. And reservations weren't need for a Monday night at 6 PM. 

Food and service were wonderful.  The two of us shared a bottle of wine and we both ordered the boeuf bourguignon - it came in a big bowl, tender meat, carrots, onions, potatoes, and lots of delicious broth.  It was comfort food.  And I used the sliced baguettes that our waiter brought over to soak up the leftover broth afterwards.  Delicious.  Also, our server was really sweet - made conversation a handful of times and then left us to happily chat the next few hours away.
author: Kimya P.

description:
I was hesitant to try French cuisine (not a big fan) but since on vacation in SF and a groupon deal, I figured why not. 

The place was nicely tucked in a small dark alley with dim lights that makes you feel you're in NY. A 6 to 7 table restaurant, it's a nice small kick back with French art all over the walls. 

I ordered the onion soup, chicken tagine, and raspberry key lime mousse. Like most fancy pants places, we were served complimentary sliced baguettes and warm butter.

Onion soup- Sweet flavored soup stuffed with sliced baguette and topped with toasted cheese. It was alright. Nothing great

Chicken Tagine: slow cooked chicken drumsticks resting on tomatoes and couscous. Don't get me wrong, I love chicken, but this dish didn't do the trick. My date ended up to-going her barely touched Chicken tagine and gave it to a homeless lady. 

Raspberry Key Lime Mousse: A 1 by 2 inch piece of mousse cake thing. Best thing of the night. 

Kinda was hoping for some super awesome French food but I didn't get oui oui'd, I just stuffed myself with bread and butter. 

Service was good. My glass was always filled and my butta and breads kept coming! Oh and for the cherry on top, an 18% gratuity was slapped I'm my faaaaaace for two guests.
author: Paul L.

description: Cocktails and creme brûlée were great. Lunch entrees were disappointing. Husband had chicken cordon bleu which he said was very dry and not very cheesy.  I ordered the shepherd's pie (can't recall French name) which was just ok - definitely would NOT recommend either. Nice ambiance and friendly staff.
author: Dianne M.

description: I really enjoyed lunch here with my friend. We were surprised with that amount of ridiculous 1-star reviews about "bland" and "flavourless" food. It was very good, even the famous for blandness onion soup, which I found much better than many I had in Paris.
author: Sophia S.

description: Food was bland no seasoning nothing to spectacular or interesting service was blahh don't see myself coming back here ever in life
author: Adrian C.

description: This place makes me feel like Owen Wilson in Midnight in Paris! The food is perfect. The service is outstanding. They even split the check 28 ways!!!
author: Chad C.

description:
I impulsively bought a coupon for the prix fixe dinner for 2 and that's what brought us here.  The location is cool with plenty of outdoor seating.  It was cold when we arrived for dinner, though, so we opted to sit inside.  There was a crowd at the bar, so it was very loud.  It would've been nice to talk over dinner, but we could barely hear each other.

The best thing about Cafe Bastille was the baguette--toasty warm, crunchy, chewy and totally reminded me of France.  We had to try really hard not to fill up on it.  Here are my thoughts on the dishes we had:

Mesclun Salad - Pretty standard, nothing special; actually tasted pretty bland to me.

French onion soup - Only dish I really enjoyed besides the bread; the broth was very sweet from the onions and seasoned just right.  My major issue was in addition to the toasty, cheesy bread on top, there were also pieces of soggy bread underneath.  Seemed like a ploy to give you less soup to me.

Boeuf Bourguignon - Beef was tender; potatoes, mushrooms and pearl onions cooked just right; carrots were on the crunchy side though and the whole thing was pretty bland.

Cassoulet - Had a couple bites of this; sausage tasted good, duck was okay; overall, lacked flavor.

Dessert - Looked like stuff I can get at a mediocre bakery in China Town.

With an order of the 1/2 Carafe Red, we paid a total of $85.  Given the food and service, $85 was a bit much.  If we paid the full price of $115 (without the coupon), I would've been annoyed.  Service was subpar.  The waitresses were inattentive and not very friendly.  The busboys were good, though.  

Overall, myeh.  I will not be coming back.
author: Thi D.

description: We had a Groupon for the fixed dinner the baby lettuce salad was good the onion soup was ok, but the main courses beef stew and chicken stew were bland, not flavorful. I would not recommend this restaurant
author: Peter M.

description:
It was an unexpected thing to have a fine dining experience on a random Tuesday afternoon. Cafe Bastille has outdoor seating in an alley. Its a special urban experience to dine al fresca in the shadows of the Financial District. There were several other restaurants also tucked in on Belden. 
The service was slightly slow. The pace felt "European" which was fine with us during an early weekday supper with the exception of having to wait for a second glass of wine. We had a Cabernet Sauvignon from Napa by the glass which was good but not exceptional. There were several pages of bottled wines and I can guess there were much better wines there than on the by the glass menu. 
I ordered the Risotto. I don't see it on the online menu and will try to recall what was in it. First, it tasted fantastic with clean flavors that blended very nicely. Crab and asparagus were there. The risotto itself was green, likely from fresh herbs. I feel completely inadequate in describing this dish but it was wonderfully creamy, fresh and balanced. With protein and veggies in it, it was a complete meal. 
My companion ordered the baked chicken which came with mashed potatoes, gravy and asparagus. (I also don't see this on the online menu.) He said it was tasty and just the right proportion of carbs and protein.
We split the tiramisu which was nicely sized, very moist and delicious. It would have been even better with a cappuccino but I'm off coffee currently.
There are other things on the menu I want to try and will plan to be back, especially for a celebratory dinner. There are fish offerings and rabbit in mustard sauce that I must try.
author: Deanna C.

description:
After having a drink at Irish Bank, we made the quick walk over to Cafe Bastille.

With the tourist season ramping down, I would say that less than half of their seats were taken.  Inside, it was almost empty.  We had a reservation but would not have needed one.  The same seemed to be true for the other restaurants in Belden Place.

We were quickly greeted.  My friend wanted to sit inside.  This was very ok for me.  It was not a particularly warm evening.  We pretty much had our pick of seats.

I actually liked the ambiance.  I thought it was very comfortable.  It was relatively casual but still had nice touches to the decor.  

I would also its location in the Belden Place.  This is quaint European inspired alley with a number of restaurants and tons of outdoor seating.  At the top of the summer season, it is a very lively place.

Soon after our seating, the server came over to take our beverage order.  We were not quite ready so he quickly went and brought waters.

The server was patient.  We were not super focused on getting ready to order.  He was also very helpful with questions about the menu.

I selected a wine.  He brought our wine and some very nice warm french style bread.

We decided that we would start with some mussels and fries.  She selected these:

MARINIÈRE
white wine, shallots, parsley

I thought the mussels in wine sauce were actually quite good.  They were relatively small mussels but there were lots of them.  There were only a couple that had not opened.  We pretty much cleaned out the pot.  The fries were only ok.  I also thought they were relatively short which made them more difficult to handle.

http://tinyurl.com/3lkc92k

I also selected a platter of sliced meat to share.

CHARCUTERIE SAMPLER
prosciutto, coppa, sopressata, chorizo, and ham

The sliced meats were very good.  The ham was a little too simple in flavor profile to hold up against the other meats.  But we thoroughly enjoyed the plate and ate almost all of the slices.

http://tinyurl.com/4ykl95r

For an entree, she selected:

GRILLED LAMB CHOP
roasted fennel and french garlic green beans

I did not really enjoy the flavor of her lamb chop.  She seemed to though.  She ate most of and had the remainder packed up to take home.

http://tinyurl.com/3mykpgw

For an entree, I selected:

STEAK AU POIVRE
three peppercorn and cognac sauce

The flavor was very good and it was cooked properly..  I substituted mashed potatoes.  It usually comes with fries but we had already had fries with the mussels. My only complaint was that the steak was not very hot when it was brought out.  It was basically just a notch over room temperature.  I enjoyed it though.  The steak, pepper sauce, and mashed potatoes came together well.  I was a good boy and cleaned my plate.

http://tinyurl.com/3j77rbd

The service was friendly and helpful.  About 3/4's through the meal, we had a change in servers but she was as attentive as our original server.

Overall, I labored between 3 stars and 4 stars.  It simply is better than a number of places I've given 3 stars to but does not hold up to some places I've awarded with 4 stars.   The food is good but not exceptional.  The ambiance is comfortable.  The service was very good.  I think it is definitely worth a try.
author: Mark D.

description:
It's one of those meals where you feel like you wasted your calories. =(

We had a coupon deal for two. Had the pate platter, onion soup, salad, mussels with all you can eat fries, beef stew, and the fettuccine with seafood.

The pate platter was ok. 
Onion soup was actually pretty good. It wasn't too salty and the bread in it was toasted.
Salad was nothing to rave about.
The mussels were good, but it was really really rich. Too rich for my taste. Just like the fettuccine. Too too rich. I felt like I gained 5lbs while eating it. And I don't even watch my diet!
The beef stew was ok. Again, nothing to rave about. Except the beef was really tender.
The fries are quite the disappointment. My friend said "It's all you can eat cuz they know you won't want more." 

Oh and dessert was not worth mentioning either. and I love almost all desserts. =(
author: Mai H.

description:
Great spot for a business lunch in the FiDi.  Service is very personal and attentive, food is presented well (and very tasty), and lunch entree prices are reasonable (croque, quiche, sandwiches, etc. in the $13-16 range).  Very fun atmosphere outside in the alley (and heat lamps that make the patio possible year-round).

Will definitely return for future business meetings in the neighborhood.
author: Tonya B.

description: Dined here using a Groupon. I was worried due to the mixed reviews by other Groupers(?) Anyway, they must've gone on a bad day. Our experience was absolutely amazing! Our server was by far the cherry on top. He was friendly, patient, helpful & just a pleasure. He answered every question I had, romancing every dish, even bringing me a taste of the wine I was asking about! The food was so rich in flavor, from the French Onion soup to the Casoulette and especially the chocolate creme brûlée mousse magic in my mouth dessert! The cafe is located in an alley which was different and nice, out of the way & more intimate without being a fancy dress party kinda deal. I highly recommend the groupon, as the prices are on the steep side. But if you've got money to blow that works too, it's definitely worth it if you could have the same experience my cousin and I had.
author: Jess V.

description:
I really enjoyed my lunch at Cafe Bastille. I had the quiche, my mom had the prawns, and my dad had the salmon. My favorite was the salmon - cooked well and topped off with olive tapenade and ratatouille. The slightly sour taste of the sauce balanced the fish flavor. My only (minor) complaint is that the location is a bit off-putting, especially on a gray and rainy day. But do not let the alleyway scare you off! Cafe Bastille is a charming restaurant with a solid menu. All of our dishes were hearty and flavorful without being overwhelming. For dessert, we shared the cognac creme brulee. It was a bit too sweet, but the texture was light and creamy. 

I have heard wonderful things about their brunch, so I will be back as soon as possible!
author: Anna N.

description:
I like this location because it is in a street only for pedestrians, no car, no noise, feels a bit like in Europe.

The food is good, you can find a lot of classic, however that is a bit expensive that is why I have only 4 stars. Waiters are nice, service is fast.
author: Sylvain K.

description: This is a nice place to go.  The menu is a little Americanized but not too much.  Nice cafe setting to eat, great coffee and the place can really get crowded.  Many places to try on Belden Place but the prices here are reasonable.  Dinner for two with drinks, wine, appetizer, etc... for $140.
author: Harrison P.

description:
First, I must comment on Belden Place.. If not for the occasional homeless person walking by and seeing the Bank of America Building between the awnings, it was almost like this alley was located in a city such as Brussels or Paris. What an incredible ambiance.

The most impressive detail was the service at Bastille. I think the servers really were native French speakers who added to the mini-vacation for my lunch. The service was extraordinary, even at the height of lunch rush as my water glass was topped off after each gulp. I regret not remembering our server, but he was extremely knowledgeable about each item on the menu. Each course was wonderful with a nice tasting and saucy escargot that forced me to dip my bread in the sauce upon completion of the dish. The nice light dressing in the salad and the tart and light sweetness of my creme brulee were perfect. The beef gratin casserole was ok, but I guess I have a preference of a more sharp flavor in the cheeses combined with more savory aftertastes of the creamy sauces in my casserole which somewhat lacked in my main course. 

As my client was thrilled with the experience as a whole, I am left with the desire to return to this morsel of fun in terms of Belden Place and of Cafe Bastille. At the risk of the area becoming very touristy, I will recommend this area of the City to delight and entertain those I break bread with.
author: Mark M.

description:
My cousin had her 25th birthday dinner here - she picked the restaurant based on the closeness of the bar she wanted to go to after. (Hence, the food at dinner was only mediocre.)
The caprihinas were good - I recommend the passion fruit over the raspberry one. The food portions were decently sized, plus the unlimited bread makes it very filling. I ordered the lamb chops because I figured you can't go wrong with that. I asked for medium and my meat came out bloody - it looked bloodier than the medium rare steak my friend ordered. According to him, it looked like we literally went and took a chunk of flesh off the lamb. Sorry for the gross image. Glad we brought 2 of our own cakes for dessert, best part of the meal.
author: Christine C.

description: Great lunch today and great service. Sat outside, it's dog friendly, and enjoyed a leisurely Saturday lunch. We shared two appetizers; the Kobe beef carpaccio and the pate trio. Though the pate was a bit pricey they were REALLY great! Husband had the mushroom and spinach crepe which was also great. I had the Caesar which was so-so. Add one glass of wine for $11 and an iced tea and the bill was $85 without tip. Pricey for the size of the dishes but good
author: Ottis M.

description:
Another great Belden find!

My boss & I did lunch here on a sunny SF afternoon. I suggest ordering a carafe of wine. Lunch is always better with alcohol. Go early and try to snag a seat outside.

I recommend their Salad Niçoise & mussels mariniere, classic French dishes done right. They also have other typical French dishes but I haven't tried any of them. 

In French style, it won't be a quick lunch but it's ok to indulge once in a while!
author: Sara P.

description:
French restaurant tucked away in a small street that resembles a back alley without the filth nor stench. I ordered the rabbit entree - the meat was very very lean but so well cooked that it wasn't dry at all. The meat sat on a bed of rice which added richness to the whole dish. 

My other party recommended that we try the mussels steamed in white wine which also comes with unlimited fries. He commented that the fries were superb - we couldn't since we were so stuffed with bread from tea. Definitely will order the next time I go back.
author: Eric K.

description: Had a pretty good meal here. We went on a Saturday night and it was a bit too windy to sit on the patio. Their tent was nearly blowing over. We started out on the patio but moved inside, since it was early and it was kind of dead out there (except for the wind).
author: Zachary C.

description:
The BF took me here for my birthday recently and the food was great, ambiance was great, and service was pretty good.  We each got the 3 course pre-fix meal for $30 and a bottle of wine to wash up the good food.  We ate outside right near the heaters and it felt like i was in Europe again.  

I had the liver salad, chicken coq au vin, and passion fruit mousse.  He had the french onion soup, rabbit in some creamy sauce and passion fruit mousse as well.  The liver salad was great.  It was sauteed nicely and didn't taste gamey at all.  For an appetizer, the portion was big.  The French Onion was delicious - pieces of bread inside, tasty soup, plenty of onions and topped with a thick crust of cheese.  Yummmm!  Our main course was delish too - there was so much chicken, I couldn't finish it all.   The rabbit with the creamy sauce was really good too.  Dessert was a fail though - I was looking forward to mousse like pudding but it was more like a cake with a thin layer of mousse on top.  The passion fruit & mango did not go well together though.  I love sweets but I had only a few bites of this one.  

Overall, great place to eat.  Its in Belden Lane near downtown and there are other great places to eat nearby as well.  Good date spot!
author: Ha T.

description:
Nice idea with unlimited wine BUT the meal was not delicious, just OK.
I took soup à l'oignon and tartare and mousse aux 3 chocolats. 
Disappointed ! It was the smallest tartare I ever seen !! And I am french, really I ate maybe 500 or more tartars in my all life.... And too much sauce. It's raw BEEF with sauce not SAUCE with raw beef.
I told them that it was the smallest tartar I ever seen, they looked embarrassing, yes of course, shame on them, because they know that is not fair for the price of the meal. moreover in France fries are homemade. Not homemade ? Not French fries.
So it's expensive and quality and quantity are not here.
Soupe a l'oignon and mousse aux 3 chocolats was so so, not bad, not good.
Never come back again.

I saw a lot of good reviews, definitively they don't know what is french food...
author: Cécile D.

description:
My boyfriend wanted to surprise me and took us here.  We decided to take a cab to get to here from our hotel which was a good call since it's located in a tiny ally.  It made me feel like I was in Europe which was cute..but not ideal if you're driving and trying to find parking...I highly recommend finding other means to get here.  

Once inside it was cozy...maybe a little too cozy since seating was really close to one table to another...so much I can hear other people's conversation in every detail.  Can kind of ruin a meal depending on who you sit next to. Anyways, we ordered our food.  I ordered a salad and rabbit entree and my bf got the french onion soup and blood sausage. We also got the two different desserts at the end as well.  We both LOVED our entrees.  My rabbit stew was so tender and had no gamey taste to it.  I loved it so much.  I had some of my bf's meal too and it was sooo good.  The blood sausage paired with some stewed apples were a great combo.  Very rich and hearty food that's done very well.  As for the dessert...I dont' remember much of it but it did come out partially frozen (not fully thawed).  

Overall ambiance and meal here are great.  It is a cozy/tight spot so if you don't like that then you shouldn't be here or ask for an emptier side of the restaurant.  If it was a nicer day/night I'd try to eat outside since it's cute Parisian like even.
author: Kim D.

description:
Ah.. just ok! Love the set up and seems like a great way to beat the chilly wind in SF, but be seated outdoors!
The food and service here seems 'mass produced'. 
The sauces in the food are overdone and intense taking away the taste of the meat.  Its French ? I mis undertood
author: Sridevi K.

description: Moules frites were great and the blood sausage was just as impressive.
author: Ryan K.

description: this place is great, it has great French food that made me think I was actually in France. The only problem was that it was a little chilly inside, eve downstairs! But all in all it was good
author: Lasse O.

description:
I'm a big lover of French Food and I was so thrilled and excited to come here with a big group of my friends for dinner one night. I loved the little alley the restaurant is located in, it felt so romantic and frenchy. And then it all went downhill from there....

They get the two stars because they butchered my steak,  it breaks my heart when a thick filet Mignon comes out promised to be medium rare and there is just blood draining out of the meat after one slice into it.  We're not talking about the good bloody we're talking about the bloody vampire steak that turns mashed potatoes bright red. We're talking about I was too disgusted to even eat my steak. We're talking about a burnt charred inside with a painfully red inside... It's not like I asked for VERY RARE or even Rare. i asked for medium rare. I don't think anyone on the twilight cast would approve of the bloodiness. Then to make matters worse, they took the steak back, cut it up into slices seared it and then it turned into well done.  What's the point of getting a filet when the restaurant decides fixing a blunder is just throwing the meat back on the stove? 

I don't think they'll get a next time, they're charming, the escargot was good and that was the saving grace.
author: Christine B.

description:
Service was uber slow, 40 minutes for entrees to arrive after having finished the soup.

My party all got the french onion soup and ordered the boeuf bourguignon (beef strew), duck confit, lapin (rabbit), and vegetable gratin as main course. They were all very bland and one dimensional...nothing memorable...we ate in silence because nobody wanted to be negative.  

Flavors, ambiance, service overall was a disappointment. Actually kind of embarrassed that I picked this restaurant for my friends and I...
author: Katherine C.

description:
3/29/13 Lunch

3.5* Quiche Lorraine was tasty--the crust crispy, the quiche itself fluffy, not too cheesy. The crust is not super thin and chewy. The plate comes with mixed greens and pomme frites. Pairing with a glass of Côtes du Rhône pinot. 

Food is decent but doesn't mesure up to Cafe Claude or South Park Cafe.
author: Matt Y.

description:
Very disappointing...

Service was very slow to the point I wanted to just walk up to the register and pay my bill. There were two large parties sitting at the basement and I assume they were not walk ins...so why only schedule two waiters for the entire evening? 

Besides the French onion soup that was decent, all other dishes were made poorly. 
The avocado & shrimp cocktail appetizer was awful, they give you baby finger size frozen shrimp that taste super fishy and were drenched in thousand island dressing. 

The pork chop was just OK and it was way way over done. 
The prawns in my main course were very inconsistent....some were barely cooked, some were overly cooked, some had shells on the tails, and some didn't. 

The main courses were a disaster. 

We were not interested to spend any more money here but it still took 15 minutes to get our bill. 

The two stars are for their bread, location & outdoor seating only.
author: Maggie C.

description: My boyfriend and I had the perfect dinner experience here. The complimentary warm baguette tasted like Paris: crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside, slightly sweet, slightly sour. Ahhh I would go back just for the bread. The French onion soup was rich and mouth-wateringly flavorful without being too heavy or too salty. They pour their wine generously and don't even THINK about skipping dessert. I'm not much into sweet stuff but their mousse-y concoctions made me melt with happiness. Service was super friendly and efficient. Ambiance was romantic (they use REAL candles on the their tables, makes all the difference), warm, and relaxed. Every diner around us seemed to be enjoying themselves, so you can't really go wrong here. It's a magical place.
author: Lisa N.

description:
Super nice service, water was always refilled without asking. Felt like in a great restaurant in Paris ;)
The food was amazing too! We had the rabbit and mussels. They Were delicious. Also had the snails...those one were a miss though. I found them tasteless... Maybe it wasn't the night.
All in all we'll be back and recommend!
author: Emma E.

description:
Yum! Went here for a friend's birthday dinner. It's more expensive than I usually go (read $20 one person dinner entree), and also more fancy.  I had the seafood pasta and it was delicious. The cream sauce was very rich, but not super crazy heavy. I probably should have asked for a box 3/4 of the way in, but it was so tastey! The service was great- with the almost all in French menu, it was nice that our waitress was generous in offering to answer questions, and the waiter with the water pitcher was all over it! (I tend to drink like a fish at meals).

We split the olive appetizer and it was tastey! There were probably about 25 olives on the plate and so yum! I tried some of my friend's gnocci which was also super rich and delicious.  The vegetable grati and chicken something seemed to go over well with others in my party :) 

Mussels seem to be a specialty of theirs.  They were included in my pasta situation and normally I'm not a fan, but they were good!

We chose to sit outside, but there's also an inside option.
author: Emma F.

description:
I came with my female friend for birthday dinner here recently and made use of a Groupon. This is the first time both of us walked along Belden Place for dinner, and the first thing we noticed was how was fun it was passing thru this row if restaurants with all the outdoor seating set up. There's also all these hosts and hostesses from other restaurants along this row coming to us (but in friendly ways) presenting their menus and asking if we want to dine. To me, it reminds me of lively parts of Hong Kong.

I made reservations online here and we were assigned a table downstairs. Overall the dining spaces combined (excluding the outdoor) does not seem very big. The decor is okay.

As for the dinner, as part of the Groupon, we both ordered a French onion soup, a main dish from a selected set, and got two desserts. She got a duck confit and I got a beef stew, both served in a casserole form. Both were decent but if I could've I may have liked to try a steak item or something like that. That's okay, since we were talking advantage of a deal. My female friend lived the dessert though; we were served two different kinds of cake.

Three-plus stars for the overall experience, especially the dinnertime walk along Belden Place. It would probably be fun to try outdoor dining sometime, especially since we see all the places have heating lamps.
author: H K.

description:
This place needs to be on one of those Food Network shows where a famous Chef redoes the entire place, menus, interior and service included.

The inside is very banged up and disorganized looking, so when we walked in to be seated, we were slightly shocked to see how beat up this place is. It looks nothing like the pictures, its cold and dark. Service was HORRIBLE, we waited for good 15-20 minutes for our waitress to pay attention to us and explain the menu and bring our water and bread. 

The menu did not have a lot to choose from but we ended up going with Escargots De Bourgogne (Snails), Mariniere Moules (Mussels in wine sauce), Bavette A L'echalotte (Angus Steak with fries), and another ahi tuna dish. All of the dishes were tasteless. Nothing stood out over the other and it was bland. The Escargots were not cooked completely and the seasoning was still hard and uncooked. The Ahi dish was OK, but nothing special. The Moules and the Steak were uneatable, so we ended up not even finishing half of our meals. The fries that the restaurant brags about being "unlimited" with the Moules tasted horrible. McDonalds has better quality french fries. Overall, the experience was horrible. I would NEVER recommend any of my friends or family to go here. Hell with it, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. period! 

It was a waste of time, money and calories! If you want tasty, delicious food, avoid this place. So not worth it. ZERO stars, if I could.

P.S. - the owner is also very rude.
author: Karina A.

description: This café was so bad I was with seven people and we all hated it! Two people bought the burger and it was I quote "one of the worst burgers I've ever eaten." Salad was nothing special, at least the bread was fresh and tasty. Not worth the price. I mean, literally most of the food mediocre if not bad.
author: Sarah A.

description: I went here for our office holiday dinner. Food was blah... and service was eh! To top it off they double charged me for our dinner and when I called to have them correct this. The owner Oliver said he couldn't do anything and it was my issue with the bank not his. I let him know HIS SERVER was the one who charged my credit card twice and didn't tell me he had done so. He said he couldn't do anything to help me that it wasn't  his problem and he wouldn't call his merchant to fix this for us. HORRIBLE HORRIBLE SERVICE. I couldn't believe the OWNER would be so shady. NEVER GOING BACK. Oliver and his staff need an to take a customer service course.
author: Maria S.

description:
The food was mediocre at best. Cocktails were horrible. I started with a French Sangria, and it was nothing more than cheap wine with orange wedges tossed in. Then the waitress offered to replace my drink so I asked for a caprianah. It was not any better. 

For my entree I had the pork chop, and for the price you're paying you would expect a little fresher quality ingredients. 

I only came here because they had a table, where everywhere else had a long wait.
author: Ray C.

description:
We came here for lunch back in December.  We were wandering around looking for a place to eat and we noticed this alleyway and all these cute restaurants.  Cafe Bastille was the "first" restaurant we saw so we thought we'd give it a try.  We were seated right away, a table for two.  Yes, the place was small and intimate, but it was full.  We had the last table that afternoon.  And with so many people, I was surprised that we could actually have a conversation since the tables were pretty close together.  People were polite about keeping their voices at a conversational level vs. loud and boisterious.  

I ordered a crepe (Complete -- ham, cheese, eggs) with salad, Latte, and Crepe Suzette for dessert.  Overall, the food was fine.  I enjoyed the ambiance and the service.  At least for a time, I felt I was in "old Paris" (never having been to France), but overall, we enjoyed our time there.  

Yes, we'll return when we are back in San Francisco.
author: Amy M.

description:
I am a former customer who loved your restaurant years ago, before I had a bad experience on my birthday in 2007. I wrote a poor review then, and just today came back to see if things have improved. What I found surprised me. My post from 2007 is still posted at the TOP of the list, as though YELP is continuing to hold Bastille to task, either for not improving, or possibly for not "buying down" the placement of my poor review from 9 years ago!!

I call FOUL! on Yelp for holding Bastille hostage in this manner, but I see that there's a way to sort the reviews by date, to see how people are reviewing more recently. It's obvious that recent complaints continue to note poor service and food, while many people also have great meals and dining experience. So what gives? How can anyone know whether Bastille's food has improved, or if the wait staff is still unfriendly, and motivated by curb appeal, convenience or profits rather than providing an excellent experience, as we used to enjoy at this cool location that we still have fond memories of.

So the obvious question for Bastille is: Why not RESPOND and improve?! I invite and encourage the owner/management to actually reply/answer each lousy review and DO SOMETHING to show you care about happy customers and a positive dining experience! Silence is not a good option, and it's obviously working against you! Train your staff to be more thoughtful and friendly if they are being dismissive!! Believe and take seriously these reviews and attempt to address the issues expressed. I'm amazed that isn't already happening.  I have no idea if management is connecting with recent unhappy customers, but if they had done so with me, I would feel heard, reassured by that effort to make things right, and consider removing my bad review, which as of today before my update, was still lurking at the top of Yelp's default review sorting. I care enough about this restaurant to shout out to Bastille's management, and if you're listening, reply! If you give great service, focus on the food, and respond positively to food complaints, you don't need Groupon, you'll regain my and other friends happy return to Beldon Alley. 

Zero Stars for Yelp, for keeping my old review at the top after 9 years. That's just LOUSY and reminds me of Yelp's sleazy practices of yesteryear, seemingly alive and well today. For Bastille, I'm upgrading to give you another chance. going from one star to two, because I LOVE FRANCE AND I WANT YOU TO IMPROVE! but that only happens when you attempt to fix the dissatisfaction of unhappy customers, rather than treating them like they don't exist or don't matter. 

My review is below, and will remain until someone from Bastille connects with me to show they care about customer experience. I'm not holding my breath, but I do believe in second chances. Someone in management has ignored this best business practice for years, and should wake up or be replaced.

6/13/2007 
We've been going to Cafe Bastille for years, and love the food there. We also like the atmosphere, which takes us back to our trips to France. 
The waiters and Maitre'd are another story. On our last visit, a cool night, we had a reservation (my birthday) yet when we arrived, they immediately insisted there wasn't indoor seating, and proceeded to seat us outside, where we could be seen by passers by as happy customers overflowing to the outdoor seating. We were so uncomfortable outside that we asked for an inside table again, and were reluctantly led inside ... into a relatively empty restaurant!! 
Amid an abundance of empty tables, we were seated wedged between the only two occupied tables in the area, so we were all bunched together overhearing each other's conversations. I have no idea why they do this!! 
Although our meal was wonderful, as usual, I left feeling very disappointed in their handling of the customer experience, which seems to take a back seat to self-promotion and convenience for the staff. We hate to say it, but we don't plan on returning anytime soon. I hope they'll reconsider their priorities and return to a customer-oriented approach. Three stars for food, one star for service.
author: Mary P.

description:
Went here on a Friday night with a group of 12 and didn't leave for almost 4 hours. Of course the Birthday Girl was late, and a few people straggled, but the overall service was slow and under par.

The food was pricey for what you got, the steak came out undercooked, and our server seemed completely annoyed to be handling our table.
author: Katie K.

description: The manager was very rude. We complained that the corkage fee should not be taxed as we were taxed when we bought the wine. Second were taxed on the tip.....i dont think so! He wouldn't even take off the San Francisco tax, which we weren't obliged to pay. I would not go back ever again nor would i recommend it. Portions were small and meat tough.
author: Roberto A.

description:
Went here for lunch today with a colleague.  I'd never been to Cafe Bastille and was wondering how it'd compare to Cafe Claude, a favorite French food place.   Sadly, Cafe Bastille's food wasn't quite as good.  Their service is excellent, so perhaps the dish I ordered wasn't one of their best.  

I ordered the Quiche Lorraine which comes with french fries and salad.   The slice of quiche is large.  However, it was some greasy and not fluffy.  Perhaps it was silly of me to expect what I had in Paris which was an amazing, melt in your mouth, slice of Quiche Lorraine.  The fries were slightly overcooked as well.  The salad was the best part of the meal.  

I'll come back as the service was attentive and try something else with the hopes that I just chose the wrong dish.
author: Scott S.

description: At the last minute, I decided to buy a Groupon for the prix fixe menu at Cafe Bastille. It was wonderful!! We made reservations, went on Friday (no day restrictions on this Groupon) and sat outside under the heaters and had a wonderful dinner. We both had the onion soup. Perfect!! Not overly salted as so many can be. The cheese was gooey and the broth was delicious. We ate this along with our warm crusty bread and butter. We were even offered a 2nd basket of bread! Then, my husband had the Boeuf bourguignon and I had the Moules (mussels) Normande.  His beef was tender with the best sauce and my huge pile of mussels was in a light cream sauce with bacon. Mine came with a hot pile of fresh french fries!!  All of it was unbelievably good!!! And then we got the two desserts, raspberry and chocolate mousse!!  Every bite was delicious!! My only complaint.... too much food!! Lol!! Such a generous menu!! We took some home!!  Thank you to the wonderful wait staff with a special thanks to Reynaud. We will definitely be back to this treasure of a place!
author: Marybeth E.

description:
I'm on a very unlucky streak with my dining experiences.

The hostess was a bit rude when we asked for a table telling us that the wait would be long for such a large group even though we had already made reservations. Our party of 12 (including two children) were seated in the underground room and were the only party downstairs for most of the night.

Our servers were friendly and didn't really rush us, which was great because we were waiting for friends to arrive. But the nastiest surprise appeared when we were deciding what to order. My friend had a ROACH crawling on his menu. 

I will never return.
author: Totran M.

description: One of the many European style restaurants in Belden Place, Cafe Bastille offers French cuisine with slight California additions to satisfy the San Franciscan palate. I came here for a team lunch, and the outdoor seating was really pleasant for the rare sunny day in the city. I ordered the grilled chicken sandwich, which came with a side of greens. The bread was on the crunchier side, but it was a good contrast to the tender grilled chicken and melting brie on the inside. The roasted red peppers added a little extra flavor, but I felt like the sandwich was missing something as a whole. For the price you pay, the food is average, but I loved the European vibe from the patio setting and busy lunch hours.
author: Ashley T.

description: Best French restaurant in town! Great food and service! I recommend, and I'm French ;)
author: Marie C.

description:
I love this place.  The food is fabulous, and the service is excellent  Highly recommend for dinner when friends visit the city.  
city diner
author: Isabelle G.

description:
We were planning on the Dine About Town prix fixe dinner menu, but all the other items on the menu were too tempting and we figured it would probably be as much or less to just order the individual things we wanted.
