In fact, I think each item on the regular prix fixe menu and the Dine About Town menu would add up to whatever it should be so it's not much of a deal to get the prix fixe. I definitely love the atmosphere here because I'm a sucker for the European-styled side walk cafe and outdoor dining in general. I love the chatter of the dinner crowd and the cool night breeze. I had made a reservation beforehand it was a good thing I did because this place was packed. We nabbed the last table outside. The service was good and we stayed there a long time.

We started out with the crab cakes and they were definitely not what we expected because they were little fried balls rather than the flat cakes I had imagined. Still, it was good because you can definitely taste the crab meat in it. It was a little dry, but the dipping sauce it came with was super good and thick. I could definitely spread that on anything. I also had the french onion soup which was one of the better ones I've had because it was not salty and the bread pieces were still intact, not broken down mush at the bottom of the bowl. The cheese was not crusted hard on top, but quite melty. I had it with the ratatouille and chicken crepe, but a little sad that there was not so much ratatouille in it and was more like a light tomato sauce. The chicken was a bit dry too. I tried the boudin noir, which was really good. The mashed potatoes were creamy and the caramelized apples were still firm. The blood sausage was very loose and far from processed. The hacis parmentier was super cheesy and hearty. I was a little disappointed by the dessert menu because they had a lot of cakes on there, but I shall for sure try the floating island next time. I would probably try the mussels and escargot next time too.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The food was delicious and the service very attentive. I can't wait to go back.
Btw: the dessert I had was particularly amazing. I forget what it was called in French but it translates to "floating Island" in English.
author: Genevieve G.

description:
We were headed to Plouf, but they were closed for lunch.  DH was craving mussels, so we figured we'd give Cafe Bastille a shot.  It was disappointing.  Service was good, but the food fell short.

The French onion soup was bland--no depth.  The mussels were of mediocre quality and the fries were terrible.  I'm a french fry fiend but I didn't bother to steal more than a couple from hubby.  That says it all; pretty sure it's the only time I haven't stolen fries from his plate.  How can a French restaurant screw up pommes frites?!  They had absolutely no flavor. Sad.  The house mesclun salad was the one good item.  We ended up paying almost $60 after tip for an unsatisfying lunch (they charge $6 for a VIRGIN bloody mary!)

Maybe they do some other items well, but we'll never know.  Next time Plouf is closed, we'll keep walking. Sorry, guys.
author: Areena M.

description:
How can you mess up a French onion soup? I mean it has what? - 3 ingredients?
A messy mess with oil from cheese separated floating on top of the watery broth...bleh
I will be coming back until they stop serving the steak tartar for lunch...

And please, oh please, fix the damn tables! It feels like a circus act to balance your plates on the wiggly table without splashing your neighbors and you with whatever is on your plates.
author: Skate K.

description:
Made me really feel like I was on vacation!

Things to love:

Lovely out door seating
Lots of people around so you feel in the heart
Very friendly wait staff
Great location

Try:

The Lychee martini
truffle fries
THE CLAM CHOWDER
The tuna tartare

It can get cold outside

Advice:
It's right by Barneys, drop in after shopping to complete a great day!
author: Kimberley G.

description:
Cafe Bastille. One of the many interesting restaurants located in belden lane. There's outdoor seating and indoor seating also. The decor seems to be misc items that kind of loosely represent a French cafe.

== Food ==

French Onion soup. I don't try it often, but it was exactly what I expected it to be. Sweet soup with soggy bread. Overall, it's alright.

Pate Sampler. I'm not a big fan of liver, but it tasted alright to me.

Moules (Mussels) with fries is the thing to get! The broth is very delicious. There's a good amount of mussels given also. 

Bread comes free with the meal. I recommend dipping the bread into the mussel broth. It's so good.

== Service ==

The waiter was very nice and helpful to a pair of completely French cuisine lost people. The food came out pretty quick.

== Overall ==

Great service and atmosphere. It's a great place to go to for dinner.
author: Steven B.

description: While it's still snowing on the East Coast, I enjoyed sitting outdoors at Cafe Bastille in the Belden Place alleyway.  My dining companions had fish entrees, while I had a delicious grilled chicken sandwich with tomato, bacon and pesto aioli ... plus a side salad.  The wait staff were very hospitable.  A most enjoyable lunch!
author: Susan N.

description:
I wish I could rate this place 3.5 but it just isn't one of my favorites in Beldon.  Came here once for a lunch interview.  A lot of bougie people like to come here and pay $20/person for a lunch of Andouillette (a bougie hotdog).  Don't get me wrong... it was good but not good enough to motivate a second visit.

Come here if you're trying to impress someone but still trying to be "down with it".  Beldon is a great area for lunch.  Perfect if it's actually a sunny day.
author: Kay R.

description: Belden Place is one of San Francisco's most charming eatery areas by far -- wish there were more of these alleys. The fries and french onion soup here were quite good -- not necessarily crave-worthy, though. You can dine inside/outside -- wonderful little spot.
author: Mel G.

description: Having lunch at my favorite French place in the city! Can't believe I will be in Paris Thurs evening. Here at Bastille makes me feel like I already arrived:-)
author: Holly L.

description:
Ok...so what can't you say about french restaurants.  Decor is fancy, food is fancy, but this place doesnt feel stuffy.  I think its prolly cuz we ate outside which was great because it wasnt too cold.  

We went for the "Dine about Town" deal.  So we got a 3 course meal for cheap

1st course: Butternut squash soup, which was awesome.  I almost licked the bowl.  
2nd course: Mussels w/ fries.  A classic french combo and hella good!
3rd course: Its called "Floating Island" which is pretty much meringue floating on a sweet cream soup. I liked the meringue.  Nice and fluffy

Overall great experience at my first real french restaurant in a while.  Service was top notch and the atmosphere was relaxing.  

I dunno if i would be a regular here. We went because of Dine about Town ad i would definitely go for the same deal again.

p.s.

There is a cigar bar around the corner worth going.  its small but friendly.
author: Roberto C.

description:
Belden Place is such a small alley that it is easy to miss. It's off Bush, between Montgomery and Kearney--enter alongside Sam's. 

Cafe Bastille is a great spot to enjoy an al fresco lunch on a sunny day. It's a genuine French experience. The Salade Niscoise was wonderful. Delicious fresh baguette and nice, strong coffee. A little slice of Paris on your lunch hour? Why not.
C'est bon!
author: Joanna S.

description:
There was no seating outside and we had to sit inside and realized how tacky the decor was. The music was way too loud.
I had the steak tartar
Mustard rabbit.
Nothing special to write home about. I think there are better spots on the alley.
author: Nathan J.

description:
From the reviews, I was worried bout the service, but our service was great. We got checked up on a few times, staff was friendly, food came out in good time, and the bus boy cleaned up our plates quickly. 

FRISÉE AUX LARDONS with pancetta, poached egg, and warm shallot dressing-yum! The poached fried egg was so good with the crispy pancetta

STEAK TARTAR with pommes frites-pretty good and pommes frites was 3 pieces of toasted bread.

CHARCUTERIE SAMPLER with prosciutto, coppa, sopressata, and ham-this was all good besides the ham. That straight up tasted like the deli meat you buy at Safeway. 

Mussles with cream, bacon, mushroom-gave a decent amount and it was yummy.

The special was a filet mignon with mushroom and potatos- tender and flavorful. 

No room for dessert.
author: Karen H.

description: This place has the best food! My husband found a travelzoo dinner special for this place, & it's my new favorite place! We got two French onion soups, which were so amazing! Then my husband got the steak with caramelized onions. The meat was so tender & yummy. I got the gnocchi which is my favorite! Last was the creme brûlée :) all for 40$
author: Jen L.

description: Great place for lunch - outdoor seating and come here before noon to avoid the crowd. Bavette d'echalotte was yummy but overcooked (i asked for medium rare but came out medium). It's best if one asks for rare to compensate. Hachis parmentier is delicious - they took a peasant dish and made it better with cheese gratin. Highly recommend it!
author: Rebecca C.

description: A prix fixe menu is always nice to see and usually a good choice; the one here was solid and our target for Dine About Town. We all enjoyed the French onion soup, and our entrees (cassoulet, boef Bourgogne, and chicken) were all good, though none stood out as exceptional. The bread and butter, though, were excellent! Dessert yielded a surprise, as the chocolate creme brûlée bore no resemblance to any brûlée we'd seen before. It was more like a custard, layered atop chocolate torte, with no torching.
author: Bill B.

description:
I came here for lunch with a few co-workers. I ordered the chicken skewers and they came with pommes frites. I liked the food very much and it filled me up for lunch. I did eat a lot of bread. All of us ordered the onion soup and it was very appetizing. I got a soda (Coke) but the drink itself was very watered down. Somebody probably forgot to refill the syrup. 

The place was very busy during lunch time. The original waiter that took down our order forgot about us. How is that possible though? We still got our refills of water and beverages from the busboy but I didn't like being forgotten. No one checked in on us to find out if everything was alright. Usually everything is but I like being asked out of courtesy. Another waiter gave us the check at the end.
author: Tim G.

description:
We really enjoyed this cute little restaurant in the the Belden Place alley. The alley itself is a charming place to eat and that helped add to the appeal of this restaurant. 

The menu was surprisingly robust and they even had a price-fixed menu option. The portions were quite large and they had two specials that really appealed to us (which is why we didn't go the price-fix route), 

We really enjoyed this restaurant - tasty food, nice weather, good service and great atmosphere: it was a great evening!
author: Allison R.

description:
I have always loved Cafe Bastille, but they have not been awarding my OpenTable dining points.

There are plenty of restaurants on OpenTable that make sure you get your points.
author: johnfromberkeley h.

description: About two weeks after dining at La Folie I had the urge of going to more French restaurants. Instead of going to fine dining place I wanted to eat lunch at a simple French bistro. With all the craze of food trucks in the Financial District I was hoping to find more European restaurants in the area. This place is about two blocks away and I gave it try. I ordered two dishes: escargot (which I never had) and boudin noir, or blood sausages, (which I had in Les Halles in New York). The escargot in butter was surprisingly delightful and doesn't resemble to the slimy snails in your garden. I thought I would get two blood sausages but I only got one boudin noir. Don't get me wrong it was good. Overall it's a decent French place to eat downtown.
author: Gerald R.

description: In Aix en Provence there is a row of restaurants on Forum des Cardeurs.  Belden Place (near Bush and Montgomery) reminds me of this street and Cafe Bastille reminds me of the restaurants.  Whether you opt for a more casual sandwich, a filling salad, or a more substantial main course, you will not be disappointed.  On the French side, the onion soup, pate, and mussels are delicious.  For a more American choice, the hamburger is grand.  They also make a perfect martini (gin, of course) and have a lovely collections of wines.  Like many bistros in France, the house wine (vin ordinaire) is quite good.  Now that you know.....allez a Bastille!
author: Nigel P.

description:
Yay! I am a fan of Cafe Bastille! 

I love this place so much that it became a joke around my office - if I wasn't at my desk, I was at Cafe Bastille. 

They have tiny sidewalk tables that are all crooked and bunched up against the table next to you, but you don't mind because it feels like Paris! 

The tables inside are also really close quarters. Also they have a bench that runs along the back and one side of the restaurant and tables in front along with one chair opposite the bench that provides more seating. Again, it feels like Paris. 

The inside is small with a big bar and case full of salads and deserts. Lovely. 

I like to get the 3-salad sampler. It's a plate with any 3 of their GREAT salads. And a glass of wine. Even on work days. It is Paris afterall.
author: Steven C.

description:
I came here with a Groupon, and I have to say that was a great idea because I never would have known this place existed without it. It's down a little alley filled with other restaurants that I didn't know was there (and I've lived in SF my whole life). 
What really impressed me was the authenticity of this place - it had andouillette (tripe sausage), boudin noir (blood sausage) steak tartare (raw ground steak) and quenelles (fish puree dumplings)- all typical French fare that would be pretty hard to sell to unaccustomed Americans. I have to give it a great review just because it was bold enough to even put andouillette on the menu. 
The food was good - pretty rich but that's French food for you. I can't wait to come again!
author: Rebecca H.

description: Food was average. All I gotta say is 18% gratuity for 2 people. Who does that? Not coming back.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I've been here for brunch, lunch and dinner several times, and Cafe Bastille has never failed me.

The service is consistently friendly and professional.  (Not to mention the hot waiters!)

The food has always been solid.  Some of my faves include: mussels/fritte, French Onion Soup, the celery root remoulade and truite aux amandes. The food is certainly great for the price you pay.

The decor is actually made up of real vintage French signage. I like the fact that you can eat outdoors or in, and being at any of the restaurants on Belden Lane always feels romantic and old-worldy.

Tip: go for weekend brunch for bottomless mimosas.
author: Karen T.

description: Ambience is cool. Small, intimate dining, with a nice outside eating area. I have been here a couple times when working in the city and have even recommended to people as a quaint place to eat with great food and great service.
author: Anne S.

description: We came here for dinner after shopping and really had a great time.  The hostess was accommodating even though Open Table failed to send my reservation to their system.  Our waitress was very nice and helpful.  The cocktails were tasty and we really enjoyed the bell pepper/goat cheese appetizer.  I really liked the kobe beef carpaccio.  Our table ordered for entrees - potato gnocchi, boeuf bourguignon, and hachis parmentier.  They were all delicious but I liked mine the best (hachis parmentier).  The gnocchi is even better if another person at the table orders the boeuf bourguignon and you add a little bit of their broth to the gnocchi sauce.  For dessert we had the chocolate crepe and ile flottante. The ile flottante was a meringue in a creamy style lemon sauce.  It was delicious and not heavy at all.  Overall, we all enjoyed everything we ate and the service was good.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Came here for my sister's birthday dinner - we were a party of 12 and had made reservation through open table.  We got seated in the patio section (wished they had informed us of that prior, thinking they had room for 50+ indoor per the opentable site), but luckily it was a nice enough night for January.   The seats were rickity, and on uneven pavement, so the table was tilted a bit, and so did your chair. It was canopy, and they only had 1 heater on the restaurant side.  

The menu looked great online, however, the food was not.  I got the prix fixe menu - and got the french onion soup, coq au vin and mango mousse (open table advertised their fixed menu at $25, they really charge $30)

French Onion Soup:  The cheese was good, it came out nice and hot and the cheese and bread was tasty.  However, which you actually tasted the soup, it was pretty bland.  Not very much flavor at all. 

My entree was the Coq Au Vin ~ and was I very disappointed. Egg noddle, was fettuine noddle, and the chicken was so dry! I hoped that dipping it in the sauce would make it better, but the sauce was mediocre. My sister makes coq au vin and she does a better job than this restaurant!  I had coq au vin at many different places and this was the first time I was disappointed at a restaurant for something like this (which I thought was a safe choice!)  Not good and like previous reviewer said before, tasted like they used same stock and massed produced this! Our table of 12 had 3 order of Coq Au Vin and all the chicken were dry ~ the beef bougnion I sampled from my friend tasted of the same sauce they used for the Coq Au Vin ~ the vegtable (potatoe, et al) was still hard in my dish!  

My sister's entree: the lamb chop - my goodness, that was the worst lamb I ever had! It still tasted so game-y and the seasoning was ehh.  The green bean was super oily.  

The dessert made the meal tolerable. Great dessert, simple mango mousse cake wtih raspberry puree.  

Good bread, soft butter, so that was good.  

Service was good and bad. When the first half of the party arrived, we got attentive service, but when the birthday girl and the rest of the party arrived, our server disappear, no water, no explanation of the menu, etc. 

They did refilled our water a couple of times, but they kept hitting up against some of the guests wicker chair and causing that person to bump the table.  

Dislike that we where we were seated, we could smell some of the employees smoking!  Their chairs were super UNCOMFORTABLE. And godforbid you have long hair, it will get stuck in the chair.  Half of the table was cold since they only have 1 heater on the far side of the wall. 

Would not recommend for group or anyone who wants AUTHENTIC french food.  I felt bad for my sister's friend and ended up picking up most of the tab, since this was a horrible first experience into french food.  Go to Cafe Claude or Le Charme instead ~
author: Kp P.

description:
A-OK - 3 stars, but still like Cafe B., food can be a bit inconsistent, (some dishes just ok, some great). Its a lively & fun scene on Belden Place (alley) .  The best French food in SF ? Ahhh no. But a varied menu with something to please everyone. The usual French menu suspects,  dining " al fresco" and just the whole Belden alley scene is worth a visit. I like Plouf a bit better and will also give them 3 stars, the Plouf menu is a bit more creative. 

http://www.belden-place.com/view/restaurants/
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Came here with my friends over the weekend for dinner. They had the dine-about-town special going on, but I ordered the lightest thing on the menu as I wasn't feeling well. We sat outside next to the restaurant- luckily there are heaters built in on the side of the building and awnings over our head because it did get rather chilly at one point. 

Service was satisfying, our water glasses were refilled very frequently. One of the waitresses really knows her wines and recommended my friends certain kinds based on their meal. 

What I like about this place is the reasonable pricing for the amount and quality of food they give you. I ordered the vegetarian pasta of the day, which turned out to be fettuccine, various veggies, mushrooms and tomato sauce. I was pleased with the way this dish turned out-- the sauce was light and the texture of the pasta and vegetables were all on point, not soggy or undercooked. The chunks of (parmesan?) cheese on top really added extra flavor, which I personally liked. With the $14 pasta dish and very pieces of their hot, toasty bread, I was full and content. 

I'm tentatively giving this place 3 stars because the pasta was good, but not special. Also, my friends complained about too much saltiness in their food, and I can attest to it as I tried their food. However, I think I would give this place another try in the future.
author: K. N.

description:
The Groupon offers a 3 course menu: appetizer, entree, and dessert. The French onion soup was hearty.  My friend enjoyed her beef Bourguignon.  The duck confit that I ordered was nothing special. The pastry desserts were OK.
Having dined at many restaurants across San Francisco, most of the time, I find the service commendable.  I was disappointed with the service here: our waitress was almost taciturn when we asked about various dishes.  When she came by during the entree course to ask about them, she walked away so quickly, making a response irrelevant. She forgot to bring our water during our dessert course. When we noted the charge of 18% gratuity, I asked the manager whether this % was required given our rather mediocre service. (I expect to pay 20% of the original price for good service and that's fair IF the service is good.)  What was unbelievable was that he didn't want to even hear why we felt this way. No wonder service is uninspired here: management is not interested in feedback!
author: Liana T.

description:
Cafe Bastille deserves a solid 4 stars.   

Now the location, on Belden place, is perfect.   Sitting outside at one of these small tables, uncomfortably perched on my chair, with the ability to pick food in the plate at the next table, all the while hearing French waiters run up and down screaming "cafe et l'addition!", that in itself takes me back to France and is worth a couple of stars.

Their food deserves a star as well.  They always make a good quiche, their fries are quite tasty, and I am rather fond of their Croque Monsieur.   To be honest, I've mostly been here at lunch and ordered bistro type fare, as mentioned above.  Anyway, the food isn't  Bouchon (http://www.yelp.com/biz/M7gmOk8Ayf-stORW8QjgOQ) good by a stretch of the imagination.  I even think Cafe de La Presse, up the street, has a slight edge on them food-wise.  Still, it's a very nice lunch, certainly far better than the typical Lee's Deli lunch (I should know... I've had my share of those as well!)

Now, though, for the last star... They serve Sancerre by the glass.   I love to come here at lunch, look around at all the tables with people drinking water, coke, or iced tea, and order a glass of Sancerre.   Take a look around next time you're there, and I *dare* you to do it... order a glass of wine with lunch... I dare you.
author: David O.

description:
i don't wanna recommend about foods, maybe some people like it, some people don't like it
i just wanna say, we paid $34+  with Groupon($39) in total.
they didn't and won't tell you they charge 18% tips 4%mandate and Tax.

we had a cup of majito, it costs $8.50
so i think $8.5+$70(groupon deal) is $78.5
but the taxes were $8.38
i don't know how they calculated it.

One star for food, at least i think food was ok
another one for Jesus Christ

Fair?
author: William C.

description: Drinks and food took a VERY long time. Food was OK: not bad, but not particularly impressive either. I think we will not be stopping by again.
author: Manny H.

description: We went here last Saturday for a friend's birthday. They were able to accommodate a party of 14 (which then became 10) easily which I appreciated. The place was in a little alleyway off Sutter Street. I love the decorations inside, especially all the French signs on the wall. Drinks were decent but a little pricey. We had the combination Charcuterie plate to share and that was good, especially the pate. They also serve bread in the beginning. For the entree, I got the Trout (forgot the name of the dish) which was delicious! Soft but not too chewy, and with a little hint of garlic. I also got to try their Boeuf Bourguignon which was amazing - the beef was cooked just right and the red wine sauce went well with the bread. I also ordered a mocha at the end and it was probably the biggest cup of mocha I've ever had - delicious and well worth the $4! Would come again to try their other dishes.
author: Tyler B.

description: Readers, please disregard the yelpers who don't have a developed pallet, or money to pay the waiter the 20%, or complain about the SF mandate to provide healthcare to people who work in the F&B industry. The restaurant has exceptional flavors, true to the French cuisine. We have enjoyed dining throughout France. The place does not have the ambiance or the personal servers like Michelin star restaurants, but the service was exceptional. One word to describe this place: magnificent!
author: T P.

description:
I just had dinner with my girlfriend at Cafe Bastille.  We decided not to go back again.  We haven't heard about mandatory tips of 18% plus 4% healthy SF on a table of 2 (usually 6 or more); (a total of 22%, on top of it, the 22% is being taxed as well).  We wouldn't mind if our server (Brandi D) didn't give us an attitude about me saying the 2 different dessert cakes we ordered had refrigerator taste & smell.  She said to me "why didn't you say something before you eat it".  She didn't even say thank you to us at the end. 
If you decide to go to Cafe Bastille, I highly suggest not to sit at Brandi D's table.  And try not to order the cake dessert unless you don't mind refrigerator taste & smell.
author: Angela Q.

description:
I have been going to the Cafe Bastille for about five years now. Every time I am in the city I always recommend it to visiting family and friends. I just love the vibe there it's really out of the way, but not too far away. It is on a side street and if you come there when they are closed it will look just like an alley way, but it's so much more. When all the restaurants on that street are open it transforms into a lively city secret. You see lots of international people and families. 

The ambience is really nice with little cafe tables lined up next to one another. I'm reminds me of paris when I go there. When a restaurant accomplishes the point of it's staging you know it's gotta be good. They offer bread at the tables and it's amazing baguettes. Crunchy, and cloudy soft in the middle. They also give you a SOFT butter. I could sit there and just eat the bread all day.

For the menu it's filled with many traditional french options. I have had an amazing steak there. I recommend the crab salad, it's divine. Wine choices are good also, you can do by-the-glass or per bottle. 

I really recommend this place. It's one of my favorites in SF. It's great for a saturday brunch (closed sundays) or a casual date. I wouldn't go on a first date, but a third date would be perfect.
author: Sherae H.

description: I will never step in that place, never again. One of the waitrer (the fat French one) was the ruddiest I have ever seen! I was having a beer with some friends at the bar on Bastille day (!), the bottle wasn't empty and he threw the bottle in the trash without checking the content. I told him that it wasn't empty, he didn't look at me, got the beer bottle out to check if I was't lying!! He didn't look at me again until I went to talk to him, then, being extremely aggressive, with his ugly face a few inches close to mine, "I'm going to give another one". Took it, without saying thank you (of course!) and went outside. It was just appalling! By the way, I created an account on yelp, just because it was one if the worst experience in a restaurant ever!
author: Jeremie D.

description:
Visited during Christmas week, taking my three children (15, 13, 11) for a "French" dinner.  Let me just say that it was truly disappointing.

We had the chicken pate to start, which was fine, but the main courses were bland and character-less.  My son had the steak and fries and my youngest had gnocchi.  Those were "fine" and no problem as they are not French dishes (my childrens' choices of course).

However, my oldest had the Hachis Parmentier, which amounted to a casserole dish I could have made myself (and I'm not a great cook).  I suppose an argument could be made about how this is not a tremendous French dish, but I would hope that a restaurant charging $17.50 would make it more special.

I had the cassoulet, with duck confit, sausages, and white beans.  Flavorless, absolutely unimpressive, and what's more, it was recommended by our waitress (I make a point of asking for house specialties and recommendations when visiting new restaurants).  

Really?  If this is the best Bastille can do, they can rest assured I will not be visiting again (nor will I be recommending it to anyone, hence this review).  In San Francisco you have many other choices for restaurants, and French food as well, so SKIP IT.
author: Christopher B.

description: The food here is absolutely fabulous. It seems to be a hidden gem.  There are a few restaurants on this street but Café Bastille has the most authentic and consistently delicious menu. The staff is already friendly and accommodating.  I moved here from Paris, France and this is exactly the same casual, but decadent cuisine I was accustomed to. Everything on the menu is excellent. Also, this is the only place in SF who can make a proper Kir Royal.  :-)
author: Kristina T.

description:
For my birthday, some of my sweet coworkers took me here for lunch.

To get to Cafe Bastille, we had to walk down Beldon Place and pass by 4-5 restaurants desperate and hungry for customers.  A host from each restaurant literally tried to show us their menu and convince us to come in.  It was quite a turn-off.

After we finally made it to our restaurant of choice, we were kindly greeted and quickly seated outside.  Our waiter was also accommodating and helpful with the food-selecting process.  Having very little experience with French food, I needed all the assistance I could get!

Our party shared two orders of fries.  For my main entree, I had the Steamed Mussels Marinieres -- served with garlic, shallots, white wine, and a side of fries.  The portion was, unfortunately, very meager.  To make matters worse, the actual meat of the mussel was as small as a Robitussin pill.  However, it is important to note that the sauce was over-the-moon good.  I couldn't stop myself from dipping bread in it and eating it all soaked up with the savory, buttery sauce. 

For dessert, we all shared Chocolate Mousse and Cognac Creme Brulee.  I believe the mousse was a special they had (as I do not see this on their online menu).  I really liked the Creme Brulee.  You can actually taste the Cognac, which brought out so much flavor in the dessert. 

If I had the opportunity to come back here, I would definitely re-order the Steamed Mussels Marinieres.
author: Judy C.

description: Arrived at 5pm chose a table right away great service great food.  We opted for the prix fixe menu $35 French onion soup amazing delicious beef bourginon  chocolate mouse cake for dessert plus the bread was really good ! Def would come here again
author: lyn m.

description:
Part of the European restaurants collection on Belden.  Nice outdoor seating area but the food is just okay.  The last time I went, I had the Monday special, which is the rabbit stew.  The stew itself was very flavorful but too salty.  Really fragrant from the onions, carrots, mushrooms and potatoes.  The rabbit is just okay.  Not bad but not so good that I want to eat it again.

My wife had the mushroom crepe.  I liked how the crepe tasted but thought the cream filling was not creamy or buttery enough.

In conclusion, not a bad place to lunch every once in a while but not a regular nor a destination spot.
author: Willie L.

description: Doesn't look much when you walk in, but food is authentic and good, the setting feels like a subway in Paris, price is ok and the waiter was nice and helpful. Overall a very nice experience
author: Sjcp R.

description:
GROUPON WAS NOT WORTH IT. You think you are saving money on the meal but by the time the tax, automatic 18% tip (for a waitress who didn't do anything except take our orders!), and previously unmentioned 4% SF mandate are through, the meal is very expensive and NOT worth what you paid. I would have paid the $39 for that meal but the additional $30 worth of charges was really frustrating. 

Our waitress sucked! She took our orders after we waited like 15 minutes and then we only saw her once after that and then again for the check. The bus boy/water/bread/food server guy did EVERYTHING except take the orders. He was very hard working and I am sad he wasn't an overall waiter. The food itself was just averagely good, definitely not worth $79. My boyfriend and I both got the French onion soup which was just okay. The broth was too sweet for me, not savory enough. I got the chicken tarjine which was actually really good, bf got the beef bourginoune (sp) which he said was pretty good. I wanted the creme brûlée mousse for dessert and the waitress gave me some weird lecture about how they don't have it and only have this triple chocolate mousse cake... It was weird because she was trying to lecture me that they had creme brûlée mousse and not actual cake (which I knew), but then I discovered they didn't have anything remotely close to creme brûlée! It was literally 3 layers of chocolate mousse, not the dessert I was told I could get. Not to mention it was a little rude for her to lecture me. Bf got raspberry key lime pie which he enjoyed. The best part of the meal was actually the bread, it was delicious. Other than that though, a disappointing experience and I feel we were quite cheated out of our money.
1 star for the bread, 1 star for that hardworking guy who attended to us all night.
author: Dana B.

description:
Pro - location, outdoor seating, good portions.

Con - nothing to rave about, bland tasting....

Food - so so.... Mussels in wine sauce... bland flavor... good size, nothing to rave about.... left me feeling like going to Rumbo Al Sur in Oakland to quench my desire for some delicious mussels. The fries were a bit soggy.

The BOEUF BOURGUIGNON was actually a better choice. A bit more tastier than the mussels. 

The tables are small and the seating area inside is dimly light. Kind of make me wonder what they are hiding. We sat downstairs and the booth appears to be broken. I am about 110 lbs and I sank in as I sat down...

The pricing for entrees are about $18-20. Mussels were about $16. I will probably go to a different place on Belden Lane
author: Jay S.

description:
Had dinner here with a girlfriend.  The food and service were about 3/5 (unlimited fries with the mussels - great).  I left an $8 tip on a $55.85 bill, which is 14.3% (no, you don't automatically get a 15% tip).  The total I'd authorized on my card was therefore $63.85.  

When I got my credit card statement, I saw that they'd rounded my tip up to an even $10 and charged my card $65.85.   This happens more than you think, which is why I always keep receipts.

I did not contact Cafe Bastille b/c it's just not worth $2 of my time - but they get a major thumbs down for this.
author: Joyce W.

description: great place to have lunch or dinner with a large family.  We pretty much had the basement floor to ourselves and the waiter did a great job of keeping our glasses full and asking if we wanted anything else throughout lunch time.  Only flaw was that they forgot one dish we had ordered and reminded them of it when everyone was pretty much finished with their plates.  To compensate for their mistake they immediately brought out the dish, and it was on the house!  Very nice people, really nice location hidden away from the main street.  So its relatively quiet if you plan on eating outside in the alley way.
author: Anthony E.

description: Cafe Bastille gets 3 stars for atmosphere. The covered, heated patio tucked in an alley gives it a European feel. We loved that. The food, however, was not spectacular. I had the beet salad and was surprised to see it was the size of a side salad--especially since it was over $10. My husband had the ratatouille crepe, which was quite nice but untraditional since it was not served in a buckwheat crepe. The Cote du Rhone was mediocre. Next time we are in SF, we'll enjoy a French lunch elsewhere.
author: Suzanne K.

description:
Got a groupon- good thing too because the food quality does NOT warrant the prices they ordinarily would charge for the dishes. With the groupon, I'd say what we paid is barely fair for what we received. We paid $39 for the groupon, then over $20 for tax + the tip they calculate in. 

The mussels were the only thing of real worth- I got the ones in white wine. Solid flavor and barely any grit - can't complain. Would have paid the full $20 price for that one,...but then there was the rest of the meal. 

No one here has quite explained why the French onion soup is "bland" though many have described it as such. Let me explain for us all: there are hardly any onions in the soup, there seems to be little to no seasoning, and the broth tastes very watered down. The bread and cheese on top was fine. 

My boyfriend ordered the duck confit dish which would have been nice if they hadn't put so much salt he complained in the car about his tongue feeling a bit numb (and I think we've all eaten that meal with too much salt that left us with a similar feeling so simply think back and decide not to order this if you go here)

The desserts were both overly sweet, and only tasted any good if you put the two together.

The service was pretty solid, but it should be if you are the only couple in the place for over half the meal. One star for the mussels and the other for service. The three missing stars for the sad choice of either overly salted / sweetened or empty of flavor dishes and the silly pricing.

Oh lastly, heads up for those trying to impress. The place looks a little run down, so not very visually impressive. Not relevant to the review, but worth to note in general I think.
author: Melissa C.

description: Very nice event for me and my "BOO ".. Celebrated 15 yrs together !.. I had the rabbit , she had the Beef Bougandy, both very good.. Would I return ?... Yes !!
author: Jim L.

description:
I had never tried French cuisine, so I decided to take advantage of the Groupon and try out Cafe Bastille.

I had a 7pm reservation, but when I approached the hostess, she seemed annoyed that I had gone up to her. She dismissively told us to sit anywhere because we had chosen to sit outside. She then yelled from inside that we can only sit in the green chairs. From the get-go, it just didn't feel professional. Unfortunately, she was also in charge of my table. She took our orders and we didn't see much of her throughout the dinner. 

I had ordered the French Onion Soup and Beef Stew, while my friend had ordered the Mesclun Salad and the Duck Confit. We both ordered the Chocolate Creme Brûlée Mousse for dessert. I felt like the French Onion Soup was a bit on the sweet side, and the Beef Stew was a bit too salty, but the beef was so deliciously tender. I had to use the bread to balance out the saltiness of the beef. I had a bit of my friend's salad and that was absolutely delicious. The dressing was perfect. The duck was a bit salty yet tender as well, but the white beans were SO good. I was disappointed with the dessert. I thought I was getting an actual Creme Brûlée because the menu didn't say it was mousse, but regardless, I found the mousse to be bland. It was just okay, nothing special, but not disgusting either.

My friend and I waited ten minutes for our check after our dessert plates were taken away, and she continued to be short and curt with us. It just gave us such a horrible vibe. We were also surprised at the 18% automatic gratuity charge for a party of 2 (because of the Groupon).

Overall, the food was average, service was great because my water and bread basket was always filled, but the customer service was terrible because my server was rude and inattentive.

Belden Pl is beautiful, but I would skip Cafe Bastille. It wasn't worth it, even with the Groupon.
author: Sharon T.

description:
One time, I had this amazing coq au vin at a French restaurant in NY. It was the most perfectly cooked and tender chicken, with the right amount of flavor. So, when I ordered the coq au vin at Cafe Bastille, I expected just that. Unfortunately, the chicken was on the dry side. The flavor was good, but with coq au vin, the chicken has to be right, too. Because I was distracted by the texture of the chicken, this dish was a 2.5 star rating.

I also had a cocktail--Lola's French Kiss, recommended by the server because I didn't know what to order. I like chocolate, so I thought this would be a good drink. I'm sure the cocktail was delicious, but for me... Chocolate and vodka don't mix. Or maybe, there was more vodka flavor than there should be. I wish I had followed my intuition and just ordered the regular French Kiss. 

Now, you see that I've rated it 4 stars, though. Why? The service was great! The servers were super nice (and some were good-looking ;)...). And, also, the baguette they serve is the best baguette I've ever had. That really was the highlight of the meal. It came out fresh, and had the right balance of crisp on the outside and soft & dough-y on the inside. I really crave that baguette right now...

Overall, this is a cute cafe, nice date place, great space--next time I'll try something else. I usually hesitate with ordering chicken...
author: Vera W.

description: Very disappointed! The hostess was not friendly... Waiter was good. The only best thing was the french bread fresh from the oven. Definitely not worth the money.
author: Connie J.

description: Horrible service, bland food. The only thing that stood out was bone marrow. Tuna wasn't fresh.  Mussels weren't garlicky or salty enough. And duck was just bland. But the service was really really bad. Wine never made it with my dinner.  The waitress seemed irritated and acted like she's doing us a favor. Go to cage Claude that's right next to it instead for great French food.
author: Elle K.

description: Amazing gem of a place!  Tucked away in the alley, you feel like you have escaped to Europe. Wonderful ambience, including the music. The service is fantastic, and the food was excellent. I had the duck confit. Bon appetit!
author: Christie H.

description:
Charming atmosphere- especially for warm weather outdoor dining. Not my favorite french restaurant in San Francisco, but a wonderful experience all the same. 

We especially enjoyed the Boeuf bourguignon and the french onion soup!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
This place is great when it's beautiful out, and you are downtown!  I've eaten here a handful of times, and have always been satisfied.

Their bread is fantastic.  I always end up eating pretty much a whole basket when I go!

I've had their boudin noir (pretty good!!), moules marinieres (very tasty, but also a little heavy for that warm day), ratatouille crepe (which is my favorite dish from them!), and tastes of their bone marrow (so decadent), hachis parmentier (also super tasty), and coq au vin (mmmm).  All of the desserts I've had there are also fantastic!

The waiters are all French, and the ambiance really feels European.

Prices are reasonable, and there are always French people dining there, so it must be pretty authentic, right?
author: Vero K.

description:
My wife and I are now regulars at Cafe Bastille - it is close to her work and I'm happy to come into the heart of SF to have dinner here!  My wife has not read the menu after our first time there because she ALWAYS gets the mussels...yes, they are apparently that good!  (Including the use of the warm baguette or the french fries to sop up the sauce!)  I, on the other hand, have the luxury of trying their many tasty specials...last time it was the filet mignon, tonight it was the pork tenderloin with carmelized pears and lentils...mmm, mmm good!

The food is creative, tasty, and authentic.  I am a fan!

As a bonus one of our favorite waiters - Anatoliy - who used to work at another French restaurant in town has made this his home.  He has consistently steered me toward good wines, and his suggestions on the menu or the specials are pure gold!

For our rare "date nights", Cafe Bastille is at the top of our list!
author: Anders N.

description:
Went on a Thursday evening after Christmas. The location is easy to miss, but adds to the charm. Once seated, it took a bit for our server to take our drink order which were excellent. Had a salmon duo appetizer and my wife had a endive salad that were both a nice beginning. She had the flat iron steak with French fries which were average at best. The meat had a good flavor, but the fries underwhelmed. I had the beef bourguignon which was a pretty large portion. Very tender beef. I did not taste the wine, but still a tasty dish on a winter evening. 
    Finished with a chocolate crepe and chocolate and pear tart with two espressos. Left fully satisfied but not painfully so. It was a lovely experience and a great value.
author: Jon T.

description:
Can't speak for the food, just dropped in to use the restroom since pretty much every other business in FiDi was closed on the Sunday. 

Had a glass of Chimay and some fries, which were both a nice break from a Sunday afternoon of showing some friends around time. 

What stands out at this restaurant is all the authentic colorful signs decorating the walls. Hidden down the Belden alley it definitely feels like a French cafe in another land. 

Service was quick and prompt. If not for dinner, come for a drink and a quick appetizer to recharge yourself.
author: Binh D.

description:
Wow, we were so incredibly happy with our group experience at Café Bastille on Belden. We arranged a dinner with 84 colleagues from all over the US and wanted to show a good taste of San Francisco without going bankrupt.  

Café Bastille did not disappoint.  

We had a custom prix-fixe meal with a salad as a starter, beef and salmon as main dish choices, and a chocolate mousse.  Everyone seemed very happy with the ambiance, food, house wine and the service.  Olivier and Sabina were great to work with in setting it up.  I would do another event with Café Bastille in a heartbeat.  

Très bien!
author: Java Z.

description: Mediocre and pretentious--and overpriced. Even the groupon didn't make it worth it. Mussells were good. Fries were forgettable. Onion soup very ordinary. Dessert? Not good.
author: Brent B.

description: My wife and I are from out of town.  We ate here September 7, 2016 based on a recommendation that it was good and we could use a groupon coupon.  Big mistake!   The restaurant is located on a side street with several restaurants and the seating is mostly outside.  A bit cramped but ok.  The coupon gets you a 3 course Prix Fixe menu of soup or salad, limited main course choice and a desert.  This was for $49 for two people excluding tax, tip and drinks.  I had the salad which was ok.  My wife had the French onion soup which was ok.  They really let us down with the main courses.  My wife had the Coq au vin.  Very unflavorfull.  Boring.  My beef Bourguinon likewise lacked flavor or character of any kind.  The deserts were good, especially the chocolate one.  However, this was not enough to rescue the experience of the poor main courses provided on the Prix fixe menu.  We cannot comment on the other items on the menu and do not plan to return to try them...  The service was quite superficial and impersonal.  Not what we expected from a restaurant that calls itself French.
author: Nelson M.

description:
Today I took my favorite "guys" to lunch, my sister and her baby ~well he's a toddler now. We went to Café Bastille on Belden Alley. She had never been there before, so we picked a spot outside. 

They always have a prix fixe menu, so I've had it before ~ this place is great for groups. I have had a couple work parties here before. She went for the Dine About Town Menu and I decided to order off the regular menu and share the dessert with her.

She started with the French Onion Soup. So good, perfect even for soup which is not easy to perfect. The baby kept saying "I yike dat. I yike dat." 

Then she had the French Hot Dog with French Fries. Not because she is crazy about hot dogs, she doesn't really like them - but hoped the baby would eat more. It was a hot dog on a roll with melted cheese - nothing spectacular here.

But my salad, the  Dungeness Crab Meat Salad with Avocado, Orange and 
Cherry Tomatoes, served with a Jalapeno Vinaigrette ~ was so freaking awesome. The tender, tender crab was so good...it almost satisfied my crab craving which is almost everyday now. My sister liked this salad, so we shared it. It was worth the price too.

 For dessert, we had a coffee & cappuccino and the Flourless Chocolate Cake with three spoons. There is something about Flourless Cake that makes it better. It's Richer and more fudgy like although it was not hard. It was really, really good. We took our eyes off him for a second and he stuffed a huge piece of chocolate cake in his mouth. 

We had to get out of there fast, before the sugar hits him and he starts yelling. We all enjoyed it. Everything I had was awesome, so no complaints here.
author: Rebekah T.

description: First time here for lunch. Great food, fab service & prices were reasonable. Definitely coming back & recommend it.
author: Ray M.

description: The filet mignon in truffle sauce was phenomenal. Great appetizers as well. I look forward to going back!
author: Anwar H.

description: This place is basically okay. The food was not terrible, but nothing to write home about. Over priced, uninspired, but with decent service. The street construction on a weeknight was an unwelcome addition to the ambiance. Jackhammers are not a great accompaniment to dinner. This place is perfect for tourists or for those who don't care about great food.
author: M J.

description:
Stopped for lunch with a friend. It's hard not to love that Belden Place atmosphere. We enjoyed the steel signage hung as decoration; my friend, a graphic designer, had a keen appreciation for it and pointed out how the colors still looked fresh and unfaded. I liked the street lamp in the corner. 

Hungry for something new, I tried Steak Tartare. I remembered a hilarious Mr. Bean sketch from my youth where Bean can't afford anything but steak tartare and is horrified when he finds it's raw. I guess that restaurant probably just made it terribly, or his English sensibilities didn't allow it. Because man, the tartare here was delicious. Soft, cold and delicious, with a bright rich flavor and a very pleasurable texture. It had lots of herbs, capers, onions and some citrus, I think lemon juice. Very tasty.

I'm not really a "fry" guy but Bastille had pretty munchable french fries. I love dijon mustard so it was a nice change from ketchup.

My friend had the bowl of mussels in white wine and amazingly, polished the whole thing off. We paid the same thing, but he definitely got a ridiculous amount of food for his dollar. I was happy with what I paid, though. Will come here again soon, really enjoyed the atmosphere and the food was lovely and the lunch prices were very reasonable especially for the usually-expensive Belden Place selections.
author: Dara K.

description:
I don't ever remember not getting my money's worth from a coupon website, but sometimes you get lucky and discover a place that exceeds expectations.  Such was the case at Bastille.  We had the prix fixe menu and the ambiance drove me uncharacteristically to the onion soup.  It was some of the best I've had on the West Coast.  My only complaint is that it contained more bread than I would have preferred (their regular table bread is great).  The others had the mescaline salads which they thoroughly enjoyed.  

I hit the jackpot with my Rabbit entrée, which was the best I've had outside Italy.  It was served in casoulet style with nicely done spinach, rice and a few potatoes.  The meat was succulent (hard for rabbit), beautifully done and the sauce was the hook.  It's a dish I'll remember and crave from time to time. 

The delightful server was kind enough to substitute a small fillet mignon for the meat dish for just another $6 dollars and it was fantastic.  The Moules were sensational and done in that inimitable French brasserie style.  The desserts were the chocolate crème broulee that was different from the traditional consistency but was delicious and they even substituted fresh raspberries for the other dessert which made my calorie conscious date quite happy.

The place was full inside and out and it was a blast.  The house wine is a very serviceable French burgundy.  We'll be back.
author: john b.

description: The terrace which is located in an alley gives a European feeling. Went here for brunch, they served really good eggs Benedict! First time in San Francisco that I got a chocolate with my coffee! Friendly staff.
author: Heloise D.

description: Went here for Bastille Day. Nice service. The quiche lorraine deal w fries and salad at 11.50 is great!
author: Andrew K.

description:
The anticipation of trying a new restaurant! Well, the service and desert were very good, but the atmosphere and entrees left something to be desired. We were anxious to try a new french brasserie and we hoping to find a new hang out, unfortunately the boeuf bourguignon tasted like beef stew. You could not distiguish the flavors of the vegetables, potatoes and meat. It all tasted overly sweet and the same. My wife ordered a Beef/Potatoe/Cheese casserole that was 95% mashed potatoes with cheese and very little beef. The saving grace was the creme brulee and cappuccino, fantastic. 

No, we will NOT be going back, but when you try a new restaurant you win some and you lose some
author: Jim C.

description:
I do enjoy eating at Cafe Bastille and you can almost call me a regular there. The food is not always great but its not terrible either. I love the setting, it feels like Europe, one thing that disappoints me is the hostess.........uuuugh!!! most of them time she is NOT in a good mood and if you get her on her better days you MAY and just MAY get a smile out of her otherwise GOOD LUCK! 
Don't get me wrong obviously she hasn't stopped me from coming back but it would add SO MUCH if she could just smile more.
author: Kajal P.

description:
Started off rough...employee asked where would you like to sit.  I said "Outside". She responded nastily "what table??".  So I wasn't expecting a good experience.  Fortunately that person wasn't our server. 
Dinner included Caesar salad with anchovies and cold crisp lettuce.  Pork tenderloin with eggplant  was superb. Crepe Suzette (flambe at the table) for dessert.  Waiter so attentive and wasn't put out when I asked for plastic utensils for my left overs since we were staying in a hotel. Cute atmosphere.  Definitely will go back!!
author: Suzy J.

description: Average food, bad service, and noisy environment.  This is not a place to go if you are looking for something special and above average.
author: D C.

description: Good French Cafe in the heart of the San Francisco Financial Dustrict. Very casual atmosphere.
author: Greg L.

description:
It's Friday and I'm ready for a drink after a long week. I have an aunt who works very close to Cafe Bastille and who I join for happy hour here. It's located in the cutest little alleyway, which I had never heard of because I don't get a chance to venture to San Francisco as often as I would like.

My first time at Cafe Bastille I had pâté with some bread and the most delicious crispy fries and many drinks at the bar.

The staff is wonderful! They are so friendly, welcoming and they really take care of you while you're there. I heard that they are going to start having brunch soon. Hopefully that means a deal on some bottomless mimosas, then I this place would probably be my new home. I'd also love to try their dinner or lunch sometime.
author: Stephanie U.

description: if we had received more attentive service, i would have given 5 stars. we arrived just after 7pm and were seated outside (thank you heat lamps!). there weren't a lot of people in the restaurant but our waitress wasn't very giving of her time. she came by to say "enjoy your meal" 10 min after we'd been served. the better question would have been "how is everything?". that was a shame but the food was really good and that's what counts. i had the boeuf bourguignon and it was absolutely delicious! the meat was fall apart on the fork tender and the broth was super flavorful. i could have used a few more potatoes and less carrots but that's a personal preference...  my friend had the chicken tagine and it was too moroccan spice for me. i haven't been here in years but it was nice to see that the food is still as good as i remembered it to be.
author: Tera K.

description: Excellent vegetarian options. They had the best cauliflower soup I've ever had (never much liked the others). The vegetable gratin is delicious, very satisfying with a savory melted cheese top. The stuffed red pepper appetizer was also great.
author: Krishna R.

description:
Date & Time:  Dinner @ 8
Location:  Belden Place
Company:  Mom & Michael
Crowd:  Young Europeans 
Atmoshere:  Dirty
Decor:  Casual and Filthy Split Level
Service:  Snooty French
Imbibe:  wine
Devour:  Food is Terrible plus its Dirty there
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Went to Cafe Bastille for our monthly get together with S and J.  Cafe Bastille is in a little alley in the heart of the financial district.  Parking is non-existent so either take public transportation or come right after work.  This alley had a couple other restaurants in it also but I didn't pay attention.  Cafe Bastille has the outdoor seating with patio heaters as well as indoor seating with a bar and a downstairs on their busier nights.  I went on a Friday night and they didn't have to use the downstairs and barely used the interior, most people decided to enjoy the exterior seating and people watch.

Service was prompt and attentive.  Not too overbearing but we weren't neglected sitting outside.  We started with the escargot which in comparison to Gamine which I had recently, I enjoyed much better.  The garlic oil that it's cooked in was delicious, something I wanted to keep dipping my bread in but I had to save myself for my meal.

I had the mussels in the white wine sauce with the unlimited fries.  The mussels were tender, the broth it was cooked in was amazing, with a mix of bacon and mushrooms, very very good.  Also, in my opinion, better than Gamine.  Serving them with fries was I guess something very french, which I appreciated.  I definitely couldn't take advantage of the endless fries because I was so full but they were tasty, with a mayo to use as a dipping sauce.

S had the duck confit while J had the Casoulet, both duck dishes but prepared differently.  I thought the duck confit was more tender and flavorful than the Casoulet but different preparations and personal taste.  Couldn't go wrong with either, plenty of duck to get full off.

Overall, a great French experience for a reasonable price.  Couldn't really beat the food, if the parking and location was more convenient, def where I would go for my French fix.
author: Brian C.

description:
So riddle me this.  Why does Belden Place get 4 1/2 stars, but all of the restaurants receive only 3 1/2 stars?  

I'm giving Cafe Bastille 4 stars and here's my logic, "it's all good, monsieur."  Good french onion soup, good chicken sandwich with grilled yellow peppers (well worth the $11 price), good service, good restaurant.  3 1/2 stars anywhere else + the great location = 4 stars.
author: Ted R.

description: Came here for Dine About Town and had a good time.  The outdoor seating was nice and cozy with the heat lamps.  I really also liked how a lot of french customers come here which shows it's pretty authentic food.  I got the duck confit salad which was delicious and had more meat than i expected.  For my main course I got the seared salmon.  It was good but the skin was burnt on one side.  I tried some of my friend's NY steak and it was a tad dry but probably because it was medium well.  Dessert was one of the best chocolate mousse that i've had.  Service is great here and I would come back to try the normal menu.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Excellent lunch! I ordered the French onion soup and the Kobe beef carpaccio. Ended with the crema brûlée. Definitely coming back! It was all delicious!
author: Reyna V.

description: French onion soup is verrry cheesy but good. Bread is just okay but moule mariniere was delicious! The waiter was funny but a little sarcastic - but did an okay job serving a large party of 20.
author: Penny Y.

description: bought a groupon for dinner for 2 for $47 to celebrate my friend's bday. (still had to pay an additional $45 for gratuity and two glasses of wine.) had the french onion soup which was good, beef bourguignon which was really good, and a really delicious and light raspberry cake. as to whether it's a good authentic "french" restaurant, have no idea as im not a francophile and not an expert on french cuisine. but considering it's san francisco where french food is not big here, we both liked the place and would come back to try other dishes.
author: p f.

description:
A long time ago, my BF and I stumbled upon this gem of a street packed with restaurants in the middle of a thunder storm. We didn't know how we got there or where in the city it was, but we were happy for some cover and we both though we'd never see it again.  

Ironically, three years later, my BF recently began working across the street from said safe haven, so we come here quite often now. 

Yesterday was my first venture to Cafe Bastille. The restaurant is so cute! I really enjoyed the soft french music and the general ambiance of the restaurant. Unfortunately, the food was just ok. I got the special for the evening: filet mignon with asparagus, french fries and cream of foie gras. Everything (with the exception of my asparagus which was mushy - yuck!) was cooked well, but everything also lacked seasoning, which resulted as you might guess in a very bland meal - not ok. My BF's duck dish was more tasty, but still not excellent.

The result: cute restaurant, great ambiance, ok food. three stars.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Let me start by referring you to this review http://www.yelp.com/biz/lYrV8EKg_FEZtea2cnHaSA#hrid:nYliOjouI8eeP6vMhS8LgA
so you'll understand how it was that we decided on Cafe Bastille over the other restaurants located in little ole "charming" Belden Place. 

I wouldn't say Cafe Bastille is authentic French Faire, but it's good stuff. I had the Tiger Shrimp in a coconut sauce with risotto cake and a fried eggplant. My meal was Delicious. My friend had the goat cheese stuffed ravioli that was also really good. The French Onion soup wasn't such a hit and everything else seemed ok but not off the charts either. They could make their menu more authentically French.
author: Lori K.

description:
We thankfully found this cafe today on a little side street.  We had a lovely brunch -- 
Eggs Benedict!  Staff was very friendly.  We thought it was appropriately priced and if we lived around here we would definitely go back.
author: Diane S.

description:
Seeking authentic French cuisine in the Bay area?  Great spot for dinner.

Ambiance: Bistro-y a la Paris
Crowd:  couple of French speaking dames sat beside us so there was a bit of Francais which added to the overall feel
Service:  one server but she was friendly and helpful
Cocktails: try the Parisian concoction, skip the capiranha, what was I thinking ordering a Brazilian cocktail in a French resto?
Food:  Coq au vin was authentic

I may return here for Bastille Day celebrations July 14th and will post another review if I do.
author: Shelley S.

description:
Café Bastille is located in the same alley way as B44 and a few other restaurants (between Bush St & Pine St) a few blocks away from Union Square. We (party of 4) dined there for lunch on a Monday. The interior décor is busy yet fun with lots of signs posted all over the walls. They had a great beer, wine and cocktail selection. We ordered the following dishes:

Main Course:
-PROSCIUTTO with fig marmalade and blue cheese (substituted blue cheese with brie) sandwich came with a side salad
- CROQUE MONSIEUR roasted ham and cheese sandwich came with a side salad
- Monday special: COQ AU VIN
- HACHIS PARMENTIER braised beef casserole with mashed potatoes and cheese gratin

Dessert:
- Chocolate Crepe
- Mango, Coconut, and Passion Mousse

Our French waiter was friendly and attentive. He mentioned the specials made a few recommendations and quickly filled our glasses with water and offered bread upon sitting. The food was HANDS DOWN delicious with reasonable prices. The sandwiches had the right ratio of cheese to bread. The side salad's were a generous portion with not too much dressing. Oh and the Monday special was Mouth-watering! 

My only complaint would be the cappuccino as it tasted and looked like a latte with extra foam sprinkled with too much cinnamon.
author: Gabby D.

description: Charming litle French Cafe. The attmoshere is as good as the food. Fresh tasty dishes set on a small side street with tables on the pedestrian only street. Its a must evry time we come up to SF.
author: Michael M.

description:
Nice spot for a French style lunch in the European restaurant alley of SF's financial district. 3.5 stars. 

Cost to worth it ratio: 4 (great lunch deals) 

Eve award: best place for a super cheesy lunch 

Highlights: 
- Prix fixe lunch: 3 courses with drink (even a glass of wine) for under $20 
- Croque Madame: ham and cheese sandwich but with a a fried egg on top. Yeah, ok not the healthiest meal you could get, but I'm a sucker for a fried egg. ;-) Not the traditional baguette you'd expect--here it's more like French toast with thick soft bread. Another surprise was the egg topped the sandwich instead of being inside. Great all around. Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KRpCCCBwaJBGrkBCVUhW7g?select=o-C5VnXOfucdCMxsmZ7U_Q
- French onion soup: ooey gooey cheesy top with bread sopped in broth. What you would expect of french onion soup, but it could've used a bit more flavor for me. 
- Side greens: lightly dressed to make you feel a bit healthier while eating all the cheesy items 
- Outside patio: pretty crowded on sunny day 
- Inside: little sanctuary from bustling outside to carry on a conversation. Also near a bar with an old school character that I liked. We got a half booth table which is nice. 
- Lemonade: perfect for me--not too sweet or tart 
- Overall menu: French items you'd expect like crepes and quiche and coq a vin

Lowlights (my flip side to highlights): 
- Certainly not a healthy or light lunch ;-) I was super full and cheesed out and ready to take a super long nap after--if only I didn't have to go back to work. 

I'd come back for another heafty leisurely city lunch.
author: Eve K.

description: Cafe bastille went down for me. Price increased, quality doesn't compare to Cafe de la Presse anymore... They do have a terrasse, but it stopped being a good enough reason to go.
author: Lionel F.

description:
Dinner at Cafe Bastille + "Next to Normal" at the Curran Theater = Great great great night. 

High points of the night:

Goat Cheese Terrine:  Wonderful layers of flavor, along with balsamic marinated tomato bits went deliciously well with our warm bread. 

Coq au Vin and Beouf Bourguignon:  Refined rustic cooking FTW. 

Outdoor seating under the heat lamps really add to the experience of dining there and are perfectly comfortable even on a chilly night.  The hostesses greeting potential diners stand beyond the heat lamps and you really feel for the poor things as additional coats and gloves are added to their wardrobe as your meal progresses lol.

Desserts of Floating Island and Cognac Creme Brulee:  Longed for a bit more cognac flavor in the creme brulee but the meringue in the floating island was light, while the caramel sauce wasn't overly sweet.  Toasted almonds on top was a winner for the gf who's an almond lover. 

Parking:  Sucks like a bitch just like parking anywhere else in the city.  If you don't mind shelling out a few bucks, the St. Marys parking garage has a lower rate than most in the area and is located on Kearny between California and Pine, just a block away from Belden Place.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I will have to give it three stars. It does nit have a classy feeling/look. 
The thing I kind of don't like is the colourful things up on the walls. It feels like I'm in an American diner. Also sometimes it feel like it's German. 
BUT
The food ''Bœuf Bourguignon" il était magnifique!!
J'ai aimé la nourriture!! J'adore la soupe à l'oignon et la baguette :)
I prefer going to Café Claude which is near by but I am ok with this place.
the entrance for inside is very small and that bothered me a lot but next time i will seat outside. 
Also for the $30 thing they have it was not worth it at the end but the food is good once again. 
Will I come back? Yes
Merci! Je vais revenir bientôt
author: Nadav M.

description:
This is a great place for dessert and steak.  OMG, the chocolate mousse was so delicious and finished in 2 bites.  The steak was nice and juicy.  The bread is nice and warm, a great warmup for the main entree.  

However, the ravoli appetizer was just too cheesy.  They do give a large portion of the trout but sadly, the taste was too lemony.
author: Rose C.

description:
2 stars just for ambiance. I felt transported back to France, with outdoor dining in little cramped alleys. The setting was perfect for lunch on a warm, sunny day.

Onion soup was goood, with lots of bread and thick melted cheese on top. It's very filling though - I can usually eat a ton but was full after just the soup. I also ordered the croque monsieur which was tasty, too - the sauce on top (bechamel?) was relaly flavorful. Fries + aioli were a big hit with our table too.

We came at 1 and it was still pretty crowded, so try to make a reservation ahead of time to guarantee you'll get a table.
author: Lisa W.

description: Pre Fixed 3 course NYE dinner. It was good. Ahi Tuna salad, Filet Mignon was cooked perfectly and chocolate mouse cake or something for dessert. Service was good as well. Planning a return dinner back here.
author: mui d.

description:
To celebrate the eve of my third favorite day of the year (Bastille Day), my friend and I decided to go to Cafe Bastille for a French lunch on Belden Place.  Since we had a late lunch, the place was relatively empty so we had our choice of restaurants and places to sit.  Since we were going with the French theme, we decided on Cafe Bastille.  In my ever indecisive nature, I couldn't figure out what to order but ended up with the Hatchis Palmenter (sp?) which, when it arrived, I realized was essentially a shepherd's pie.  Don't get me wrong - who doesn't love mashed potatoes, ground beef and cheese?  But I probably should have gone with the croque monsieur - a little more French, and Cafe Bastille probably would have prepared it better.

My food was fine but not particularly interesting or flavorful, and it's a tad pricy for lunch.  The best thing about the place is the outdoor patio!
author: Wendy L.

description:
French food? Sure, I guess. In our table of four, no one had anything incredibly mouth watering. 

However, Cafe Bastille does have its perks:  Ambiance, romantic, on the cutest street in the city, and fair service. 

Its a great place if you're in good company, but don't come expecting to be romanced by the food.
author: Halley B.

description:
Did you know there is a French Quarter in San Francisco? And by "French Quarter" I mean one street packed with restaurants, mostly French, a few Italian. But - I digress. 

This was the perfect place to stop for dinner when we arrived hungry and too early to find most places open (4:30'ish). It's true that every other open restaurant on the street tried to lure us into their place with promises of good food & drink, but we chose Cafe Bastille because the waiter was friendly and nice, and they had a good menu on display. 

My boyfriend had the Hachis Parmentier (which is basically like a French Shepard's pie: ground beef, mashed potatoes, carrots & cheese served casserole style) and I had some kind of lamb sausage sandwich - both were served with perfectly crisped frites. We also had a glass of Pinot Noir and Beaujolais nouveua which accompanied our dinner well.

Overall, good tasty food, great service and decent prices meant that we chose well. I'd visit again - if I didn't think I needed to try at least a few other places on Belden.
author: Amie S.

description:
Came for lunch and sat outside - amazing weather that day, so LOVED the patio (five stars).

The food was good, nothing amazing, but good (I only had a sandwich - so it could be why I wasn't in awe).  The service was great and overall, had a good time.
author: Bill H.

description:
I was there recently for Valentine's day dinner and the experience was great.  We had reservations at 8pm, arrived 10 minutes late but were seated immediately.  It did take some time to get us water and bread so I knocked off one star for that glitch.  However the food made up for the wait.  I had the crab salad and it was delicious.  My filet mignon steak was also really good.  It tasted like butter in my mouth, it was so tender.  The dessert was a chocolate cake and it was awesome...not too sweet.  The Zinfindal wine that I had was also good.  The interior decor reminded me of the European restaurants in Spain and Italy.
I only wish the bread was served warm.  However, the dinner was great and pricing is awesome.   Don't listen to the Grouponers as this place has excellent pricing.  I was expecting to pay much more for Valentine's day dinner so I consider this place a bargain.  Belden Place is also a very cool place to take friends for dinner.  The crowded restaurants give it such a European flair and I love it.  Anybody who has gone to Italy and Spain will know the feel.  I will definitely come back again when I am in the area.
author: corey c.

description: Oh dear. A thin, soupy, watery version of the classic Beef Bourguignon complete with undercooked vegetables and dry lean beef swimming in an utterly tasteless and bland "broth". Have they run out of flour to make their roux (and time to cook their food, or even salt)? Perhaps they are attempting to reinterpret this dish as something lighter for dieters? Well it's not working, and why? They present themselves as a "classic" French bistro. This dish should be thick, rich, slow cooked, melt in your mouth unctuousness...If I could give negative stars I would. Avoid.
author: Anthony B.

description:
I had lunch at Cafe Bastille today with the co-workers.  I definitely recommend this place to you for a very pleasant lunch.

The Skinny:

Excellent price point for very fresh tasting food.  I ordered the Bastille Burger done medium-well and it was perfect.  Service is above average even when very busy.  Nice ambiance with a nice crowd.  Will definitely come back for dinner and more lunches.  I wanted so badly to have a glass of wine, but had to go back to work sans apertif.  We split the bill four ways on four credit cards and not even one bit of attitude from the staff.  Thank you, Cafe Bastille!

Improvements:

Offer me a refill on my drink before it's time to clear my plate.  Make sure to serve appetizer bread basket right away.

Overall:  Definitely check it out!
author: Sharan T.

description: We just stepped into Paris, this little Bistro transported us to a wonderful evening in true French style. It was a true rendition of what restaurants were meant to be. We spent am evening in a glorious dining pleasure, true to its French name. The bread, the appetizer, the mains were authentic. The time passed as we engaged in conversation. The staff were excellent. My wife had the pastise prawns and raved to the chef, and in a quant gesture they presented us with a wonderful fruit platter that overwhelmed us. We would love to go there every night if we could. It would be fun to get to know this establishment intimately.
author: Steve L.

description: The food was fabulous! Loved everything we got. I would have given it five stars if the waitress wasn't so "authentic" (read: snooty)! She had to ask what MY problem was when someone was smoking two tables away. It was a big deal for me to be so inconsiderate to their smoking problem!
author: Molly G.

description: I had the prix fixe dinner at Cafe Bastille last night--French Onion Soup, Steamed Moules and Raspberry Key Lime Mousse.  It was worst French meal I have had in a long time.  The soup was sweet, with not enough good cheese and sherry to offset the onions; the Moules broth was tasteless, except for garlic, and the accompanying fries were not as good as fast food joints; and the Mousse was soggy and also without taste.  The saving graces were the large servings, although I left more than half uneaten, and the baguette served at the beginning.  Service was fine.
author: Ashok K.

description:
One of my favorite lunch places in downtown.  Belden Alley, where this place is located, transforms into a European style restaurant district during lunch and the evening.  Umbrella tables, streamers of lights and lots of chatter.  Every restaurant has outdoor and indoor seating.  

The ambiance is great, and Cafe Bastille is no exception.  I always get good service, the food is authentic French cafe food.  My favorite is the Crepe Complete.  The French Onion soup better than most and recently I tried the croque monsieur for the first time, I loved it.  Cheaper French cafe food that is on par can be found at La Boulange Bakery two blocks away.  However Cafe Bastille offers a much more festive atmosphere.  So if it's just straight up food you want and are in a rush for lunch you can safe about 30% going elsewhere, but if you want a nice lunch, outside, in a festive environment (as Elaine would say "this, that and the other") then I highly recommend this place.  Also probably one of the cheaper restaurants in the alley.

Belden Alley, especially Cafe Bastille, feels like a micro-lunch-time-vacation, where I am wisped away to Europe for 45 minutes before returning to the artificially lit cubicle forest.  Never have nor would eat there for a solo lunch, there's really no point.  But if got company and want some fresh air, eat here.
author: Joe G.

description:
