Came with a groupon - fantastic value in a nice setting. App selection is mouth watering - French onion soup is the traditional fare you'd expect, with a delicious bread crust.
Mussles in white wine were noticably fresh. The frites were average - seemed frozen and oily, alas what I've come to expect.
Beef bourguignon was a little tasteless, although the beef was melt-in-the-mouth good. 
Well worth a visit, would love to try more of the menu
author: Cian C.

description:
Sunny afternoon - everyone is out in their power suits, starched shirts and Chanel glasses.  When you got all that going on - only place to take it is to Belden.  

So that's what we did as well.  And we picked Cafe Bastille.  We got there at 12:15 and had the pick of almost any table outside which was great.  Sat down, perused the menu.  I wanted the "Tuesday Special" of Boeuf Bourguignon.  However, rather than the soup or house salad that I could order with it - I wanted a caesar.  

Nope.  I was told.
Um, okay - I'm happy to pay extra.
Nope.  You have to order them separate.
Um, okay.  So what should have been a $16.00 lunch for me, now went up to $24.00.  Okay - that offers NO flexibility whatsoever on their part.  Not Cool!

The BB was awesome, I have to say.  The soupy sauce was fantastic - full of flavor.  The meet was tender and not too stringy/chewy like some BB I have had in the past.  The caesar, however, very plain.  Way too much creamy dressing on it.  They also served bread to the table, but didn't eat any so I can' comment on it.

Also ordered the fries as an appetizer.  The fries were 4 stars, for sure.  Super hot, crunchy in all of the right places.  

Dining companion had the Salad with Grilled Chicken as a lunch entree and really enjoyed it.  

SERVICE BLOWS AT BASTILLE.  There, I said it.  No one came and asked us if we wanted refills on our drinks.  NO ONE ever, not once, stopped by to see if we liked our meals.  Or could they get us anything.  I mean, c'mon - we know the world cup is going on, but can't you tear away from the T.V. inside the restaurant just a smidge to check in with us?
author: Jason I.

description:
Why would you ever serve steak tartare as an entree, It was DISGUSTING.. I felt like I was being served dog food - AND I normally love steak tarare!! I do, promise.. just not served in a big mound!..

It was way too overwhelming. I need a serious break from Cafe Bastille.. This makes me sad. 

woof woof
author: Monica S.

description:
Blood sausage, mashed potatoes, and poached/caramelized apple ($14). Sounds good doesn't it? This was a delicious meal, but didn't hit the spot for me, hence the 3. Let me elaborate.

For starters we ordered crab cakes ($12). I heard they were good here from you guys. But...um...Though I appreciate their new take on crab cakes in the shape of crab croquettes or crab balls (maybe this is super French and I just don't know) this was very unexpected. The crab cake was only okay. It tasted fresh enough, and Amy remarked that she could really taste the crab. But I'd prefer to taste the crab with more herb flavoring (thyme for example) and did not. The crab cakes also came out with a smokey remoulade (sp), which was delicious, and a fennel salad, which was far too citrus-y for me.

Originally coming here for Dine About Town (DAT) the DAT menu stank compared to the menu itself. The menu's cheapest item is a crepe ($11), and most expensive item is steak (I forget, ~$30). I wanted something in-between. I chose the blood sausage since I never tried it before. It was crumbly, tender, OK. It tasted like meat yes... It was characteristically dark yes...But it was not "omg delicious!" The mashed potato-blood sausage-caramelized apple combo was pretty good, but after a couple of bites, flavors dulled. I much preferred Amy's dish, which was practically shepherd's pie (just made with ground beef instead of lamb). It was cheesy, hearty, and delish. Jen's crepe with ratatouille was surprisingly hearty and filling as well! My single taste left me with a good impression. It only cost $11. If I had to hand out a recommendation however, I would recommend ordering the shepherd's pie.

Notes:
**They also offer pate, but their pate is not homemade as we found out. Boo to that. Get it at a specialty grocery store yourself.

Setting reminds me of NYC's Little Italy, except rather than all of the hosts being male (NYC), they're female (SF). Interesting difference... Moreover, everyone is bunched together in a tight space with both indoor and outdoor setting. Servers are zooming in and out, pouring water, collecting dishes. Everywhere outside of your meal is controlled mayhem! I personally prefer more space between tables (the table next to us was def eavesdropping!), but they don't go for "space" in an alley. 

The dessert menu was "eh." There is definitely room for improvement in that department. But that is just my take on it.
author: Sarah W.

description:
3- stars.  The service and atmosphere was good, but food was ok.  The dishes were not up to SF restaurants standards.  Price was high for quality and quantity.   Probably wouldn't go there again.  

P.S. Can't figure out why Yelp reviews were so high
author: Al G.

description:
I think this place is resting on its laurels.

the frisee salad, billed with lardons, came with undercooked bacon. i know it doesn't seem like a big deal, but i had recently had the same salad at a small place in NYC, and the lardons made the salad.

my sister had a very good mushroom crepe, followed by average moules (mussels).  my onion soup was ok.
author: Colleen C.

description:
This place had been on our list for over a year, we finally made it there Tues. night.
We chose to sit outside since it was a nice night. At the beginning, service was a little slow. Although, once we got our water and bread, (which was way too good) it seemed to pick up.
Our server kept our glasses refilled, and our plates cleared.
I had the escargots, which was delish! 
For my entree, i had the special. It was pan roasted halibut with carrots and potatoes. It also came with a tomato-lemon sauce, which i asked for on the side.
Everything was cooked well, and had good flavor.
We split a crepe for dessert, (mostly because we wanted to try one somewhere besides the farmers market.)
It was ok, but nothing special.
They have a VERY extensive wine list, and some great martinis too.

Much better than the over-hyped Plouf!
author: Amanda G.

description: We enjoyed the atmosphere which is quite charming and authentic as well as our entrees.  The mussels in particular were amazing.  The french onion soup was just sad -- come on guys this is a French place.  How disappointing.  Service was also poor -- I don't mind slow dinner service in the true french style, but they should at least greet us and bring us water or bread while we wait.  Overall, fairly enjoyable dinner, may be back if we are in the area.
author: Chris F.

description:
The things I like about Cafe Bastille based on three visits.

Location  
Located in an alley way that reminds me very much of the Notre Dame district in Paris.  Walking down the path having people ask me if I've selected a place to eat already.  Why, yes, I have, I'm going to Cafe Bastille.  

The Food  
I'm particularly fond of the muscles there (the one in the bacon and creme sauce of course).  It's a good staple for me after a long day of dealing with graduate students and the clinically insane.  One night, I also had the bone marrow (to die for).  For desert, if you're a fan, i recommend the Creme Brulee. A m a z i n g.  

The Service, etc.  
Every time I've gone, my friends and I are greeted with that kind of warmth that makes you feel you're going to be well taken care of.  The decor is cute.  I like that they have a downstairs section.  I may even have my birthday party there.  The staff is attentive, especially the waiter I seem to get every time I go there, Anton.  My friends even make it a point to tell me that they thoroughly enjoy the service when they go there at other times as well.  

I gave it five stars for the complete experience of the night.  My friends and I always arrive happy, and leave delighted and full.  There's no question whether I'll be back or not, the only question is how am I going to find a way to afford to eat there as often as I do being a student and all.
author: Nht N.

description: I've been here twice, once for brunch once for lunch. Both times completely satisfied with great food & service. Great wine & Mimosas. The waitress overheard us saying it was my birthday, so she brought me a free slice of cake w/a candle! Love the vibe of Belden Place as well.
author: Lacey R.

description: Decided to go against the 3.5 star reviews here on yelp and go for it! I had heard of the few restaurants down this little alley way and decided to try it finally. First off, it was easy to find... second... it wasnt at all crowded on a saturday evening... thirdy it had a great vibe! The service was great the food was delicious and all in all not bad for the price. There are way more pretentious and over priced places in SF than this place. I took off one star because of my drink request. I ordered hennessy and in the glass came some crown royal... disgusting. For a french place I expected better selection from the bar. Great otherwise!
author: Anthony M.

description: It's good, very predictable cafe experience. Not excellent, but not bad. You won't be disappointed nor overwhelmed with excitement. It did feel like you were out of the city and that alone makes me want to return.
author: John R.

description:
more like 1.5 cuz i've definitely experienced better. and i will never go back.

the ONLY good thing about here was that it felt like i was in europe having this meal. andddd that's about it. 

the service was SLOW. the only guy that was memorable was the busboy who checked up on us. he's probably the only person i would have smiled at the whole time i was there. our waiter NEVER came to check on us. we ordered, and that was it. i don't care if you're from france or whatever. i think we told the busboy that we wanted to order, wanted some bread, and wanted our check.

the food... was whatever. seriously... i don't get the great reviews from some. i had the french onion soup, boyfriend had the lamb mergyez and eggs, and friend had a salad. our friend enjoyed the salad... but... unless you're using rotten products, you can't really mess this up. the merguez was a bit of a disappointment for how expensive it was... seriously? 2 links of sausage and eggs. and then my french onion soup was just WATER. it was LOTS of bread... and water. 

oh and the mojito i ordered was more like lime juice. i never ask to redo a drink and i had to. it was just too sour. 

im sorry, san francisco. i did not like this place.
author: Christine N.

description:
Location: Belden Place
Ambiance: vintage-y Paris?
Crowd: FiDi busybees at lunch
YUM: Croque Madame. Ham and cheese squished between light bread covered in cheese with a fried egg (lightly dressed salad on the side) Are you salivating yet??
Bottoms Up: just water
Service: friendly and accommodating
Notes: This is a great lunch spot in the FiDi. I really loved my croque madame! My coworkers had the beet napoleon and bone marrow which also looked good. Why the missing star? The place is kinda dirty (especially for the location and the price of the food)!

Eat it. Like it. Repeat.
author: Jenna s.

description:
Ambiance: 4 stars
Food: 2.5 stars
Service: 2 stars

Based on the small sample we had for lunch today the food was just mediocre or so so at best compared to other French restaurants in SF, they were fortunate to score a sweet spot in the alley to generate business from the fidi folks and tourists. 

Here's what we ordered:
- Steamed mussels with garlic, shallots and white wine and pomme frites. I was expecting my frites to be thin, long string potatoes with a dash of parsley for presentation. Nope, none of that! They were burger size fries! 
- Steamed salmon, spinach, roasted fingerling potatoes in a garlic sauce. The salmon was slightly overdone and nothing exciting! I could of made this fish with better results at home!
-Burger with swiss cheese- the cheese didn't even slightly melt on the meat! 
-Croque Madame  "Croque Monsieur with Fried Egg"- This was the worst croque style sandwich I ever had. The bread was mushy, soft, drenched in cheese and butter glob! uhh, that sounds gross! Yeah, it wasn't that good, maybe the chef was just having a bad day! 
-Bread was stale

Staffs- very inattentive! Granted that it was super busy at 12:50pm, it felt like our staff's mind was all over the place. While we were waiting, I saw a couple with a menu leaving a table, that's a sign! Then we were seated at exactly the SAME TABLE!! haha..., they didn't even notice customers left! Once seated, no one came over to offer us water, bread, introduce themselves. When someone did come over, he told us the special and NEVER came back! He just kind of forgot about us. 20 mins, later when the crowd died down, another waiter came over to take our order and I actually had to ASK HIM if we can get some water! Geez!!
author: Leeseuh K.

description: Les crêpes comme en France!
author: Khaloud D.

description: Great little local find. Prices are reasonable, atmosphere is casual, food was outstanding!!!!
author: Liz S.

description:
I first went to Cafe Bastille in 1990, the year it opened, and I've been a big fan ever since. It's not the coziest and I don't care for sitting downstairs or even even outside (except for those rare warm SF evenings), but the place still works. It's been pretty much the same the last 20 years and is probably the most authentic French cafe in this country, even down to the wait staff (although I've noticed a few "foreigners" , i.e. non-French, waiting on me lately). For years, the menu barely changed but in the last few there have been tweaking going on. For crepes, they are the best. My friend always orders the croque madam, always top notch. However, the most popular item for years, the chocolate mousse with orange peel shavings in it, was taken off the list a few years ago. Mon dieu! 

I'd give it four stars, but they need to re-do the interior a little, especially the downstairs, and bring back the mousse before I give it to them.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Sex on the Beach. Currant and Citron Vodka, Raspberry Coulis, and Orange and Lemon Juice. It was quite strong, so you get your money's worth.

Bread & Butter. Their bread was bombbb! Love French restaurants with their nommy bread!

Duck Leg Confit. With Baby Spinach Salad and Roasted Potatoes. The duck was pretty bomb! The meat fell off the bone pretty much and the potatoes were delicious. I think they added rosemary to it because it was really fragrant and delish. 

Coq Au Vin. Butter Noodles, Chicken braised in Red Wine, Pearl Onions, Bacon, and Mushrooms. My friends ordered this so I only got to try the chicken but it was really good. Definitely recommended! The chicken was nice and soft, not the least bit dry or chewy! 

Floating Island. Almond Meringue in Vanilla Sauce. This was pretty good. I liked it especially because after attempting to make meringue I now know how difficult it is. It was really soft and delicious. And not something you get a chance to eat all the time. NOMS!

The service was really good and the food was noms, plus our server was pretty cute so that's a plus too.
author: Constance C.

description:
Ambience 5 stars - euro alleyway outdoor bistro action
Staff 5 stars
Frenchiness 5 stars (in a good way)
Food 4 stars
Value 5 stars - try the 3 course meal with unlimited wine 45 bucks!
author: g w.

description:
Came here for my birthday with a large group of 15, (and they let us reserve a much higher number, earlier; this is hard to do in SF on a Saturday!!)  There was a fun jazz trio/quartet when we arrived that played the Mario Bros theme; hurrah!
We had the entire room to ourselves, the service was perfectly attentive & non-intrusive.  He was fast, kept things straight, and yet had a fun sense of humor, and we would've loved him to join us... we got the same warm feeling from the owner.  We shut the place down, ordered everything on the appetizer menu before our entrees, and no-one fainted from the bill.

However, the most important part was... (and I expected good food, but not spectacularity); this turned out to be the best steak I've had in three years!  it was the special fillet mignon, and it was **perfect***.  I also totally loved the herring appetizer, the floating island desert, the mussels were great, the leek soup was divine, the fois gras was yummie, wine selections great....

Thank you soooo much, Bastille!
author: Amber S.

description:
I took a date here on a friend's recommendation. First off, it's reasonably priced with average portion size (despite unnecessarily large plates/bowls). We had a delicious salad with a deep fried poached egg as an appetizer. The egg was poached perfectly with a light, crisp exterior. We had the Pasti Prawns and the Boeuf Bourguinon. The prawns were delicious and the bourguinon was incredibly tender. We also had a chocolate pear tart which tasted as decadent as it sounded.

Drinks! Cafe Bastille has a large selection of beer, liquor, and wine. We chose to go with the cocktails. I had the Speedy Gonzales which was very tasty! Despite made with tequila, it tasted surprisingly similar to a mojito. We also had a Le Parisien which was perfectly sweet while still feeling light.

Service was great- our server checked in on us regularly, was patient, and answered every question we had about the menu. The servers and staff were all extremely polite and helpful. We ended up staying about 25 minutes past closing, but they never interrupted us or hinted for us to leave.

My only negative critique would be the volume. Although having a fair amount of indoor space, the way the restaurant is laid out forces every table to be very close to each other (6 inches apart). As a result, even if it's just you and another group, it becomes difficult to hear each other without a lot of effort and leaning.
author: Alvin L.

description:
Meh. When you dine here, what you're really paying for is the ambiance of Belden place.

We ordered the escargots, lapin, nicoise, and a bottle of pinot noir. None really disappointed, but having been spoiled by SF standards (and I especially love French food) I have to say it was a little mediocre. Also, the service was not great, and for some reason the waiter brought us the budget pinot noir, despite the fact we asked for a different one. 

Not bad, but I've had better.
author: Kari G.

description: I liked the ambience however as soon as I walked in it smelled like rotting fruit. Food was good but prob won't return
author: Diane F.

description:
I went down to Belden Place on my lunch break today, never been down here. Someone had recommended that I should try it out  during the World Cup. He was right! Its so much fun. So we got to see some of the Brazil game and the antics that go on between the servers from the different restaurants in this lane. All of the restaurants are "representing" different European countries so the rivalries are there. I recommend experiencing it first hand. 
We had a great experience at Cafe Bastille. The waiter was hilarious and the food was delicious. They made me a Croque Monsieur without the meat, so I guess thats just a grilled cheese, right? Go for the atmosphere and the soccer. Of course I didn't want to come back to work, which is what I should be doing now......
author: lilly s.

description:
the cafe is located in a small, quaint alley that transports you to europe with it's outdoor seating, strewn lights, close quarters, and european fare. we sat inside and had the entire downstairs to ourselves. the restaurant is quiet and dimly lit, definitely offering a romantic ambiance.

our waitress was french and had the "i dont give a fuck" parisian air to her. i agree wit a previous yelper that the busboy did most of the work and was much more pleasant.

i ordered the french onion soup ($7.95). while the gruyere on top was melty, silky, and divine, the actual soup was rather bland. though, they have good fries.

i probably won't be back because i think there's better french food to be had elsewhere; the draw for this place is ambiance---but you cant eat ambiance, homie.
author: Melissa N.

description:
I went to Cafe Bastille on a Monday afternoon for lunch with a bunch of French friends. For some of you that think it is "cliché" than French people gather together to speak French in a French restaurant that is own by French people I stop you right there. This is not "cliché" :-) The food is good here and their special sounds yummy for anyone that would like to try to some authentic French dishes.

Cafe Bastille is one of those perfect spot by a sunny work week day in the Financial District. You can take a seat on their outside terrace and enjoy great food. They do have seating inside but I won't recommend them for lunch.

Please be warned that this place is busy and we had to wait about 15-20 minutes to get a table for 6. 15 minutes usually is not a lot, but during weekday when you don't want to spend too much time outside of the office it still 15 minutes ;)

We got our table and then quickly order. They did have a great special every day. This monday was rabbit stew. A friend of mine try it and apparently it was very good. (Not easy aparently to get rabbit in the city). On my side I tried their Croque Madame (that is a Croque Monsieur with a friend egg) and I was really good. The dish came with a bit of green as a side in order to balance it a little bit ;).

The place was a bit noisy but since they are sharing a narrow street with other cafe this is something you can definitely avoid. Especially if you are outside.

To conclude, I went to Cafe Bastille only once but I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a great spot during the week and that like French food and atmosphere.

==============================

Pros:
- Having French food for lunch by a sunny day in the Financial District... what else?
- A different special everyday! Monday was Rabbit stew, tuesday was boeuf bourguignon (Yum!), Wednesday was Coq au vin, Thursday was steak tartare and Friday was Choucroute.

Cons:
- Appart from our wait (which can have been awaited by taking a reservation) everything was good.

Cedric's secret advice:
 - best time of the day to go there and avoid the crowd? During weekdays, after 1pm if you can afford it.
author: Cedric L.

description:
3.5 stars 

Came here this week and had their salmon with ratatouille. 
food, really delicious and flavorful, large portion 4stars

Service was attentive and friendly,4 stars

Ambience was ok, we were seated deep inside and the bathroom was a flighty trek down and really dark (not romantically dim btw). 3 stars
author: Amy S.

description:
Went with a group of six people. We made reservations and saw three tables outside placed side-by-side and asked if we could sit there. The waiter told us the table, clearly for six, was for 10 people and that if we wanted to sit outside, we had to specifically request it on our reservation. 

I made the reservation through Yelp and there is no comment box where I can specifically request to sit outside. Instead of apologizing, the waiter was arguing with me and even told me to come to his computer to show me how I should have made my reservation. Instead of walking over to his computer we walked to the Spanish Tapas place near the Pine Street entrance. It turned out to be a lovely lunch and we were seated outside on three tables placed side-by-side. Exactly what I had wanted from the beginning. :)
author: Julie Z.

description:
I'd have to say, my bf was very upset with our experience here. As for me, I'm more easy going but it was disappointing to say the least. 
They messed up my order multiple times and did not pay attention to details.  I ordered well done but it came rare (i don't like eating raw meat), so i sent it back immediately to be redone.  When it came back to my table, the portion was reduced to half of the original and it was just medium and not well done as specified. 
I was afraid if i sent it back again, it would've gotten even smaller so i just traded with my boyfriend.  It was disappointing for the outrageous amount of money we spent there.  I will never be back again.  That's all  I'm saying, it just isn't worth it.
author: Tu L.

description: It seems that over the course of few years, the quality of food isn't where it should be. Service is good but other than breakfast, both lunch and dinner needs refinement. I can pretty much say I had almost everything on the menu over frequent visits because it's near my work. I wish the back of the house puts more attention to detail when it comes to freshness.
author: H.Y. K.

description: This place was a treasure of a find while visiting San Francisco! The absolute best gnocchi I've ever had, authentic French style cafe au lait, and a great European alley atmosphere.
author: Sherry K.

description:
I recently came to Cafe Bastille for my birthday dinner. I made a reservation for 12 and that evening, my sisters and a few of my friends arrived first and were seated at the table... which was on the patio. While making the reservation, I assumed that with such a large party and a large indoor dining area that we would be seated inside; however, I was wrong. I guess that's why people say that assuming makes an ass out of you AND me. If you're wondering if there were heaters, yes, there was ONE heater directed at our table which was sufficient for the first four members of my party, but as for the rest of us, we used our napkins as blankets. The pavement was extremely uneven causing the tables to be slanted. Not only that, but I felt like I was sitting on a rocking chair - that was a problem, particularly because I was in pumps. The restaurant was supposed to non-smoking, but we kept smelling smoke from the servers who were taking smoke breaks... I guess "non-smoking" must only apply to the inside of the restaurant. Anyway, that was strike 1.

Now, for the food. The server brought us bread and butter, and the bread was cold and rock hard. The other tables in my party had softer bread, so we ended up stealing their bread until our food was brought out. For my entree, I ordered the lamb chop and to say the least, I left the restaurant dissatisfied and hungry. When the dish was brought out, it didn't look or smell too appealing. I learned that you should never judge a plate by its cover, so with that in mind, I cut into it and wish I had gone with my first instinct. The fennel on the plate was larger than the actual lamb chops, and there were so many green beans that it looked like it should have been the main course rather than the side. Both lamb chops were extremely chewy, dry, and gamey. The green beans were slathered in oil, and after taking a bite, I had a layer of oil on my lips. Needless to say, I was quick to toss the dish aside - Strike 2.

Four of the people in my party ordered the Coq au Vin because I've had the dish at other restaurants and it has never failed me. Unfortunately, I was again, wrong. The dish came out with fettucini noodles when the menu stated it would be served with egg noodles which I found odd. Anyway, the chicken itself was dry and the sauce did not help that issue. The only good thing from that dish was probably the mushrooms, which is sad.

The service was also mediocre. The server kept reaching over my head and running into my chair which resulted in the two hind legs of my chair being lifted off the pavement and me bumping into the table.. constantly. I mean yes, I'm a petite girl, but reaching over my head without a saying "Excuse me" was just completely rude. Oh and my friend who ordered the mussels and bottomless french fries requested a second basket of french fries which came out AFTER the bill had already been given to us... um, okay? I guess we should be happy they still gave them to us. This was strike 3.

The vast majority of my party drove from San Jose and had never tried French cuisine before, so it was unfortunate that this was their first experience. I was already pretty embarrassed when I discovered that we were sitting outside on an uneven pavement when we were expecting a nice restaurant so needless to say, I was even more embarrassed when they described the food as "interesting" and left dissatisfied. So, as they all say, 3 strikes and you're out!
author: Kim P.

description: We sat outside on a fairly warm day which is most always pleasant at Belden Place; I ordered a nicoise salad which is a favorite of mine. The tuna was seared and the salad was very good overall, but the dressing was just a little too thick in my opinion. I tried my friend's mussels which were also good. I'd visit again!
author: Natalie M.

description: Bottomless Mimosas are always a good idea. They use decent/good champagne too. Vegetable sandwich with Goat cheese was decent as well. Price was justified considering we (party of 2) had 2 pitchers of Mimosa with meal at $11
author: Rick S.

description: Had an amazing Beef Bourguignon here the other evening.  It was better than the one I make and mine gets raves always.    Haven't been to Belden Place in a quite a while, and I was reminded that it's a very european feeling place to dine.  Quite charming even on a cold San Francisco night. Will be back
author: Barbara M.

description: Not the greatest, but it gets the job done when you're craving a quick French fix. Do love the outdoor seating, though!
author: Brad Y.

description:
Got their special filet minon. I got it medium, but felt like they cooked it a little longer than I would have liked. I forget what mushrooms came with it, but those mushrooms in the pork sauce were my favorite part!! crazy right??

Also got the coq-au-vin and the chicken fell right off the bone! I liked it a lot cause it was soup based and it was a good day for soup since it was chilly and windy out.

Oh and also got their french onion soup. Tasted like any other good french onion soup nothing special, but it wasn't bad either.

The service was excellent, even got them to take a picture for us. They came around fairly often to make sure we were ok. We also even took a while to order and they were patient with us.

Ambiance was very nice, but the noise level was a little more on the quieter side for me, so I almost had to whisper most of the time. It might have been more so because the tables were really close together so you couldn't really have a private conversation.

So overall rating:
Food: 4 stars (for mushroom with pork sauce), but unfortunately the other stuff was only about 3.2 stars (because it was only a little above average)
Service: 4.2 stars
Ambiance: 3 stars
Parking: 3.5 stars (above average for SF since it was really close to a parking garage)

Averages out to around 3.4, so rounding down to 3.
author: Sean L.

description: HORRIBLE SERVICE! Mid way to our meal our waitress just grabbed her purse and walked out without letting us know that we will be taken care of by another wait staff. I sat with my friend and chit chatted for quite some time before I noticed that we were not once asked by another waitress waiting on the tables near by if we needed anything, when I flagged down one of the other waitresses she walked over and asked us in a very rude tone if we were done, slammed our check on the table and walked away. The food was not half bad...the shrimp and avocado appetizer and the goat cheese pepper rolls were good. The chicken sandwich was pretty bland though. Cute outdoor seating, very reminiscent of a cafe in Paris. However, with service that bad I don't think i'll ever go back...
author: Nairy P.

description: We ate here for lunch several time, because this place is accessible, not too fancy, but good for quick lunch. I am ok with carpaccio and modules et frites, but don't like steak tartare.
author: A J.

description:
This review is for their WEEKEND BRUNCH.

Overall: weekend brunch options are limited in the Financial District, so with that as context, I'd say this is a pretty darn good choice--especially if you don't want to go to a hotel.

Food: solid.  I had the EGGS BASTILLE (their take on eggs benedict), and it was good.  The plate had a good variety to make a complete meal: grilled potatoes, salad, fruit.  The cafe au lait was a bit watery, but still good.

Service: a bit slow, but nothing to complain about.  Weekend lunch is kind of quiet in Belden Lane, so they probably can't afford to staff up too much.

Decor:  you get the morning-after, hangover version of Belden Lane, instead of its usual European charm.  The area does feel a bit forlorn, but Cafe Bastille itself has a good crowd, given it's one of the few places open on Belden Lane for weekend lunch.
author: Izzy C.

description:
I visited Cafe' Bastille for a business lunch and liked it so much that I found myself going back three more times within the same 10-day period, either with friends or out-of-towners and another business lunch. 

The food is really good and the portions are decent. The rabbit is my favorite item on the menu, but I also tasted lots of dishes that were ordered at my table and liked everything. Everybody dining with me at this restaurant was also very satisfied with the food, from appetizers to dessert - these were my husband, clients, out-of-towners, all people of different ages and backgrounds. Some of the highlights, aside from the rabbit, were: the pate', the steak, the fish, and... the desserts, which were amazing and big enough to split (even though we got one each). 

The atmosphere is very European. When the weather is not too cold outside, it is nice and fun to dine outside, making it an European-like experience in the heart of San Francisco! I never sat in the dining room downstairs, only in the main room upstairs during lunch and in the outside patio during both lunch and dinner. At night they have stings of lights over the tables, which make atmosphere, and they have heaters. 

I would highly recommend trying Cafe Bastille for both the food and the atmosphere!
author: OcchiDiGatto S.

description:
It's stunning that some people on here are complimenting the food.  This was the worst French food I've ever had in my life.  The escargot was a greasy, oily mess.  The mussels weren't fresh and the broth lacked any flavor other than "butter".  And the steak dish was poorest quality cut of meat that I've ever been served at a restaurant- chewy with tons of fat that simply fell apart.

Embarrassing.
author: Mike B.

description:
I came here for lunch this past Friday with a some coworkers as we were the only ones in the office that day so the partner decided to do a office lunch. SCORE! Since the other restaurants next door were either packed or required us to sit outside which we did not approve of we came knocking on the door of Cafe Bastille.

We got seated in a hidden corner of the restaurant. It was such a tight spot that the hostess had to pull the table out allow us to sit and push the table back...um CLAUSTROPHOBIA?!?!

An Asian waiter soon came speaking something in French gibberish. We ordered our food 3 Madame Monsieur and the Quiche of the day (blue cheese & ham). I had the Quiche. The bread came cold, nothing special. The food took a while. Everything looked delicious. The Madame came with only salad whereas the Quiche had fries and salad. Although we thought the Madame also came with fries. My Quiche was decent very blue cheesy, I love cheese don't get me wrong by the cheese was too pungent for my taste. I still scarfed it down, don't waste food!

My coworkers thoroughly enjoyed their Madam Monsieur even though the contents would probably require a triple bypass shortly after-- it looked amazing. 

The service was exceptionally slow (we blame it on the European) we waited probably 20 minutes for our food and another 15 minutes for the bill to come even though we flagged down our waiter. When you're in a rush to get back to the office, this is a big no no.

Overall the food was decent but I've had better, cue Cafe Claude. The service is not so hot..."Meh...I've experienced better"
author: Myron J.

description:
I love the Hachis Parmentier.  Best I've had outside of France.  I love sitting outside on a nice day.
Came here for a big group and they did an amazing job.  We had the entire restaurant reserved.  The service was excellent.
author: Karen C.

description:
I left satisfied at Cafe Bastille. 

A bunch of us went here on New Year's Eve, and had a fantastic time. 

We had reservations at 7, and arrived at 6:55 and were seated immediately. The cafe was even nice enough to accommodate an extra guest, to make our party of 6 one of 7. 

They had a prix fix menu available for NYE, it looked good, but I was not in the mood for what they were offering. Instead, the whole group split some appetizers. We ordered the some tuna tartar, Pâté sampler, and  a goat cheese dish. All were delectable.

For entrees, there were a multitude of options. I opted for the braised rabbit with mustard sauce. It was a perfect amount, and the mustard sauce was exotic. 

Throughout the night we had many drinks and fine French wine, which paired well with our appetizers and main dished. 

All in all, I'd say everything was on point that night, except my lack of any pronunciation skills of the French language!
author: Cameron B.

description: First time at this restaurant last night.  We love Belden Ally and go there regularly, but first time at Cafe Bastille.  And we will be back.  Wife and I each had one of the 3-course meal option.  Salad and onion soup were both very good.  Entree were likewise, especially the mussels.  Very good deserts.  Bill was a little higher in the end than we expected, especially the 4% SF health tax.  That percentage seems higher than normal, but maybe I just haven't paid enough attention to other places.  Our server was very attentive.  As mentioned, will definitely be back again.
author: Brad L.

description:
Cafe Bastille is rolling the 2 star review.  Sorry to say it, but tonight was not just underwhelming...it was bad.  And I don't take any joy in writing that since we have enjoyed this place many times in the past.  In fact, when we get those rare days where it's going to be nice in the evening in SF we nearly always go here.  Not anymore.  The details:

Appetizer: Mussels...not great.   The sauce was bland.
Bread: OK, but closer to the stale side (good for sauce dipping though) than the "good" side.
Steak Fritte: Not good.  The meat itself had almost no taste and was tougher than it should have been.
Duck confit: Pretty good actually.  Very small piece of duck, but in terms of the finish...it was pretty good.  The swiss chard side was very good.

Service: They were pretty busy, but the service quality was not reflective of their business.  A quick example was ordering sauce on the side and having it served on the steak.  I like a lot of water...so on the positive side...the guy bringing the water was awesome and kept my glass full.

Good wines as well...

All in, Cafe Bastille will not be on our "nice weather in the evening in SF" list anymore.  We've been there a bunch so perhaps the universe is just sending us to a new restaurant.
author: Matt B.

description: I will say the Groupon just like the other yelper is a complete RIP OFF.  This definitely will be the last Groupon to a restaurant I will be purchasing.  What i've noticed is that restaurants that are either new (and you don't know how the food is) or bad (the food is just not good so that's why there are no customers) post on groupon.  This one is definitely the later.  The food is not good here.  The salad was just weird with pickles and olives and spring mix with vingerette.  It was very BLAH and the food was just atrocious.  I got the chicken with some weird water downed tomato mix with the sauce drowning the couscous.  It was weird and dry and just not good.  The desert took nearly 20minutes for it to come out.  We got charged the groupon $45 with a tax bill of $34 and some mandatory taxes from SF.  Paid $40+45 ish total=85ish, wow completely ripped off and Definitely NOT COMING back!
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description:
I love Belden Alley and Cafe Bastille is definately one of the rockstars.  A glass of French champagne to go with a divine trio of seared scallops on a bed of mashed potatoes in a lobster cognac sauce was a match made in heaven - one of my all time favorite combinations.  Next came the Mahi Mahi in a champagne hollandaise sauce paired with a glass of French Pinot Gris - both were very good but the wine was better than the fish.  And to top off our meal, an espresso with their sinfully delicious flourless chocolate torte.  The staff was attentive, efficient, and knew when to back off to let us enjoy.  

A warm night, an outdoor table with the city lights above us, and this fantastic dinner.  A votre sante
author: Sara M.

description: Leave this place to the tourists. Too bad, this place used to serve pretty good food.
author: Charles S.

description:
I have a friend that loves coming to this place for his birthday and with a group of 15-20 people this place SUCKS! I would absolutely NOT recommend coming here if you are more than 4 people as they know the tip is built in and the service becomes deplorable.... having said that, the food is delicious.

I have been to many french restaurants in NY and what separates them from Cafe Bastille is that their menu constantly changes, where, here, its the same thing everytime you go.

the escargot is simply divine.. rich and full of flavor and butter, its comes in a dish that makes sopping up all the buttery goodness with bread really easy.

the service is slow, the wait staff are rude, but the food is really good.. this place is pretty pricey, but French food tends to be that way and just like sushi, as long as you know that going in, you should be fine.
author: Edibleocea N.

description:
After my trip to Cafe Bastille, I am convinced that Beldon Place is officially a tourist trap.  

Cold and improperly cooked food, neglectful service.... just like every European tourist trap I have ever been in.
author: David A.

description:
I am giving this spot 3 stars. 5 from my first visit, and 1 from my most recent experience in December, when there was clearly a different staff.

FOOD:
The food options were fine both times. We were a group of at least 12 each time and elected to do the prix fixe menu - $46.95 for a 3 course menu with unlimited house wine. I love the french onion soup, moules (mussels) with white wine sauce, and the poulet au cidre (braised chicken with pearl onions). I must warn you though - their house wine is strictly limited to chardonnay and shiraz and while it is constantly flowing, it is either poor quality or watered down or both, because after many rounds, we were sober. 

AMBIANCE:
Charming, and classier than the other joints on Belden Lane. Affordable French, and louder, so good for lively groups. I like sitting on the patio, but that gets claimed early on, so get there on time, or specify it when making the reservation. 

SERVICE:
There was definitely a stark contrast between our experience the first time - giving us reason to come back for dinner this time around and this past Friday. I don't know if it was a brand new group of servers and managers but it was a joke. Normally, most restaurants staff their A team on a Friday night because of the dinner rush and we arrived beyond the dinner rush (at 8:30pm) and it was not crowded. Our group was comprised of the most laidback people I know, and it was a common sentiment experience across the board. For starters, we requested the patio, and the hostess conveniently left it off the reservation notes, and they weren't very accommodating about it. There was tons of confusion and our group of 15 was definitely not their first priority. We were seated downstairs, but that resulted in being ignored for the first 15 minutes. Drinks took forever, the server was rude and not flexible on anything, and definitely did not know how to explain menu offerings. She also didn't let us know what was available/not for the evening. C'mon lady - the menu is not THAT large. 

OVERALL:
There were many periods of delay and the service was not a smooth one. Getting up to run upstairs to ask for refills is not how I wanted to spend my dinner. And the rudeness throughout our meal will give me reason to really think twice before returning. Pricing was fair (but I think it went up recently) for the amount we drank, but the quality was subpar. This was my best friend's birthday dinner with family members that traveled long distances to come celebrate, and I wish I had chosen another restaurant.
author: Tammy H.

description:
My high regard for Cafe Bastille has been reconfirmed, yet again. It is a place I've always enjoyed dining at since the days when it was the only restaurant in the alley. 

It has authentic cuisine, a unique atmosphere, good service, but what they offer, that no one else comes close to, is an energy that takes you back to France and memories of bistro dining. 

Highlights of my recent visit are the foie gras, crab cakes, salade frisée, and soupe à l'oignon. All delicious with excellent presentation. I am happy to see that they are offering prix fixe menus daily now and not just on Bastille Day. Their prix fixe lunch even includes a drink. Speaking of drinks... go for the Sidecar, FABULOUS!!!. It is one of the best outside of the Top of the Mark.

A lot of restaurants come and go but for anyone who has been around San Francisco, for any length of time, knows Cafe Bastille is a mainstay.
author: Alona G.

description:
Came for dinner.  Disappointing.  Seared tuna was full of sinews, endive salad was crappy, dessert was frozen prepackaged, service was passable, but 2nd rate.  

I've been here for lunch many times before over the years, and it was a nice place to come for good food.  This dinner was disappointing.
author: Ritch G.

description: Lovely for brunch. Exquisite eggs benedict. Yummy bottomless Mimosas. Terrific relaxed service. Off the beaten path. Small menu often means everything is a specialty...true here. We'll be back!
author: Maureen H.

description: We got there a half hour early for our reservation, but were seated immediately. The tables are a bit close together, we worked a bit to ignore medical details from our neighbors, but that is my only complaint. The food was excellent, flavorful  and the price was appropriate.
author: Carol L.

description: $6 beers downtown in a not so tourist infested part of San Francisco.  Nothing to complain about and perfect place to go for drinks on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Tony U.

description:
Agree with other reviews.....

Nice idea, poor execution.  Had the escargot app, salmon entree and crepe suzette.  Would recommend the salmon entree, but that's it.  The escargot was oily but not tasty, crepe was rubbery with little flavor or sweetness.  Dining companions had one of the worst caesar salads in their memory.  So much potential wasted here.

Had a large party seated inside and chairs and tables were sort of rickety and uncomfortable.
author: Matt G.

description:
I love this place... sitting outside for lunch on a sunny  day or even on a cold  SF night under the heat lap.  The food is excellent and be sure to try their fries, muscles, and save room for at least one desert.   The service is very European so don't be shy and make yourself at home.  It's next door to another "more dresser" dinner place favorite Plouf and across the street from my favorite Jazzier French place, Cafe Claude. 

Its a big place and a fun place to make reservation for 20, maybe more.
author: Grenache G.

description:
i came here tonight for a girls night out meal and the service and food were really great.

we started off with the pomme frites with garlic aioli the fries were nice and crispy, lightly saleted and with the garlic aioli it was just a perfect pair. my friends and i all opted for the 3 course prix fix menu for $25 which was a pretty good deal, since each entree on its own ranged from $14-30 easily. i started with the salad and my friends had the onion soup, they loved it because it was not as salty as some other onion soups and the flavor was good.

We all had different entrees, i had the crepe de mushroom and chicken. it was in a nice, crispy crepe filled with alot of nicely seasoned and tasty mushrooms and chicken. one of my friends had the mussells and the sauce it came in was delicious and creamy! and the mussells werent overcooked they were tender. my other friend had the Boeuf Bourguignon. boy, that was delicious! the meat was nice, juicy and tender cubes of beef cooked to perfection. it was seasoned nicely with a carrots and potatos that were just soft enough.

dessert we all had the floating island cake. it wasn't so much a cake as it was a floating foam. but delicious and sweet foam drizzled with honey and topped with almonds. the "cake" tasted like marshmellow foam, tasty yet sweet. i only had about half and i had to stop. sugar overload O_O

service was also really good, our waiter, i forgot his name but he was very attentive, nice and cute as hell. probably one of the only asian, spiky haired, sounds like he speaks french guys there. lol
author: Stella J.

description: I went to cafe bastille for brunch, with a friend (she recommended it). Checked out the menu online, seemed limited but was ok. The highlight is probably the bottomless mimosa's. We had a reservation for 1pm and sat outside, they were pretty full outside. I ordered the eggs Benedict. The food came pretty quick. It looked good but my first bite wasn't great, the meat was rubbery & tasted funny but I was starving...went for the 2nd bite and then stopped because there was a HAIR in my food, yuck! Called the waiter and showed him and (even though I didn't want to eat there now, but was starving) I asked for French Toast and he said ok. I RECEIVED ZERO APOLOGY. But whatever. Got the french toast which was decent but not amazing and I wasn't going to argue but they still charged me (for the french toast not the eggs benedict) which was also not great customer service. There are too many great brunch places in San Francisco for me to ever go back here, skip this place!
author: Kimberly R.

description:
A few pals and I visited on Bastille Day for a joint birthday lunch. There's great outdoor seating if you're lucky enough to go on a sunny day in San Francisco.  That day French words fluttered through the air occasionally interrupted by crass English words from our table.  

Mussels
Delicious dead sea life, soaked in white wine sauce, and even better chased down with more wine. 

Coq Au Vin
Lovely, I'd order this again and not just because I like saying Coq.

Flourless Chocolate Cake
Gluttonly delish. If you're looking for a fun way to get fat, this is your ticket!
author: Angie O.

description:
Great restaurant tucked away in Belden Place (my favorite little European spot to dine).

My friends and I came here for the Dine About Town pre fixe menu. I ordered the Mushroom soup (appetizer),  Salmon dish (entre), and the Flourless Chocolate cake (dessert). Everything tasted pretty standard and I found it to be very filling. I was served more food than I could finish, which is pretty unusual for French dining.

I expected the food to be in smaller tastier portions, and though the food was not bad at Cafe Bastille at all, this wouldnt really be on my top choice for French dining. Nevertheless, its a convenient place to stop for a bite and the ambience is quite nice.
author: S. V.

description:
I must say I absolutely adore this tiny little eatery tucked in an alley near Chinatown! 

Its such a perfect spot because people can eat outside without the cold of San Francisco's brutal wind. 

We tried the Ahi Tuna, Coq Au Vin (fucking delicious! they cooked the chicken for so long with red wine that even the bone is tender! THIS is the perfect meal when u are hungry and it is cold outside), Escargot (too salty), and a friend of mine had savory crepes. 

All in all, it was an awesome dining experience! We went on a weekday around 5ish so it wasn't crowded, but as the night falls, you better make a reservation! 

PSST they have all you can drink package! freeee flowwwwww
author: Miss C.

description: Ambiance and food is great. Customer service also great. The pork chops over lentils topped with caramelized onions was super delicious! Escargot was also very good.
author: Mavette S.

description: Good food. Good service. Duck Confit was amazing!
author: Alfred L.

description:
Almost like being in Paris, since the people at the surrounding tables were all either French or, like us, of French extraction.  Order the mussels!  Service is very spotty and non-specific, as the night we were there there were 3 servers, the bartender, and a very busy bus person, all of whom were hustling outside and on the main floor as well as up and down the stairs to the lower level.

We had made a reservation through Open Table.  It was honored, but we still waited nearly 20 minutes.  Outside seating has heat lamps, but you need to be right near 'em to benefit.

NOTE:  lots of families with kids as young as a year old, so if you're kid-phobic, you might want to dine late.
author: Anne M.

description:
I would give it 5 stars if the downstairs area didn't look like such a cheaply designed restaurant.  Anyway, we had a birthday party there for one of my friends and they didn't have a big enough table for a party of about 20 people, so they had to split two tables between 20 people which already made it kind of disappointing, but nonetheless, we were all somewhat together.  So, they sent us to the downstairs level, which looked super cheesy, with it's really old looking Christmas decorations.

The menu had some good main dishes in it, stuff such as rack of lambs, vegetarian ravioli, scallops.  I ordered the rack of lambs.  For a table of 20, the service was alright, food got to us quickly but the waitress seemed a bit out of it like she didn't want to be there.  The lamb itself was mighty tasty, cooked to my liking.  Everyone else seemed to enjoy there meals, no complaints, although you can't refill on soda...THAT should be a norm in a restaurant.  I didn't mind paying for another cup of soda, but don't put so much ice in it next time.  2-something for a half cup of Coke isn't exactly worth it.

As I said before, the design of the downstairs level of the restaurant was quite boring and timid, upstairs was a lot more elegant.  I wish that we were seated outside on the patio instead where it was a lot more...pretty.  Beldan Place is quite a cute little alleyway, it's very different from most places in San Francisco.  The surrounding area of Beldan Place was very "financial" looking which is quite a pleasant surprise when you turn into that alley and see a couple of exquisitely cute looking restaurants with outdoor patio seatings.

All in all, it's not a bad place for people looking for a small restaurant with some delectable food, but just don't get stuck with a table downstairs, I recommend asking for an outdoor patio seating.
author: Simon L.

description:
Dinner @ Bastille - let's keep this short and sweet :)
Ambiance
Decent for a Saturday night, can be a bit crowded. 

Food
Appetizer/foie gras - excellent
Appetizer/escargot - average 
Entree/rabbit - pretty decent, big portioned, kinda sweet, kinda rich, didn't finish the whole thing.
Entree/mussels - gotta be the largest bowl of mussels i've seen at a French restaurant.. excellent
author: Catalina C.

description:
French casual home cooking style, good mussels, great Rosette de Lyon  (French salami) even though it is actually local, good value wine list, it felt like home!
Outdoor dining is also a nice touch, very European!
author: Frederic P.

description:
I met some friends tonight here, who had just returned from a trip to France. We sat outside by the heat lamp and it was pouring down rain, but we stayed dry. We sat for hours sipping kir royales and wine and eating and talking. We had a great time. Although they've changed their menu, they've kept the old standbys and they are still reasonably priced for the neighborhood. 

The service was exceptionally nice. Not until later did I think about this though - at the end they said, "Just so you know, there's already an 18% service charge on the bill." None of us had any problem with it because we had a nice time, but there were only five of us - usually they do that with parties of 6. To me, it was more of a grim indication of survival than anything.  Belden Alley was very quiet and Cafe Bastille was empty. It is Monday so I'm crossing my fingers and hoping the combination of weather as well as the fact that it's Monday were the main reasons. Secretly I know they're not!!
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Came here for a beer after with a friend.  The staff is hella friendly but idk about the food, since we just had beers.  The vibe is all around a very cozy one.  Sat outside underneath the lamps, and had a great time.  The alley always has a bunch of tourists that pass by and snap pics, and it can get annoying if its a lot of people, but then you start to think about how cool it is that you live here and don't need to take pictures to remember.
author: Harry F.

description:
Still new to lunching places, my friend brought me to Belden Lane and told me to choose a restaurant.  Cafe Bastille has lovely patio seating and it was a nice sunny day (maybe too sunny) to be lunching on the patio.  I like outdoor seating and people watching...this is the perfect place to do that.

I ordered the Dungeness crab meat salad with avocado, orange and cherry tomatoes, with jalepeno vinaigrette.  Yum!  It was light and refreshing and delicious!
author: Christine C.

description:
I can't believe the number of positive reviews of this place.

Yes, the service is terrible.

But the food is downright horrendous. Everything is cooked improperly, the ingredients taste a little rotten, and everything is underseasoned. So gross. This isn't just a taste preference. It was just nasty.

I guess the fries were ok...
author: Jon F.

description: Looking for a casual, authentic French cuisine? This is it! My brother-in-law, who has been to France many times recommended Cafe Bastille and it was absolutely fantastic. There were four of us who all ordered different meals but we shared. Everything was it incredible, it seems you just can't go wrong. BTW, the French Onion Soup is a must have!
author: Debbie Z.

description: Went to Cafe Bastille based  in Yelp reviews and so glad we did! The food was great! A slice of Paris in San Francisco! We started with escargot and had Hacis paramientier (a casseole of braided beef, potatoes and cheese) for main. The dish was glorious! Really enjoyed it! Would go back. Also, great value for the price.
author: Ryen T.

description: Business lunch for four. Opted for outside seating. Good food, prompt and attentive service, and a pleasant environment. Cafe Bastille is a reliable go to destination for lunch.
author: Brian K.

description:
A bas le Bastille? Mais non! If you stroll along Belden Place at noon on a weekday, you will find yourself running a gauntlet of restaurateurs eager to feed you. Several of the restaurants here are quite good, but my favorite is Cafe Bastille.  The onion soup is incredible, and everything else I've tried is very good.

The menu was just reprinted and some items have changed. I'm not sure whether this indicates a change in chefs. They'd better not mess with the soup. Or the croque monsieur.

I've never been to Paris, so I can't respond to those who've remarked on authenticity. But I don't particularly care. The food and service are consistently good and it's authentically Cafe Bastille.
author: Charlie G.

description:
Wanted to enjoy the gorgeous weather in SF the other day so we went to Belden Place.  It was about 2:30pm on a Saturday and Cafe Bastille was the only place open (yay!).  

The wine list is pretty good and bottle prices are very reasonable.  We ordered a bottle of bubbles, and some apps (pomme frites and a chicken/port pate) and the total bill was $50.  Not too shabby.  Service is good, friendly staff, friendly  crowd at the restaurant.  

Not sure if I would make a separate trip to seek out this place again, but I would also recommend it if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Angie M.

description: The first time I ate here was on a French field trip a couple years ago and since then I have been craving the hatchis parmienter, this wonderful meat and mash potato duo over melted cheese.. so much calories but so good!! The bread they give you as you wait was kind of stale but the butter, very soft like it's freshly made and stirred makes up for it. My mother got the quiche lorraine with fries and let me tell you that THE FRIES ARE THE BOMB!!!! it's a great mix of in and out fries and McDonald fries together.. I just couldn't keep my hands off my moms fries, lol. The waiter always refilled our drinks before we could even ask which was very prompt and professional. Before my mom and I got there we accidently went to the one next to it which smelled weird but as we were directed to the real cafe bastille we chose to sit outside as the interior of their cafe was sort of dark and tacky. The prices are pretty over average but for god sakes it's wonderful French food where you didn't have to fly to France but just travel downtown! All in all it was great for somewhere to eat once in awhile.
author: Mermaid K.

description: Rude service. Ordered two portions of what our neighbor was having. The waiter brings out something else and curses at us in French when we ask them to take back the plates. Unacceptable
author: Simon N.

description:
We were here for a business lunch on Monday, where we were seated downstairs. The service was so bad I was actually quite astonished. I'm not a harsh critic of restaurant service either (I was a waitress all through high school/undergrad so I know how it is!), but our server displayed absolutely no interest in making sure we had what we had needed (or what we had asked for, more than once). 

Pair that with a lack of good vegetarian selections, and I will definitely pass on coming back here.
author: Gaelen X.

description: Great outdoor brunch place tucked away in an alley. The eggs benedict and potatoes hit the spot! I'll be going back for sure.
author: Stacy W.

description:
I went here on Friday night and was really unimpressed. I ordered the cassoulet, but only ate a few bites because the food tasted old. I'm pretty sure it had been prepared days ago, and likely reheated, if not frozen. I was scared to eat any more for fear I'd get food poisoning.

The waitress and bus boy didn't even comment on the fact that I hadn't eaten my food, so I guess this might happen fairly often.

My friend had the mussels, and said they were ok. 

I wouldn't eat here again.
author: Sheri M.

description: Had the boudin noir, great! Wife had French onion soup....btw, do you know what they call French onion soup in France?.....
author: Mike J.

description: Trois pate, sweetbreads, blood sausage, coq au vin, flowerless cake ... Shoot me now!
author: P S.

description:
A good spot on Belden Place. As long as you're not sent downstairs to the dungeon to enjoy your food toilet-side, this place has a great outdoor atmosphere and good food. They use a little too much cream in all their dishes so watch out for your heart, but everything tastes nice as a result. 

To fully enjoy a meal here:
1. Sit outside
2. Bring your lactase pills
3. Brush up on your French
author: Emma C.

description: It was Bastille Day, fixed price. $35 for one course.  We had a 6:00 reservation.  The glass of champagne was flat, and had to be sent back.  One of the entrees was a mushroom fettuccine that was striking for its mediocrity.   The meager sauce was flavorless and in lieu of many mushrooms, there was spinach thrown in, for no apparent reason.  (Color, perhaps? Not good enough.)  The other entree was a filet mignon, which was fine, but it was supposed to be accompanied by truffled potatoes rissole.  The potatoes didn't appear to have been near butter, oil, or truffles, but instead were hard, dry and diced.  The service was graceless.  A knife had to be borrowed from another table but then instead of adjusting the place settings, we were questioned about it.  The bread basket was moved hastily from the side of our table that almost conjoined another and plopped  thoughtlessly atop the rim of bread plates so another couple could sit down because they'd squeezed the tables too closely together, (but then the other couple decided to eat inside anyway).  We were repeatedly asked if we had finished when we clearly still had food on our plates. The only thing this restaurant has going for it is that it's in Belden Place, and you can sit outside and feel that you're having a Parisian cafe experience.  However, five minutes into the food and flat champagne, all you've got are the legendary rude waiters to make you think of Paris...and even they are never so graceless as these.
author: Margaret S.

description: Loved it. Great food at reasonable prices. What else can you ask for. The beef bourguignon is delicious.
author: Steve J.

description:
In short: nice to be able to eat French food in a cafe-like atmosphere outside, but the food itself lacks depth/complexity. 

We went here recently on one of San Francisco's warm September evenings to enjoy some outside dining -- tried Cafe Claude first, and regretted not waiting for a table there.  The wait staff at Bastille was friendly and efficient, the price was not unreasonable, and the atmosphere was quaint, but both of our meals from the prix fixe menu were relatively bland.  The French onion soup looked like the real thing, but the broth was bland.  The boeuf bourguignon likewise had all the right ingredients but tasted as if it had stewed for a few minutes rather than a few hours.  The bread and the peach tarts were the highlights of the meal ... in the end, we didn't regret going, but we wouldn't go again.
author: Rob S.

description:
What gal doesn't enjoy beautiful patio dining in an alley way of San Francisco? Very SATC, yes?  Beldon Way is the perfect place to have a girls lunch out on a nice day. Food, Wine, Girl Talk. 

I always get the same thing, the croque monsieur, the french version of grilled ham and cheese, slathered with a bit of bechemel sauce. I do need a bit of an angioplasty afterward but its so good going down.  

Moderately priced.
author: Roseabelle M.

description: The food was delicious and the prices are a steal. This place is my new ATF  french cafe.
author: Graylain A.

description: The service was really poor. I felt rushed when I was ordering. Although, I really enjoyed my filet mignon. The dessert.. chocolate cake was to die for. I felt like they totally ignored us.Waited like half an hour for my entree.  And when I asked for coffee with my dessert. The coffee was lukewarm. So, I asked to get a refill. Hopefully, it would be nice and hot. The coffee was cold. I waited another 20 minutes before I can even get any type of service. Eventually, I asked another waiter to give us two cup of hot coffee. He brought us one. So, I decided not to make anymore complaints, and let my friend have the coffee with his dessert. Food was really good, but the service was really bad.
author: Jenny W.

description:
"Pleaze for you come and looohk at me menu.  Ahh, you so bella.  trey bella. mwah mwah. Izz nice yez? You come in, jhez?"  *wink* *wink*

NO.  ME NOT COME IN.  IZ NOT FUCKING NICE.  IZ CHEEZY.  IZ TACKY.  IZ OVERPRICE.  IZ FRENCH WHORE OUT FRONT FLASHING WHITE TEETH AND WINK WINK ME.  IZ SAME AS ALL OTHER ONES ON STREET.  IZ ANNOYING.
author: Rick H.

description:
What a fantastic surprise!

So today, the other Steph and I, yes, our company thought it would be a good idea to hire 2 Stephanie's cuz that's not confusing or anything, hehe, or maybe they are just really smart, cuz we kinda rock, wait, where was I going with this? Oh yeah, our discovery!!

So we wanted to go grab lunch and catch up and I threw out sushi. But as anyone who works in the Financial District knows, there isn't exactly a huge array of tasty sushi options around. Pssst, Financial District, get on that! And so after checking out one place but finding it had no seating, we decided to change gears and search for something else. 

As we walked down a street looking at random signs, we both happened to look to our left and whoa, what was that? Is that Paris? Is that New York? Is that a siesta in Spain? Whatever it was, we were going! And so we walked down the alley to this adorable little outdoor cafe area! :) 

Lucky for us there was a table available and so we grabbed it and checked out the venue. They offered up a prix fixe menu with an appetizer and main meal and a glass of vino and can you say, sold? :) I can. I went with the French Onion soup and it was pretty amazing. i really liked that it wasn't too salty and not super beefy tasting. I usually order this soup at most French restaurants and you would be amazed how many places fail to deliver the goods. Bastille, did a nice job.

I also ordered the Croque Madam, because there clearly wasn't enough cheese in my soup (sheesh, haha, pig). When it arrived, oh my, what a large sammich of cheese and ham and a fried egg. When i cut into it, it was good, but I have to say the Croque Madam at Foreign Cinema trumps this one any day! THAT is a CM, while this was more like a cm. Get my drift ;)

The other Stephanie ordered the goat cheese salad and it looked deelish and upon her urging I tried a little piece of the bread that came with hers and it had not just goat cheese on it, but butter to boot and how are you really gonna go wrong with that!! She also ordered the prosciutto sammich and that looked good as well.

All in all, it was a delightful lunch with the other Steph and I definitely enjoyed our time together :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
Oh why, oh why did I not listen to some of my favorite yelp reviewers about this place???  Outside of the French manager and waitresses, I can't say anything is really authentic about this place.  What a tourist trap!  

I love French food.  My boyfriend, who is French, is often surprised by my constant desire to try French restaurants here in the city.  We've had some good experiences, but I think that we've also had some mediocre ones.  I am always hopeful.

I had never been to Cafe Bastille prior to my spontaneous "date" with my boyfriend. I thought it would be great to sit with my authentically French boyfriend and share authentically French food and drink.  
How wrong I was.

For 2 individuals, the total, after tax, but prior to tip was $94.12.

For this amount we got:
1- kir royale type of drink (le parisien) = $11.00
1- french onion soup for my boyfriend (lots of cheese and breadlike topping, but very LITTLE soup).  = $7.50
1-Mixed green salad (dripping in disgusting, oily, flavorless salad dressing) = $7.75.
1 duck breast main dish for my boyfriend (tasted gamey) = $22.00
1 NY steak with peppercorn sauce (too much sauce with too much PEPPER...they ruined a perfectly cooked piece of meat) = $23.00
1 glass of Cabernet = $8.50
1 chocolate crepe (could have gotten a much better one at SOPHIES CREPES in Japantown, of all places) = $7.00

In addition, we sat outside around a cafe table that was precariously perched on a downward incline.  So, I was worried that my food would slide off the table.  Unfortunately, the lopsided table was the least of our worries b/c we watched as the disorganized wait staff mixed up a multitude of orders while we were forced to inhale smoke from locals smoking right next to the cafe seating partition.  Ugh...

Plus, the only thing at the dinner table that night that was "authentically French" seemed to be my boyfriend and perhaps the stale baguettes...

Overall, the dining experience left me sorely disappointed.  I will NOT go back.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I've always wanted to check out Belden Place.  After scouring over yelp reviews, I decided that Cafe Bastille would be my best bet.  The experience overall was pretty good.

The AMBIANCE:
A friend of mine was in town so I wanted to take her somewhere interesting.  Also gave me a perfect opportunity to cross another restaurant off my bookmarks.  The alley was very quaint and reminiscent of Europe.  Im always a fan of bringing something different or interesting to my dining experience.  

The FOOD:
We weren't that hungry so we decided to share the Prix Fixe Lunch and the mussels that were raved about so much.  For the Prix Fixe, we ordered a French Onion Soup and the Croquet Madame.  

- I thoroughly enjoyed the FRENCH ONION SOUP.  Often times, french onion soup is too salty IMO, but it was great here.  
- The CROQUET MADAME was delicious.  I was a bit skeptical when I read about what it was.  Am I really going to pay that much for a Ham and Cheese Sandwich, EVEN if they give me an egg?!  Its definitely not your run-of-the-mill ham and cheese sandwich.  I enjoyed it and definitely would come back for it.  
- The MUSSELS were a bit disappointing.  Very small mussels.  The size reminded more of clams.  The sauce was good, but I was expecting more given the hype from the yelp reviews.

We opted to share dessert last minute and ordered the special Nutella Crepe they were offering.  The first time the crepe came out, it was missing Nutella!  The same thing happened to the table next to us.  However, they were very kind and gave everyone a free glass of port.  It went very well with the nutella. 

The SERVICE:
Service was great.  Very polite and hospitable staff.  I have always been fond of French accents.  Haha maybe its just me, but every girl I know that speaks with a French accent sounds exactly like my girl cousin from Belgium.

OVERALL:
Definitely would come back here.  The food is not mindblowing, but its good and its a cool place to go.  Makes it a nice place to take a girl you want to "hang out" with.  You know... the point before a real "formal" date.  Have a nice friendly lunch in a place that is nice to have a long conversation with someone.  Maybe I'm just biased because I was in good company.
author: Bert N.

description: I ate here last night for Bastille Day, which may not be a good representation of a typical experience at this restaurant. We had a reservation, but had to wait 45 minutes past our reservation for a table in the ugly downstairs area. The food was okay, nothing special. Large servings, uninteresting flavors, expensive. Loud techno and disco music played with flashing laser lights, definitely not the "French" flavor I was looking for. Guests were crammed in everywhere, plastic cups of beer in hand, indoors and outdoors. It felt like a euro-trash pick-up scene. If that's your thing, then you might like it here.
author: Tanya R.

description:
Fresh baked bread served table-side with unsalted butter made for a very nice start. I enjoyed my prosciutto sandwich with the fig spread, although I'm tempted to request a chevre cheese instead of the blue cheese that comes with the sandwich, only because blue cheese is pretty strong for my personal taste. For any blue cheese lovers, this is the sandwich for you. It was balanced nicely with their spring mix salad. And the portions are huge. I would have ordered dessert too if I had the room for it.

Overall ambience is great for any lunch with co-workers or friends and I would like to try out their dinner menu as well.  Don't be fooled by the amount of seating - there is a huge dining area downstairs to sit in and you can be shielded by the elements. Plus, the prices are incredibly reasonable for their menu offerings. I would definitely come back here again.
author: Justine P.

description: The mussels are a must. I came here for the first time with my boyfriend the other night, and had a good time (except for the awful people who sat next to us...and as the reviewers below note, Belden Lane is quaint and intimate, and slightly claustrophobic.) The service was great, in my opinion. We were given complimentary glasses of champagne when our table was not vacated on time, the waitress was always there filling up our glasses before I noticed they needed filling. The duck and mussels were the best I have tasted, and the ahi tuna was delicious as well. Obviously, or not, no room for dessert.
author: Joanna M.

description:
The goat cheese appetizer is GREAT, the coconut shrimp yummy and the  Cabernet Franc divine. Service was very accommodating of our rambunctious group that basically drank and nibbled for three hours. 
They have a decent selection on the cheese and fruit plates (although a bit mainstream), and a nice range of wines by the glass - both French and Cali.

The only negatives were the leg eating tables outside and the fries. I wanted classic frites but really these were standard fries, and not altogether wonderful.
author: Lise L.

description: Stay away. Food was OK but disappointing. Bathrooms dirty. Service was horrible. Waiter Andrew F. brought bottle with a less favorable year than printed in the menu, then brought the menu out to argue with me until he realized he was wrong. Horrible service from him (got more out of the bus boy). He stopped by the table exactly once (at the end of the meal) after taking our order. Try Brindisi or Tiramisu for a better experience in Belden, or go to one of the other French restaurants in the area if you want that. Plenty that are much better.
author: Mike R.

description:
I'll start off with two somewhat random, though important!, things to say about Cafe Bastille.

First a note to the guys. The hostess is GORGEOUS. Exotic. French. Unbelievably beautiful. We were all a bunch of straight girls and could not stop staring at her...

Secondly...they charge per soda. No free refills here. Most people don't assume this, but we ended up paying $20 just for soda refills and didn't realize until we received the bill. Naive on our part maybe, but you've been warned.

Belden Place is a treat in its own, and Cafe Bastille never disappoints. The food is excellent and beautifully prepared--I highly recommend the halibut or crab salad. The atmosphere could not be more charming or more romantic. I strongly disagree with people saying its tacky. It's completely charming and lovely. 

Belden Place is certainly one of my favorite dining destinations, and Cafe Bastille is always an excellent choice amongst the restaurants it has to offer.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Took my team to lunch here there other day - food was good, service was fine, cute place. We did the lunch pre-fixe which allowed us to pick 2 items from the menu. Had the onion soup and the ham and cheese - it was rich and satisfying - perfect for a cold day.

Overall, a good place. A bit on the pricey end.
author: Joy A.

description: This place had the non pretentious feel of a true French place. It reminded me of cafe Paris in epernay . The steak frites ( which by the way is indeed a French dish) was perfect ( loved the hot mustard on the table for the fries) a nice Alsatian beer...life is good.
