My wife had a beautiful moist trout...all and all very reasonably prices and a wonderful atmosphere. We will be back. Next time the mussels :-)
author: Robert V.

description: Had the hachis parmentier, which was sort of similar to shepherd's pie. It was just okay and super hot (temperature). It took a long time to cool down. I did enjoy the fries and aioli--would've been very happy with just that and beer. Cool vintage French signage all around.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I had a nice dinner at Cafe Bastille on Sat night. We had some friends from out of town to entertain and I though Belden St would be just the place. I love walking up to the alley, all decorated in twinkle lights. Since I have not been to Europe, I figure this is the next best thing.

I had originally made my reservation for outside, however the weather had turned a bit cold, so I asked to be moved inside. No problem. The seating is a bit tight, but charming. I was drawn to the french menu and thought the prices seemed very fair. I loved my vegetarian ravioli, and I have never ordered anything vegetarian before! It was excellent. The rack of lamb was also a stand out dish. Unfortunately, my guest fillet Mignon was under cooked. He specified medium and it was very rare. It took us a good five minuted to get anyone to help us send it back and when it was returned it was on the same plate. The blood had run all over the risotto and now the plate looked very un-appetizing. My guest did not even attempt to eat his meal. :o(

I could have easily over looked this problem, had the waiter tried to be the least bit concerned. However, he almost made us feel bad for sending the steak back! Not sure if it was a language thing, but he came off very condescending.

I will give Cafe Bastille another shot. I thought it was a good value and I did enjoy my meal. Hopefully the waiter we had was just having an off night?
author: Lisa A.

description:
Belden Lane is sometimes hit or miss for me. I love the hustle and bustle of the street, and the outdoor seating is of course clutch, but the cuisine at some of the establishments sometimes plays second fiddle to the conversation and company.

With that in mind, I was very happy to have the chance to eat at Cafe Bastille this past Friday. We had a group of some 12 people, so they sat us downstairs (without a reservation, they still squeezed us in, in under 15 mintues). We were a boisterous and demanding group, but our waiter was a superstar - he kept us occupied with some great wine selections - and managed to get us our courses like clockwork - all the time with a good smile.

Being a French bistro, I gravitate towards the Steak Frittes, and here Bastille came through with shining colors. My steak was a perfect medium rare, and the accompanying fries were crispy yet soft inside, golden brown the way I like them.

After the meal, we congregated upstairs at the bar, sort of a winding down with good friends. Bastille turned out to be that perfect standard that all neighborhood bistros should aspire to, and I'm looking forward to my next visit in earnest.
author: Nish N.

description:
3.5 stars, and mostly because they have my most favorite dessert in the whole wide world: floating islands. Well, more like one giant floating island, the way that Cafe Bastille served it. One giant meringue floating on a cold vanilla soup with caramel and candied almond cookie type thing crumbled on top. A little disappointing, I thought that it was just ok. I've had better at Absinthe.

As my lunch entree, I ordered the grilled veggie and cheese sandwich. Served on a baguette with a side salad. The veggies, were just zucchini and asparagus. The cheese was Gruyere. Nothing special/nothing to die for. Just decent filling food. And the service was nothing special/nothing to die for. 

We sat outside in the little alley, which was quite nice, especially with the heating lamp right above us. Oh and I also stole some of Teri C.'s french fries which were pretty good!
author: Caroline C.

description:
If you're looking for French food in the Financial District, go to Jeanty's instead. If it's sunny and you're looking for an alfresco lunch, then this place will do. 

Their french onion soup (in beef broth), pomme frite with aoili and dungeness crab meat salad are pretty good. Chase it down with a glass of champagne and you're set for the afternoon. About $40 with tip.

Sidenote: If you're craving for french onion soup (FOS) and you're vegetarian, try Trader Joe's frozen FOS. It's a little salty, but quite good and cheap.
author: Miles G.

description:
Our friend had her 25th birthday dinner here.  We originally wanted to eat somewhere else, but found out that place was closed on Saturday's.  A friend said she always wanted to go to Café Bastille because it looks "cute".  

I gotta give them props for accepting our reservation of 14 people a day in advance, and then letting us change the reservation time 30 minutes before our reservation.  They brought us downstairs, to a more secluded area.  The people that worked there all sounded French.  I ordered the cheese ravioli dish thing, and took nibbles from other people's plates.  I didn't eat much, but service was good, atmosphere was dimly lit, nice, like our own little private party downstairs.
author: Carren E.

description:
I really liked this place - The lively atmosphere, cool outdoor seating, interesting menu w/ fun traditional French dishes, and unique cocktail list.  I had been to Plouf next door and have always wanted to come back to try Cafe Bastille.  

My friend and I shared a foie gras terrine, mussels w/ white wine garlic sauce, duck breast entree and french fries on the side.  We absolutely loved everything.  

I will say that we were disappointed the french fries were a bit soggy but the aioli was tasty and made us crave for more.

The duck breast was cooked beautifully and seasoned wonderfully - red/pink center and crispy/medium on the outside.  However, the lentils and bed of spinach it was resting on was WAY TOO SALTY and really overpowered the duck.  

Terrine and mussels were delicious.  

We had a nice girl's night out and enjoyed the friendly wait staff and the yummy cocktails.  Wish we had saved room for dessert.  Hopefully, we will be back again soon.
author: Kathleen H.

description:
Belden Lane restaurants in general have the following in common: employees in the alley as you walk by hustling to get you into their restaurants, super sharp service, and that romantic European ambiance and flair. 

That said at Cafe Bastille: I had the pate sandwich, which was good but for some reason didn't live up to what I had been hoping for. It did come with though a large salad tossed in a balsamic vinaigrette that was really refreshing and just what I needed. The french hot dog that I had was literally a regular hot dog in french roll with melted cheese on it. But I will say that it was a good quality hot dog. That said the food wasn't bad, but it wasn't fantastic either. If you pair the food though with the alley itself and the surroundings and the service and the good wine and champagne you are having with your meal, well then you get a 4 star experience.
author: Denise B.

description:
I've eaten here twice so far, and both times have been excellent. I had the salmon the first time, and the second I had a swordfish special. The salmon was good, but I actually found the side dishes to be the star of the show. The artichoke hearts were so savory, and was a perfect match against the sweetness of the caramelized apples. The swordfish was again good, but the green beans and mushrooms that came with it were so damn good. Perfectly steamed, so as to be not too limp, and with good flavor. The mushrooms and the sauce that came with it were so good that I used the bread to soak up every last drop. I don't know anything about no pomme fritz, but man, I'd highly recommend trying the fish dishes here. 

The place itself is a little cramped, so it's not perfect. As far as the service goes,  I haven't had a problem yet. A solid establishment, in my opinion.
author: Tom H.

description:
I am a big fan of the Belden Lane restaurants, particularly Plouf and Taverna. Since I hadn't really had a memorable experience at Cafe Bastille I thought it might be worth another shot. The weather was divine and the lunch crowd had not yet descended so I was eager for some yummy french eats. 

The waitress was very friendly, though my dining companions couldn't figure out what the specials were (thick accent) so we simply consulted the chalkboard. Everyone but me ordered the prix fixe lunch options and at second glance I should have as well. My quiche, with a side salad and pomme frites, was gooey and cheesy. It actually tasted more like fried cheese than anything with egg in it but that's likely the souffle element. There didn't seem to be much in the quiche besides this cheesy "egg" concoction...I guess it lacked more than "j'ne sais quois". The frites were crispy and perfect but the meal in its entirety failed to satisfy. 

Maybe my expectations were more aligned with Plouf & Taverna, but I was just so unimpressed with my meal at Cafe Bastille that I doubt I'll try again when there are better options so nearby.
author: Jane K.

description:
My last experience at Cafe Bastille was absolutely awful because of the service and the ambiance, and the food was just so-so.

Service: went for dinner and the weather was drizzly and freezing cold outside, so we asked to sit inside.  They put us downstair where we were alone (which was nice for a bit).  But because we were downstairs alone, our waiter forgot about us.  Then, the bartender upstairs started to play horrible French house music (remember, this is a restaurant, not a club) and neglected to realize that the speakers downstairs, where we were eating, were turned up exceptionally loud.  It was absolutely miserable and almost twenty minutes later when our waiter decided to grace us with his presence for only the second time after about an hour, we had to ask to turn the music down because he apparently couldn't tell that it was atrocious.

The food: so-so at best.  To start, by boyfriend and I had the escargots de bourgogne, which was ok and not nearly as good as that of some of the neighboring French restuarants (I won't name names).  My mother and boyfriend had the steak entree.  My mother's was fine but my boyfriend had to send his back because it wasn't cooked properly (it was completely purple and cold  inside, when he ordered "medium").  I had the Coq au Vin.  The presentation was awful (messy, and drenched in sauce).  Taste was ok.  Quite simply I've had much, much better.  And the desserts were good, but nothing to report home about.

I guess overall the restaurant is a good representation of authentic French cuisine, which from my experience is typically simple, without all the bells and whistles that French Restaurants in the US use (which I happen to enjoy).  If you are looking for a place that is "very French," has a Parisian atmosphere (think house music, coupled with outdoor seating and poor service), and so-so food, then this is the place for you!  I don't think I will ever go back.  There are way too many good french restaurants in the city to waste your time on this one.
author: Lauren W.

description:
We came here for Valentines Day, got reservation a couple hours before going. Very nice ambiance outside; heated, live music (violin & accordion); not too loud. 

The food was pretty much the single best French cuisine I've ever had. We had scallops as an appetizer, lightly seared & perfectly cooked. 
For the main course I had salmon with small potatoes & spinach. My girlfriend had the filet mignon with scalloped potatoes & cremini mushrooms. Both dishes were seasoned perfectly to let the flavors of the actual ingredients be the main elements you taste. 
For desert (obviously) creme brulee; so delicious. Very rich & creamy on the inside, the top was perfectly crispy with a raspberry. 1 is enough for 2 people, but you have to get it - even if you're too full.

The only semi negative I would say was, the outside seating was a little crowded, but the inside was fairly empty which had normal seating/spacing. If there isn't a lot of people sitting outside at the same time the seating is fine. The food more than makes up for the tight quarters & with a couple glasses or wine or beer you'll make friends fast. Good food always makes everyone friendlier.
author: Rohnny J.

description:
It's everything I could ask for from a French bistro. A small place tucked away in an alley. A decently stocked bar. No unnecessary decor, a few amusing pop art posters. Little stairs that go to who knows where. Most of the seating is outside in the charming patio aka the alley, which is brightly lit with hanging lights. A secluded world in the midst of the financial center, a sparkling bubble that lets you know that you have a cozy place to escape to in the middle of fake money-waving formality.

I hate pretentiousness with a passion, and there's no room for it here. It's good bistro fare with no pretending or pressure. Take a smoke break between courses, enjoy an amusingly cheesy named cocktail, it's about the society, and loving it with food. No formalities, and that is a very welcome luxury I long for. 

They serve good foie gras terrine, and the blood sausage entree with roasted apples and potatoes was very heartwarming.

With my personal tastes, I can see myself enjoying a fun romantic date here far more than any 5-star restaurant where they fold your napkins for you every time you get up from the table. This place is not for the common diner, but for someone who loves a quirky atmosphere that one finds in the least expected places.
author: Daria J.

description:
Are you kidding me?

I work in the restaurant industry, at 2 very well-known restaurants, in fact, and never before have I felt compelled to call the manager to our table. Might I add this is my first Yelp review.

First, let me begin by saying that by no means did I expect stellar service on a Friday night on Belden Lane, but certainly I expected more than what we got, which was NOTHING!

Our server was completely absent and didn't seem to give two sh**s about us, as his tables around us enjoyed all their courses and continued to leave as we sat there still waiting for our food to be delivered. Water didn't even get to the table until after we placed our order! Our first round of drinks arrived, but then our glasses sat empty until almost the end of the meal. He never checked in with us to see if we needed anything or to see if we even liked our food (which was mediocre, at best). Our busser was the most attentive one, as he refilled our water and re-marked our table for main courses.

Finally, I was fed up and irritated. I walked up to the front desk and asked another employee to please send over a manager to our table. About 10 minutes passed when someone finally arrived. I explained to him how disappointed we were in the service, and he simply mumbled an apology and walked away, never to return to offer anything in reciprocation. Nothing. Totally unacceptable.

We finally asked for our check and, much to our surprise, nothing was comped off the check. We left paying the full check and a small tip (my friend took some pity).

Never, never, never again. This is San Francisco, dammit! There's no excuse for such crappy service.
author: Angela O.

description:
The people-watching alone is a great reason to come here (or to any restaurant in Belden Place). Even though I wasn't planning to eat here, I've found that I'm a total sucker for girls who ask me in French to try their restaurant. 

We got the Crepe-Suzette (butter/Grand Marnier sauce) and a creme brulée for dessert, and although they were nothing overwhelmingly unique, they were tasty. I was particularly impressed with the presentation of the Armagnac, with the glass balanced on top of another glass that had hot water in it to warm the drink. Cappuccinos with thick creamy heads were very a decent finish.
author: Shannon R.

description: Came here on a Groupon for the prix-fixe meal, but will definitely be back to order other dishes off the menu. Started with the onion soup, which was delicious and had a sweet flavor from the onions actually being carmelized instead of just tossed into the broth. Main course was beef bourguignon, and let me tell you, it doesn't get better than this. The pieces of beef were so tender they melted in your mouth, and the array of vegetables that come with are all perfectly cooked. The best part is that the cooking sauce (made with red wine) is distinctive, but subtle. So when you're eating a carrot, it tastes like a carrot. When you're eating a mushroom, it tastes like a mushroom. All with the undercurrent of the red wine sauce flavor. Most places cook everything together for so long it all tastes the same. Not here. We were huge fans! Desserts were tasty (I had the key lime raspberry mousse, which was a little too tart but still yummy enough that I wanted to lick the plate). The service is impeccable and the staff super friendly. We had a lengthy chat with the host (a Parisian) about our many trips to Paris and the foods we love. He even took time to talk about the other restaurants on Belden Place and recommended others to try. I honestly felt like I was back in Paris (my favorite place in the world). I HIGHLY recommend Cafe Bastille.
author: Bob A.

description:
I'd never been to Cafe Bastille or Belden Place before last night, so I was charmed by the little French man who bounced around outside, enticing people into his restaurant.  We sat inside, not too far from a small jazz group jamming in the corner.  The door was open, so it was a bit chilly, but not too bad.  Everything was really good--we had the goat cheese appetizer, the mussels, and the coq au vin.  It was all delicious.

And then our plates were whisked away, and dessert menus placed in front of us (we didn't ask for them, they just appeared).

And then.

We waited.

And waited.

Waited.

Wait.

Wai.

Wa.

W.

I wish I could say we split the floating island dessert (anything that floats and has island in the title is an IMMEDIATE front runner for dessert options).  I wish we had split it--I bet it's delightful.  BUT by the time our waiter remembered we were alive, all we wanted was the check.

So we asked for the check, please.

And waited.

Waited.

(Do you get the sense there was a lot of waiting involved?  Because there was.)

We contemplated making a break for it, BUT were done raised right, and waited (some more).  Finally, the bill came, and it wasn't too bad.  

I'd go back.  Probably.  If I didn't have to do so much damn waiting.
author: diana s.

description:
I ordered what I usually do at a French cafe:  Onion Soup, Steak Frites, Flourless Chocolate Cake.  The soup was thin and not particularly flavorful.  The cheese on its top was, however, very good indeed.  The steak was adequate but could have been prepared with a bit more care.  Either the steak was difficult to cut or the knife I was given for the job was just not sharp.  The cake was the highlight of my meal.  It wasn't as heavy as some implementations of this dish -- almost like a mousse.

Where is the restroom in this place?  I couldn't find it.  I would have asked the waiter, but I saw him so infrequently.
author: Christopher V.

description:
If you order a red meat, have it cooked more than you would normally like.  We ordered the lamb rare and it was definitely less on the medium-rare side and more on the completely bloody raw side. 

Otherwise, the mussels (a la Normande), foie gras, and cognac creme brulee were all yummy.

The kitchen was really slow with our food, and the waitstaff was fine but not as charming as I'm used to at other French restaurants.

Cafe Bastille's not bad, but if you have other options at Belden Place, I would opt for those first.
author: S L.

description:
I found this place totally charming. 

Walking through the Beldon Way alley to get to Cafe Bastille, you almost feel as though you are walking on the cobblestone streets of Florence and Paris, lined with outside seating and waiters trying to lure you in. 

The restaurant is cozy and dimly lit; I imagine it would be a wonderful place for a romantic dinner (hint hint). I absolutely could not decide what to order- everything from the savory crepes to the grilled steak sandwich to the hot dog in a baguette made my mouth water. 

I decided on rock shrimp sauteed with fresh vegetables over a thin pastry with a balsamic reduction. The asparagus, zucchini, and mushrooms were perfectly cooked to a crisp, sauteed with large rock shrimp. The sweet balsamic reduction complimented the shrimp and veggies seasoning perfectly. And the multi layer thin pastry underneath it all soaked up the balsamic and olive oil juices and the butterlicious pastry melted in my mouth. 

Though I don't work downtown, I dream of coming back soon.....for lunch or dinner.
author: Laura D.

description:
After walking down Belden and getting menus shoved in our face from EVERY restaurant in the row, we chose Cafe Bastille, which is where we heading originally anyway.

The french onion soup was delicious, with a very flavorful broth.  For the entrees, I ordered the Coq au Vin, and my boyfriend ordered the Boeuf Bourguignon, and both were very tasty.  The chocolate crepe for dessert had tons of Nutella and reminded me of Paris!

I thought the prices were reasonable for how good the was.
author: Kristen A.

description:
Have been there for my birthday back in February  and last Saturday took two of my clients for dinner.

Simple  fantastic!!! 

Try any of these; Filet mignon, the thing french fries, Cesar salad, crab cakes and any their  dessert. 

Awesome atmosphere too!
author: Bernadette M.

description:
I love this place!! Webt there for a bday party last week and I had one of the most memorable dinner in my life. If you are into seafood dont get anything else besides the Ahi Tuna!! Cooked perfectly and the sauce that comes with is out of this world.
Thanks Brenda for choosing Cafe Bastille for your bday!!
author: Heather P.

description: Yes please. Spent 5 hours relaxing, drinking a crazy amount of rose, and enjoying all that Belden has to offer yesterday at CB. Had excellent service, fantastic food, and got to feel like I was back in Paris for an afternoon. The alley really keeps the wind at bay and I always choose CB for its perfectly authentic experience. Oh, and I love their 2 for 1 happy hour from 4-6. Because what else would I be doing at that time anyway?
author: Kylie S.

description: We had a delicious work lunch on a Tuesday. The crepe, cassoulet and salad nicoise were delicious and the service was efficient.
author: Judy S.

description:
Yes, many tourist visit Belden Place, including Bastille.  But if you aren't a tourist and you come often, they treat you like royalty.  Free champagne, appetizers and port.  Not too bad.  When ever my friends and I go for dinner they gush over us.  I have never been disappointed with the food.  It is consistently good.  They keep the same main ingredients, just preparation changes.  So the menu is always slightly changing.  It also should be noted that I have an affection for this place because one of the first times I went was during the world cup and the excitement was intoxicating.  

If you've only been to Bastille once, it is worth trying again.  Belden place is charming.  Go later in the evening.  It is not very busy and the atmosphere seems more intimate.
author: Alexis M.

description:
We ordered a Cassoulet which was really good and a Coq au Vin which was above average. The reason why I give it only 2 stars is that both me and my friend are small eaters and could finish less than half of our portions. So obviously the next step is to take it to go. Well. we told the waiter to give us boxes but he paid a deaf ear and threw away our food. 
We were terribly upset and will never go back because it left a bad taste in the end. (our total bill was $60 and we are students)
author: Jiggy B.

description:
I really enjoyed Cafe Bastille.  The ambiance was nice and very French.  I'm a very picky bread eater but the bread was amazing!!  I had the onion soup and the duck, both of which were amazing.  The chocolate crepe was also delicious as was their house coffee.  
Overall food was good, service was .crap.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I went here on a Friday evening recently and we LOVED the food it was really memorable, the tuna tartar was out of this world!  The vegetarian ravioli was incredible, the whole roasted cloves of garlic had me closing my eyes involuntarily.  The wine (Sauvingnon Blanc) by the glass was delish. 
My fiance loved the escargo and the seafood pasta too.

The downsides were our server- we sat inside, and were literally the closest table to the computer where the servers enter information/ hangout.  And we had to grab her several times, and waving our hands didn't work, she just didn't look like she wanted to be at work. 
The other downside is the tables being SOOOO close to each other.  I had to go the the restroom and I felt like I was putting my butt in the next table's plates!

Over all, we'd go back and sit either outside or at a different table, and HOPE for a different server.

** Update** 
I just got a very nice email from the server from that evening apologizing for our experience that evening.  I think it's very nice that Cafe Bastille/ She cares and pays attention to reviews!
Thanks Sabina
author: Nica W.

description:
I hadn't been to Cafe Bastille for some time, but after a recent lunch with my friend Deborah, I was kicking myself for forgetting how great it is.

The food is, OK by SF standards, but it is the ambience that helps remind me of what an amazing city SF is. Belden Lane is one of the many iconic mini-neighborhoods that is a little European, very urban, and is grounded in the soul of SF.

As I waited for Deborah to arrive, I spied "Suits" from the Financial District, creative-types no doubt from local design shops, and was seated between a VC meeting with a team of budding entrepeneurs (I was eaves dropping) and a software sales exec taking an iPhone conference call while she sipped her onion soup (I couldn't help but overhear). 

The alley was bustling with the sounds and sights of the City, and I was center stage at Cafe Bastille.

I can't wait to go back.
author: David I.

description:
Cafe Bastille, as well as every other eatery on the short walking block that is Belden, is one of those places that someone that has never been to France or Europe would describe as "very European."  The wait staff have accents (real or fake, I don't know, I wasn't paying attention), the walls and menu is plastered with 1920's and 1930's French liqueur ads (such as Dubonet)--the kind of stuff you find at your typical 'European interior decor' store.  The setting is fairly cozy though, with a long bench on both sides of the room, tables pressed against that with chairs on the outside and a attractive looking bar anchoring the entrance.  Lighting is soft, music is more the 'this is what Europe must be like' sort.

While I am quietly poking fun at the inauthentic authenticness of the place, I really have to say I enjoyed the dish I got a lot.  Don't bother with the expensive $20+ items as they didn't seem to be all that impressive based on my observation (granted, I didn't order one, just gandered at other people's dishes) but stick with the $14-20 items.  I got the Mussels, which were $14.25.  Based on the place, and the menu price scale, I figured I'd get a small dish with about 8 mussels on it.  Wrong.  The dish was HUGE and had dozens of mussels, all nicely prepared sitting in a tasty broth.  A side of french fries was also included (real French, I'm sure).  

For that dish alone, I give this place three stars.  Like I said, the decor was nothing to get excited about and lost points for trying to hard to be Epcot Center at Disney World.  The service was pretty good, but I really give most of the credit to the bus boys for that as they were constantly filling my water glass and were quick to clear the table.  The waitress disappeared after taking the order without even stopping by to ask me how I was enjoying my mound-o-mussels.

Overall, a nice place to go with friends if you want a nice bite to eat at semi-reasonable prices.  Get the mussels.
author: Eric M.

description: Food, around the table, was horrible. The service was slow and clumsy. Portions of the poor prepared food were small, thank god.
author: Dave C.

description:
Belden Place is like a little outdoor alleyway straight out of Europe.  too bad we were seated downstairs in the dungeon and didn't get to enjoy any of that atmosphere.

granted, we did have a large party, and that was probably the only area that could accommodate that number of people.  anyway, despite that, the service was still friendly, they never forgot about us, and the food came pretty quickly.

i ordered a.. Lola's Kiss?  (some chocolate-creme-vodka drink), which was very good, and the NY steak, which was not so good.  asked for it medium-rare, and it came out medium (a little too dry for me).  actually, four of us ordered it medium-rare, and they all came out medium.

this place is kinda like fancy french-infused comfort food with a nice atmosphere (if you're one of the lucky ones seated upstairs).
author: stefanie h.

description: Came here with a group in which they didn't honor the value of and didn't mention it, just charged full price on the bill. Mediocre food and poor service :(
author: Hannah D.

description:
Nothing makes me happier than lunch with my girls on a sunny San Francisco afternoon. Lucky for me, I had just that the other day :)

While this place was certainly a lil trek from my office near the Embarcadero, especially in heels, it was located in the cutest lil block of restaurants that I never even knew existed. Once I sat down I was told this was one of my girlfriends favorite places to eat great French food at an affordable price (since she's French I'll take her word for it).

For lunch I had a chance to sample:
- Escargots de bourgongne- My first time have escargot and I must say it wasn't bad. They had a very earthy taste but the sauce made of butter, garlic and parsley really went very well with it. Also, dip a lil bread in the sauce (as suggested by our friend and it was delish)
- Steamed mussels with bacon, tomatoes, onions served with pomme frites served with an aoli- Delicious. The pomme were perfectly crispy and the aoli went really well with it. The mussels were also very tasty, probably my favorite dish of the 3
- Steamed salmon, spinach, roasted fingerling potatoes and mushrooms in a garlic sauce- My dish. The salmon was perfectly cooked, the dish was very simple but tasty. It was also light without making me crazy full. 
- Hachis Parmentier- mashed potatoes, ground beef and cheese casserole- served with a green salad- this was good but cheese isn't one of my favorite things to eat so its hard for me to judge. But the green salad it came with was simple and tasty

Service was awesome, our waiter was super helpful and kinda cute too (the accent was definitely a plus)  ;) But then again, lunch out with my girls on a beautiful day in they city, can't really ask for much more to brighten up a workday!
author: Nadia L.

description:
Went there for dine about town this past week for dinner with my boyfriend. I have been there previously and the food did not taste so great. Decided to head back and the give the restaurant another try since the waiter was very nice. Still tasted just as bad. 
The first time I ordered a chicken dish. The chicken was dry and just tasted like unseasoned chicken. This time I had pan seared trout which turned out to be pan seared flounder. Once again, not much flavoring. Just loads of butter and a hint of lemon. The creamed spinach was probably the best part of that dish and I can get that at Trader Joe's. 
My boyfriend, who is French, ordered the Casoullet. He said the dish was not bad. 
Another thing, major stomach discomfort that lasted the whole night (till morning) on both occasions for both of us! I suspect it is all the butter they put in their food. 
For the amount of money I paid, this place was totally NOT worth it. Food was expensive, bland, drenched in butter, and hurt alot afterward.
author: Yaoyun S.

description:
I lived in Paris for a long, long time, and Cafe Bastille is the ersatz American version of the typical French bistro.  Sure, the average American's romantic vision of the Parisian bistro contains layers of charm with smarmy waitstaff, impeccible food and the leisurely meals...all part of la vie quotidienne, no?

Well, Bastille delivers excellent French bistro food with the typical French bistro atmosphere.  Belden Lane, on a nice day, is the perfect place to sit outside and transport yourself to any european city.  Once inside, Bastille becomes exactly what it is -- a great bistro.  Don't expect friendly, attentive waitstaff...because you don't get them in a French bistro, and you won't find them here.

I actually believe Bastille to be one of the more authentic French dining experiences in San Francisco.  They kicked to the curb the American notion of what French dining should be and brought to life what it really is.
author: Aaron G.

description:
It's Bastille Day, so we had to go here for lunch. The alley was jamming and definitely something to experience. I can definitely see myself feeling the need to go experience the alley. Although today it's hot and sunny, my co-diner mentioned that this place is also great when foggy and nasty and you want onion soup and casserole. So, that's good to know, with the abundance of days like that, I'm always looking for a place that fits that need.

The food is quintessentially French. I had a the black sausage with mashed potatoes and apples. When reading the menu, I got the sensation that being adventurous was definitely the way to go, and that idea paid off. The sausage was delicious, and now I get to pat myself on the back all day for eating blood sausage. The desert was great and so was the espresso.

The server was a wee bit attitudinal, but since he was a bonafide Euro (though not French), I guess that's ok.

Definitely a scene, the food is good, the alley is great, la la la, I'll be back when the mood hits.
author: Dibital N.

description: Terrible! The placed my group in the basement and some guest returned their food. It was so bad they didn't want anything else.
author: Francophones S.

description: Had the mushroom and cream crepe today with a small side salad. The crepe was divine! The mushrooms and cream were very tasty and the salad had a good flavor. Good service, good prices--will definitely return!
author: Tasha L.

description:
I have been coming to Cafe Bastille since the first day it opened and I was in elementary school. I recommend this fine establishment to anyone with great taste and an appetite for wonderful food. My favorite dish (and one I always recommend to friends) is the Coq Au Vin. Forgive the crude and vulgar remark, but eating at Cafe Bastille feels like you have the Larousse Gastronomique in your mouth. Simply delicious!
This place is really good to bring your close friends for a nice dinner, and drinks afterwards. The bar is in the top dining room next to the live performance alcove and stocked with the finest liquor. 

Tip: If you found you have eaten too much, ask the waiter or bartender for a "Trou Normand".
author: Guillaume J.

description: I have been here twice and the food  each time was amazing!.. Only giving 4 stars because last time the waiter was not very attentive.  Love the escargot and the bone marrow is amazing.
author: Kristin K.

description:
Wow.  Last night was crazy hot in SF.  The kind of weather where you just want to dine al fresco in no sleeves.  Which never happens in this foggy, windy city.  Usually the icy wind whips up in the afternoon and the layers must be applied liberally.

So, it was the perfect evening for a little outdoor dining on Belden Place.  Plouf is my favorite, but having done that recently I was interested in something slightly different.  The hostess at Petrino offered a table - I told her I wanted to eat outdoors.  She said she had a nice indoor table near the open window, but that did not fit my criteria.  After getting the brash hard sell from the hostess at Brindisi, and seeing all the heavy pasta and meat dishes at the other restaurants, I settled in at a small table at Cafe Bastille.

Their menu is nice but looked too heavy for a hot night.  Blood sausage and the other offerings were just going to be too much.  The waitress approached and I wistfully told her that due to the hot weather I had just been looking for a simple salade nicoise, which was not on the menu.  And having lived in France I wasn't sure that the chef would happily whip something up on the spot that was not listed.

Well, my dear waitress said - they serve it for lunch, let me ask the chef.  He may have what he needs.  Lo and behold - a short while later I was presented with the most beautiful salade nicoise I had ever seen.  Oddly I could not find a single leaf of lettuce, but was extremely satisfied with the lovely green beans, tiny but flavorful olives, egg, potato, cucumber and large portion of seasoned and seared ahi tuna.  Oh, don't forget the adorable little cornichons.  I did my very best to polish it off but the serving was huge.  I left absolutely satisfied and happy, feeling perhaps even a bit like a celebrity because they made a custom dish just for me.

Thanks to the staff at Cafe Bastille for accommodating my request.  You truly made my evening and next time my boss is asking for his favorite salad, I know just exactly where to go.  Merci bien!!
author: Sara L.

description:
My friend and I decided to try this place out last Friday because it was on the Dine About Town list.  We both ordered the french onion soup.  She had the crouque madame and I had the special pasta with blue cheese sauce.

The soup was not good.  It certainly didn't taste like any other french onion soup I have had here or in France.  It was bland instead of a rich broth.  Outback Steakhouse' was much better.  I finished mine, but she hardly touched her's.  I was disappointed that the server who cleared the soup bowls didn't notice that her's was barely touched.

For our entrees, her sandwich was very cheesy and there should be more ham.  The only complaint I had with my pasta was that it was too cheesy, but that is easily remedied.  We paid about $55 total (including tax and tip) for lunch.  The money could've been spent better.
author: SF P.

description: The bread came cold, and the Sole wasn't properly cleaned. I ended up with a bite that tasted like complete crap. The servers were generally rude and incompetent. The portion size was small, and the presentation was terrible. The cost was way too high for all of that. What a terrible place.
author: Brian S.

description:
The French have some things on their menus that would make East Asians and Southeast Asians double-take. Having both regions in the family, dim sum and Cafe Bastille are big hits; the French in-laws come here when craving some homeland food. The blood sausage with the apple compote (?) is a favorite staple at Bastille. Just guzzle down one of the assorted alcohol options from an extensive list if you have to tough it out; great bar selections.

The lunch options are better...would hit up one of the other resaurants on the alley for dinner.
author: Tanya P.

description:
I came to visit San Francisco with my grandmother, from Paris. Cafe Bastille is a little piece of France in the beautiful city of San Francisco!

The food was amazing and our server was adorable! I will definitely be back soon!
author: FRANCOUR V.

description:
Had dinner here last night at a friend's request. Having no need to go down to this part of town anymore I had no clue where we were going. I then realized it was THE Cafe Bastille. That was surprise #1.

Suprise #2 came when the hostess who was about to seat us said OH HEY! Upon close examination I realized it was a girl I had known since the age of 2, gone to school with for all "13" grades, had a falling out of sorts with, heard things about her post HS life, and not spoken to or seen in 4 years. Awkward? A bit. We said hello, and caught up for a few minutes then the managers sent us complimentary drinks because we knew someone who worked there.

Surprise #3 the food. Very simple but nice french food. I ordered the salmon, which is not normal as I don't usually go for it but something called me. It was nice, flaky, not fatty, but still moist. I have a goat cheese problem, which made the pastry puff wrapped goat cheese part of the draw. Friends ordered the Steak and Frits, and the Potato/Beef casserole with salad I cannot pronounce. 

Surprisingly still, it made me miss street cafes in NY that I spent time in in college. One of the few times I'll admit that I missed NY.
author: Niki M.

description: Oh, there.   .   .  We 8 (88) at the Spanish Basque place next door, and bumpt into the Lees.
author: Clifford L.

description:
Went here for my birthday on Friday night. 

The service was stellar, very attentive and friendly. They didn't mind that the last person in our party of 12 didn't arrive until 7:51 for a 7pm reservation. They brought out a birthday cake and sang at the end, which was nice. Loved the atmosphere/ambience.

Food was a bit of a disappointment; my entree was fairly subpar (I don't even think they brought out the right thing); the onion soup was quite good (although I wanted to be blown away, which I was not); ditto for the flourless chocolate cake.

While I probably wouldn't go back here, as there are so many other French places in the city I want to try, I would still highly recommend it for a big event.
author: Mark A.

description:
Would have gotten 4+, but their Creme Brule ruined it!

The meal was good but the Creme Brulee had almost NO TOPPING at all! In addition, it tasted burnt. I know what you're thinking, it's Creme Brule (Burnt Cream), it's SUPPOSED to be burnt. Make no mistake, I want it to taste of burnt sugar (yum-my!) but this tasted of smoke. It didn't go well with the rich vanilla & cognac flavors & was frankly (even if the flavor was purposeful) too overpowering.

Aside from the dessert, which I had to get off my chest first, I enjoyed their Metropole cocktail (although my boyfriend did not care for it) & their Chicken Liver Pate appetizer was excellent!

We also had the Salmon Ceviche appetizer, which had lots of potential but was missing a needed flavor for balance. It had some oil drizzled on it & needs a flavor to cut it & set off the fish. Something salty or with zing!

Last appetizer was the Foie Gras. It was a pate form, which I have not had before, but having loved seared Foie Gras, I could not eat this. It was served in a wedge, cold, along with a hot pastery filled with rich cheese. The Foie Gras was too rich on it's own to put on top of this, so I tried it with the table bread. Hmmm...I think the cold part was the problem - it was like trying to eat straight butter & made me quesy. I imaging it's a matter of taste - the boyfriend loved it & finished it for me happily. (*Okay, I have since had this pate-style foie gras somewhere else & apparently I just can't stomach it prepared this way. So if you know you DO like it this way, you'll probably like it here)
author: M B.

description:
The onion soup was fine, not perfect.  The outdoor seating was comfortable enough, but the table pretty wildly uneven.  The croque monsieur was good, and so was the croque madame.  Good, not perfect.

But the service was really bad.

And the place was deserted - this is the day before thanksgiving - so no excuses on being busy.  

And while this does nothing to undermine the authentic french bistro experience, it does tend to detract from lunch when you're trying to get back to the office.

Que sera....
author: Jacob R.

description:
I found out about Belden Place on-line. Since it was NYE and my man is French I thought this would be a fun place for dinner. We had no reservations and started skimming the menus at the various restaurants here. We chose to eat here since the price was the most reasonable. $45 for 3 courses on NYE!

My man was a bit disappointed that no one spoke french but he had the salmon and I had the Filet Mignon. He loved both plates...lol! I asked for my filet cooked well and it came out still alive...my man being the love that he is switched plates with me. The salmon that I ended up eating was delicious! Dessert was yummy too...i think we both had creme brulee. 

I want to go again when the weather is nicer!
author: Diana B.

description:
My advice for a good experience on Belden Place is this ... go to Belden for (in order of importance)
(1) Being swept away into a completely different (in a good way) San Francisco scene while dining al fresco (especially on a warm day)
(2) Enjoying long conversations with the people you love over a glass of wine
(3) People watching.  An interesting mix of tourists, the FiDi crowd (on weekdays), and foreigners (Europeans).
(4) The food

Notice the placement of food at the bottom of the list and the absence of service/price from the list.  My only real exception to this list is Cafe Bastille (okay, maybe my other exception is B44).  I know, I'm disgusting and I happen to like the taste of a cow's stomach lining and Cafe Bastille happens to have a pretty tasty andouillette which puts food as #1 on that above list.  The prices here are also the most reasonable of all the establishments.
author: Jean A.

description:
3 to 3 1/2 Stars

After trying Fingale, Le Charm, Chapeau!, Clementine, Cote Sud, ...etc...

This place is not bad...If I had choices I would go to the ones above. The service was spotty. One of my poor dining member didn't get her dish 15 minutes after all 3 of us! we did ask them twice during the 15 mins.

The dishes were average. However the if you want to dine outside in the alley. It does add a new dimension to the dining atmosphere.

Some should take picture of the restaurant's alley shot during the nite. That should be the "first photo"
author: S.K. Y.

description: We had dinner at Café Bastille - the food was good, the service was friendly and helpful and decent prices. Their warm bread is mouth watering and we end up eating two whole baskets, for entrees we both had the Roasted Salmon with olive tapenade and ratatouille and for dessert Cognac Crème Brule - although, we wished a bit more cognac flavor. Our French friends like this place to celebrate Bastille Day and watch games. This place is great for groups as it has another dinning room downstairs.
author: Gigi W.

description:
What a cute little bistro!  Luckily, we got seats outside during the summer, on one of those rare days when San Francisco is bright and warm.  I'm sure the seating area violates several city fire codes, but it's bursting with energy and made me nostalgic for European sidewalk cafes.

I ordered the buffalo mozarella and tiger shrimp salad, which was absolutely delicious.  The shrimp was grilled, smoky and tender.  Portions are fairly small, but great for a light lunch with coworkers.
author: Elaine Z.

description:
What the hell happened?  This place used to be awesome!

I dragged my friend, Herr Doktor here with promises of tasty French food.  We ordered a terrine de foie gras and a dish of mussels to share.

The terrine, my friends, was a blob of pate the likes of which you can get at any grocery store.  Not that it wasn't good, but it was wholly unremarkable and tasted molecule for molecule like what I buy at Trader Joe's.

The mussels were off.  Off, off, off.  They had not been chilled or prepared properly and tasted just on the verge of turning.  We ate them anyway - no one got sick, but they were anything but fresh.  

Not to mention they sat us in the downstairs in the very back corner and promptly forgot about us.  Placed us in an oubliette*, if you will.



* Main Entry: oubliette 
Pronunciation: "-blE-'et
Function: noun
Etymology: French, from Middle French, from oublier to forget, from (assumed) Vulgar Latin oblitare, frequentative of Latin oblivisci to forget -- more at OBLIVION
: a dungeon with an opening only at the top 

(aren't I fancy?)
author: Frankie D.

description:
I love this restaurant: great ambiance, great food, and down a cute little alleyway. What more can you ask for?

Inside:  the restaurant is a little dark inside, which provides a nice, intimate setting.  We've been here several times and everything is always great.  The last time we went the waiter was happy to suggest a wine that went splendidly with our meal.  The pork chops and scallops were wonderful.  My son was with us and the chef was actually willing to fry some shrimp for him, which I thought was so nice (He's not a really young kid, just a little picky. I wasn't even going to ask, but my friend knew our waiter).  For dessert I had the chocolate mousse which melted in my mouth.  

Their french fries alone are worth stopping in at this cute little restaurant.  I love eating outside, especially at night under the twinkly lights.  Such a great, intimate atmosphere.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Came here in January to celebrate a friend's birthday.  The decor is cute, very cozy with whimsical posters and pictures covering the walls.  They had outdoor seating, which would be perfect for a warm summer night.  We were seated downstairs since we had 10 people in our party.  We occupied half of the downstairs eating area.  Our friends had a little toddler and requested a hi-chair.  But, they only had one available and the table next to us was using it.  The waiter told us they were leaving soon, so we could have then. 

It was also Dine about Town, so I went with their 3 course menu.  For my first course, I had the salmon tartare.  This was OK, nothing really memorable or exciting.  My hubby got the french onion soup and it was a bit salty and not cheesy enough.  For the main course, I had the duck confit cassoulet.  It came with sausages and white beans.  What a disappointment!  The overall dish was so salty that I couldn't taste anything else.  And it wasn't just my dish, everyone else that had the cassoulet complained about the overwhelming amount of salt they put in the dish.  My friend said it was so salty it stung his chapped lips.  LOL. Hubby got the coq au vin and was so excited about it, but oh man, what a disappointment.  The chicken was so dried, it reminded me of the leftover meat (that no one eats) from my mom's soup that had been cooking for 4 hours.  He couldn't even finish his dinner and kinda picked at it with his fork all night.  Finally, our dessert came and I either had the chocolate tart or creme brulee.  I tried both and they were fine and probably the best part of our dinner.  On a positive note, we had a drink at the bar before dinner and the bartender was really nice and even made my friend's drink stronger because it was her birthday.  I had the coconut mojito and it was good.  But overall, I was disappointed with the food, and won't be coming back since there are so many other french restaurants in the city to try.
author: Kat M.

description: After spending some time in France i'm a sucker for French food and Cafe Bastille fit the bill. It's a cozy little place and I really liked the decor with the French signs. My waitress was French which certainly didn't hurt:) I went with the escargot bourgogne to start. The escargot was very well cooked but was a bit overdressed with the garlic/pesto mix. For my entree I went with the duck confit. The meat was nice and tender although I would have like the skin slightly less cooked. Overall a nice place that I would try again in the future.
author: David P.

description:
Came for dinner on a Friday evening with 2 co-workers.

Rather than do their DAT menu we opted to share appetizers and desserts and get our own entrees.

Appetizers: 
- Chicken pate:delicious! i haven't had too much pate in my day (...yet) but I really enjoyed eating this
- Frites w/ garlic aioli: i freakin' love frites. and I love garlic, so this was a perfect combination.  It's really garlicky, but if you're like me you don't mind at all.  Heck I would have eaten the aioli straight....
- Mussels: we split these as an appetizer since we all wanted to try some.  The mussels were indeed tasty and the sauce/soupy/broth was delicious though a bit too salty.  It was good to split, and I really enjoyed dipping bread into the leftover broth.

Entree:
I got the scallops which were cooked perfectly.  It was just the right amount too (4 scallops).  Unfortunately, I feel like my tastebuds were still recovering from the too-salty mussels broth and the scallop dish tasted bland.  I still thought it was tasty.

My coworkers got the coq au vin and the lamb shank which I tasted.  Both were yummy but again, a bit heavy on the salt for our taste.

Dessert:
Flourless chocolate cake was absolutely heavenly.  It wasn't too sweet and really let the chocolate-y ness of the cake come out at the same time.  Perfect.

Cognac creme brulee: yummy!  it was also very good but the sugar "crust" on top wasn't so crispy and I couldn't taste too much of the cognac.

Overall a very good dinner.  Service was nice, not too fast or slow.  And they refilled our bread.  YUM.  I recommend this place for small groups since the tables are cramped together outside.
author: Naoko M.

description:
Have you walked down Beldin Place lately?  It's like walking down Broadway except that they're hawking food and not naked people.  "Hungry?"  "Would you like to come in?"  "Want to look at our menu?"

Anyway, having read reviews for this place, my friend and I made our way to Cafe Bastille.  My reaction on leaving after dinner?  They had a really good band playing that night.   

Don't get me wrong.  It wasn't horrible.  The crabcakes were good, but the rest of the food was just...average.  My friend had the Scallops and I had the Coq au vin and they were passable, but I was expecting something more.  Then, we finished the chocolate cake which was a bit bland.  

Good atmosphere.  Okay service.  But the food just didn't wow me for the cost.  

I might go to have a drink there, but I'd probably pass on dinner there as a first choice.
author: H C.

description: I don't believe I've ever eaten at Cafe Bastille before but then again, most of the places along Belden Lane blend together for me.  I headed to Cafe Bastille last week with a large group and we had a set menu which was very reasonably priced and decent food.  We all had the onion soup which was good.  I wouldn't say this is a "go out of your way to eat here" place but it was fun for a group.
author: Blake B.

description:
Surprising to see numerous positive reviews of this place.  The European street patio cafe has great atmosphere, but disappointing food.

My Croque Monsieur was a thin piece of Oscar Meyer ham and tasteless cheese on something that was close to Wonder Bread.  Perhaps I've been spoiled by my artisan fare in the city, but I was expecting a decent piece of ham with Greyuere cheese on a great crustry bread.

The pomme frites were also sad - these had some sort of coating on them like the Burger King fries a few years back.

Great location, but needs a serious upgrade in ingredients.
author: Scott C.

description: With our office move closer to this restaurant, I decided to give it another try. The $25 pre fixe deal is a steal! Everything was super delicious and the Friday night live jazz was oh so romantic. A good first date kinda place. :)
author: Su K.

description: Did I say "strawberry tart"? That sums it up.
author: Joan S.

description:
It was my turn to play cruise director for the Bay Area, Mini-Trinity College Reunion/Bachelorette Party.  I pointed out the French quarter on our walk from the Ferry Building Taylor's outpost to The Other Em's car in the Tenderloin, via Chinatown (Happy New Year!), Nob Hill and the Fi Di.  Even my San Fran friends had never heard of Belden Place! Since patio seating was a must this long weekend, we'd fuel up with French brunch and coffee at Cafe Bastille before hiking around the city on our last day together.  

I'd drink dishwater out of those big bowls French restaurants serve coffee in, but I don't drink coffee, so I ordered a hot chocolate. If by hot chocolate you mean steamed milk... luckily, I had G, for whom foam is priceless, sitting across from me.  

Added bonus: I got to eavesdrop on the Berkeley Rep subscribers sitting next to us!  

The bottom line: Next time, I'd make an exception and order the enfianced's lattes -- served with a small square of chocolate to stir in -- or just call it a day with les moules et frites.

ERF
author: Emily F.

description:
Cafe Bastille certainly brings a fun bistro feel to the Financial District tucked away in a cute alley with lots of outdoor seating.  The food is fine but overpriced.  Maybe it is more of a deal at lunch, but dinner was pricey for what you got. 

I did fall in love with the goat cheese appetizer.  For $10, you get a huge block of goat cheese with a raisin compote, a sprinkling of olives and baguette toast.   All the entrees I sampled (lamb shank, coq au vin, and grilled portobello mushroom) were good but nothing amazing.   As suspected, the vegetarian dish was the most disappointingly executed.  But their cognac creme brulee was prepared to perfection and worth every bit of its $6 cost.

We did enjoy the Friday night jazz trio accompanying our meal.  They were the perfect volume and set a nice mood.

I'd go back to give them a look for lunch as the lunch menu looks more appealing to me and my wallet.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Oh Hell, why not...

Ode to Cafe Bastille; how I love thee.
Bastille, how I write of your food and wine.
I, along the European alley 
would go, to enjoy a glass of Bordeaux.

Your crab cakes, escargot...did I mention
The wonderful Bordeaux?  Your Pinot's 'eah'.
How I am so emo without your food
And of course, your spicy, yet light Bordeaux.

Oh Bordeaux, Oh Bordeaux, I mean Bastille...
I love your lamb, your duck, your beef and your--
cake.  I love sitting outside your tables
conversing with friends over French food and wine.
author: Billy C.

description:
What a great place for a mid-week lunch.  When you're all cooped up in an office looking out to a beautiful sunny day, there's nothing quite like venturing out, meeting a good friend(s) for lunch, grab a table outside, a cold iced tea, and a french hot dog.  

Perfection... like gum in an ATM vestibule.  (if you happen to know old Friends episodes)
author: Kelly K.

description:
Great lunch takeout... especially for training meetings...

Around the table the choices varied from crepes to coq au vin, to my sausage with pommes frites. All great choices... and all just make me want to wander over here some bright, sunny afternoon and sit around enjoying lunch (possibly with a glass of wine... depending on how much work must be done)... and imagine myself in some place far more exotic than just down the street from my office...
author: Jordan Y.

description: I really enjoyed eating at Cafe Bastille for dinner on Friday night.  I like Belden Lane in general. It feels like you are dining in Paris when you sit outside under the heat lamps on Belden Lane. We had a late dinner and enjoyed the live jazz music from inside. I ordered the pasta special which was Mahi Mahi fettucine with a tomato based sauce. The food was decent but not too memorable the atmosphere is definitely what makes this place appealing.
author: Debbie C.

description: For many years this has been my favorite place to eat Quiche.  Today I decided to go downtown and get a slice.  The special was Ham & Brie...yummy right?  Not today..the Quiche was filled with cheese and very little egg.  I told the waiter and he just said well brie is a strong cheese and I said yes but it was all cheese and no egg.  The tall pretty boy waiter did nothing to adjust my tab but did say he would speak to the chef but never came back to me.  Next time I will think twice about going back to Cafe Bastille.,
author: Ricky B.

description: I had a green salad which they through in a couple of tiny pickles, which zested up an ordinary salad a little bit. I Ordered the Mesculun plate, which is steamed mussels. They do it two ways i opted for the white wine broth and they were amazing.I didn't have a huge appetite when i got there but after tasting the first few mussels i couldn't resist.  They are served with endless fries and some garlic aoili dipping sauce that was tasty.  The next time i go back to Belden Alley i will stop here exclusively for the mussels. Nice beer selection, their one draft beer was french and it was awesome
author: Stephen C.

description:
Last week I went to Cafe Bastille with my family, we where planning on going to another restaurant, but as soon as we passed by Belden we where hooked by the charm of that place... and as soon as we saw Cafe Bastille we decided to go there, it doesnt look very frenchie, but let me tell u somenthing... the food is MAGNIFIQUE!!

We order the prix fixe menu, and its great, we had the Onion Soup, which in flavor its delicious, the only thing I didnt like a lot its that it contained a lot of bread, then we had the bouef bourguignon which was amazing, very well served, and excellent in flavor, my mother had the steak tartare which was a very generous portion, and very flavorfull, and for dessert I had the chocolate mousse, exquisite presentation and flavor!!

I recommend Cafe Bastille for a very good experience, great food, great place and mostly great prices!!
author: Laura D.

description: Merry Christmas to us!  We received a groupon for a dinner for two at Cafe Bastille. The restaurant is located in an alley that is reminiscent of Little Italy in Boston.  It is difficult to see the names of the restaurants on the buildings and a nice hostess walked us over to Cafe Bastille, which is towards the back end of the alley.  Walking in, I felt the atmosphere was immediately 'stuffy.'  People stare as folks walk through the door.  It is extremely quiet and the wait staff seem minimally interested in providing you with recommendations.  I got the meat and cheese casserole which was good for the mere fact that it was doused in cheese.  It was a bit salty, but with me, you can't go wrong with loading cheese on a plate.  My hubby got duck confit and it was devoid of taste.  It is pretty bad when he picks at his meal, and he ends up bringing it home to the dogs.  Of course, you know the drill with groupon dinners, you still end up paying  tip and tax.   We decided to skip the dessert and go home to surprise the dogs lol.
author: Steph W.

description:
This was the only place open at Belden Place for lunch on Saturday so we had no choice.
I liked the lunch special... soup, salad, entry and beverage for $19.95.
Had the French Onion Soup, Ahi Quesh and a glass of Chadonnay. 
The French Onion Soup had a lot of flavor but the Quesh... not so much.
I won't go back to this particular restaurant but I will go back to Belden Place to try out the other places.
author: Grace P.

description:
Compared to other French restaurants , you can get much better. The service was decent but the food is not as good as has been suggested in earlier reviews. Their pasta was not cooked properly and their sauce was lacking some flavor. Also, a friend ordered the steak and while it was OK, the presentation was not there either.

I did like the location however, it is very nice!
author: Andrew F.

description: My review won't be too thorough....that's because I left before actually eating here.  And here's why....I show up at lunchtime with a friend and sat down....waited for about 5 minutes before a waiter finally came out.  No water was offered, no bread, nothing.  The waiter eventually started reading the specials of the day, and by started I mean just that....he kind of trailed off and never really finished before walking away.  And the last straw for me was trying to get his attention to order a couple glasses of wine....you think I got it?  Hell no.  We ended up leaving....and quite frankly I don't think the waiter even noticed.  Oh and just in case you are wondering....it wasn't busy....it was just us and one other table...seriously.
author: Brian S.

description:
I should have read the Yelp reviews before going here to get recommendations on what to order because I ordered very very wrong.  I had the tomato and mozzarella salad, which they were nice enough to accompany with some extra salad greens when I asked, but unfortunately, the entire thing tasted like nothing.  It had grilled shrimp on top which also tasted like nothing.  

And to top it all off, I think the chef forgot to put the basil on top.   Tomato and mozzarella is like a 2 legged tripod without basil.  Or maybe it's that tomato, mozarella, and basil is one those ultra ultimate combinations.  Either way, there was no basil on my salad.

So I wrote what I would consider a pretty mean review for me - yet you're probably wondering why the 3 stars?  Well, we were a party of 20, and the waiter still put up with us with a smile, that deserves 3 stars all on its own.
author: Audrey T.

description:
J'adore! 

We came on a Friday night with good weather, so the tables outside were crowded. Not wanting to wait, we took an immediately available table inside by the jazz trio. Food was well-prepared and our service was low-key but fine. I ordered the grilled salmon with polenta, which was fantastic. Good spot for a date or dinner to catch up with a friend.  A little more expensive than a casual dinner, but not unreasonable. Wouldn't bring a group here. I can't imagine what it might be like on Bastille Day - it's not very big.
author: Jill C.

description: Cafe Bastille is a nice small French Cafe. The food is nothing to get too excited about, but is still very good none the less. Once you smell the bread, you know that it will be delicious. The appetizers and entrees are good, nice taste, but not amazing. The staff seems nice enough, the bar is really lack luster and not too many choices. The upstairs is also very small, but it seems to have a downstairs if it gets packed and it has outdoor seating for lunch. I would recommend lunch over dinner here, but its good whenever you go.
author: Sebastien D.

description:
Shatangi likes the French food. Good menu and service. Great for groups but too noisy for a date. Not a great place to take kids.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
For my 100th REVIEW - this is dedicated to great French food. Or even the French Alley - Belden Lane.

Cafe Bastille is a Belden Lane gem...the 1st restaurant from the Bush Street entrance, they serve an excellent lunch/dinner selection with very reasonable prices. Try the salmon with mashed potatoes topped with garlic puree - it's simply delicious.
author: Sav B.

description:
Went during the France v. Togo World cup game. Many drunken France fans, few drunken Togo fans, and many, many drunken fans of being drunken. Regardless, we (3 of us) got a table in about 5 minutes during lunch. Had the tomato and mozzarella salad. (light, fresh, and amazing motz). Crab salad looked great, but didn't get a bite. :-( Roast chicken dish smelled and looked amazing but, alas, didn't get a bite of that either. Though I heard they were both delicious.

I felt like I was back in France...I barely heard any English coming from the tables around us and the waiters all took cigarette breaks down the alley. Ah, mais oui.
author: Ali L.

description: I always love to come to this restaurant for some good French comfort food. It's one of the best places to get ratatouille (like mom used to make...if she was French). I love the onion soup (which is not too salty compared to other French restaurants around the Bay). Also, I love the cozy atmosphere and the live jazz band on the weekends. The only thing that keeps me from giving this place 5 stars: the acoustics is not very good (a.k.a. it gets noisy), especially when the live jazz band plays...
author: Melinda C.

description:
I was pretty disappointed; the jalapeno vinaigrette on the crab salad doesn't work - the crab salad itself was "meh" - the tomatoes weren't fresh and were squishy, and the crab tasted like it had been previously frozen.  The frites with aioli were way oversalted, and the aioli didn't taste right.

Service was speedy & friendly and the wine was good, though.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
I love outdoor seating, french food and tables close enough so you can hear your neighbor.  The alleyway-chic ambiance at Cafe Bastille reminded me of a little street in Paris (rue mouffetard) where I would eat my steak au poivre and people watch. 

Yes, there are tourists but who cares? I lovedit!
author: Krissy M.

description:
I love Belden place.  It really feels like Paris to me.  I chose Cafe Bastille for my birthday a couple years ago, and I was not disappointed.

I don't think that we had a reservation, but it didn't matter, because I think it was a Thursday night, and it was only my husband and I.  Would have liked to dine outside, but this September was without Indian Summer.  To my surprise, we were lead in side to a table near the bar to see a small jazz combo setting up.  They were very good, and thankfully not so load as to inhibit conversation.

This was also a birthday of firsts.  This is the first place where I learned to love Walnuts.  We ordered the lovely cheese and fruit plate as an appetizer, which is one of the things that sticks out most in my memory.  There was this creamy and wonderfully tangy goat cheese that paired very nicely with their candied walnuts, which were a far cry from the dry almost rancid ones that have always kept me from liking them.  I got the Grilled Salmon (which is different from the version on their menu now ... no prawns) which was perfectly cooked and was in every way comparable to the salmon I had in Paris.  My husband ordered the fillet Mignon with foie gras and frites.  This was also the my first time trying foie gras, which always sounded gross to me, but it was smooth and velvety, almost like the goat cheese, but more savory.  The steak was juicy and flavorful.

Vaguely remember ordering dessert ... flourless chocolate cake for me, and a colonel for the guy (lime sorbet with vodka).  I'm sure it was tasty, but it was two years ago so ... Ooops.  Maybe I will go back, and try again.

Ok ... here is my obligatory plug for us flourless folk.  French food is always a little difficult to navigate, since they want to give you a baguette with everything.  However, looking over their current menu, I see a few things that seem safe.  As usual, ask for no bread, and inquire about the thickening agent in sauces, and avoid pasta.  My dinner here was before I knew for sure that I couldn't have Gluten products, so I didn't ask.  If I ever get the chance return, I will certainly update this review with staff responses/attitudes upon being asked.
author: Karly L.

description:
This restaurant is located in a very European-like alley with four other French and Italian restaurants.  One of my bfs took me here for a very late birthday dinner last night.   When we arrived, there was only outdoor seating immediately available so we sat right next to their heat lamp.  The host and waitress were both very gracious and assured us a couple of times that if we got too cold, they would move us in right away.  

We started with two appetizers: foie gras and the escargot.  I wasn't...well never was....a fan of the escargot.  I can't feel happy knowing I'm eating snail.  The foie gras is highly recommended.  It was a nice generous portion and it was very good.  It was served with candied walnuts and pear with a port reduction. YUM-O!  I selected the salmon as an entree and friend had the coq au vin pasta.  My salmon probably could have been more moist but the sauce and the mushroom were amazing.  Friend really enjoyed the coq au vin...I had a small piece but can't really remember it.  The service was great.  The waitress and host checked on us numerous times and made sure our water was filled.  The location itself is really small and crowded.  I can assume it's pretty happening on a Friday night.  

We discovered from our waitress that the owner of Bastille also owns Plouf an B44.  I'd like to try the other places.  This is a really cute area to take a date; not too quiet where it can be frighteningly uncomfortable but fun enough to enjoy the scene when there's no chatter going on.
author: Jess C.

description:
I came for lunch, and left wanting to pretend as a French...person.  I ordered a croque madame, as it is just about the only French dish I know how to cook, and I figured it would an interesting way to compare my skills to theirs.  The appetizer bread was quite good, and got me excited for the sandwich.

The croque madame itself was excellent.  It was prepared a little differently than I  learned it; I make it open faced on one piece of bread, they put the ham between two pieces, and topped it with the egg and white sauce.  But I'm going to assume their way is right.  In any case, it was nom-nom.  The salad that came with it was pretty meh, but I could care less.

Bonus points for making me believe everyone that worked there was actually French.  There is the possibility that they weren't French.  Perhaps they were just students practicing their French on unsuspecting patrons.  But I found it entertaining.
author: Robert S.

description:
I've been to this place twice and both times the food was pretty good. Not spectacular, but definitely affordable for French food. On Valentine's day they have a prix fixe menu which is pretty filling. 

The restaurant is in the alley and parking is horrendous. If you can't find street parking during the first pass, then just go to a garage.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Bastille has always been a good experience in my ten years in SF.  From the midday lunches during the workweek, quiet dinners, or the occasional late night parties downstairs w/ great house music, its all bonne at Bastille.

I recently hosted a dinner party and post-dinner cocktail party on a Saturday night, and was pleased with how easy they made the whole thing.  With a prixe fix menu, a good selection of french food/wine (and tasty too), and the european feel, the whole experience was excellent.  Dinner was accompanied by a smooth, live three-piece jazz ensemble.  After dinner we headed upstairs to the bar, where they let us bump our own music until they shut down at 1230am.  How cool is that?!

The alley feel also gives it the feeling of being a bistro on a side street of Paris, with a european staff and clientele, its a different kind of dining experience in SF.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I've been to Cafe Bastille a number of times. Their menu is very standard SF French bistro fare. Entree selection is your usual: lamb shank, salmon, coq au vin, steak, and duck. 

They do quite well with what I usually order...mussels marinere and pomme frites. They are generous with their mussels, which are cooked to pillow plump perfection. Frites are done nicely.

Basically, the food is fine. It's not a bad choice if you're in the mood for a casual spot for French fare. The only real downsides are spotty service and the hosts trying to pull potential diners. Very annoying and at times condescending. Not as aggressive as those in North Beach, but still...
author: Debbie T.

description:
With more than a hundred reviews, what more can I say?

How about:

It's a great place to dine al fresco during those rare warm evenings in San Francisco.

The variety in the menu is a reason to come. Blood sausages and escargot is what we ordered during a recent visit.

Unusual cocktails. Maybe a little too unusual. I had a coconut-flavored mojito. Um... mint and coconut don't quite mix.
author: Wella L.

description:
went for dinner tonight.

I'll echo the other reviewers that say go here for the ambiance, not the food.  Buddy and I had the Steak and Lamb shank respectively, and neither was up to snuff.  Lamb was a bit dry.  Steak was just a horrible cut.
author: David R.

description:
Well, my friends all enjoyed this restaurant when we went out.  I would have to say the food is averages (but not a disappointment), atmosphere is nice, and the service is good.  This is a good place (and area) to go if you are with a huge group of friends who are picky and don't know where to eat.

Reservations was a little odd though, but friendly...
author: Adam S.

description:
OK, I know it's kind of touristy. But I just spent three weeks in Europe, and this place is the closest thing I can find to the European restaurant scene. I love Belden Alley, packed with restaurants and patrons.

The food was also outstanding. The steak was fantastic. And the foie gras and french onion soup was great as well. And the manager was authentic french -- we even exchanged a few works in French.

Great place.
author: Evan G.

description:
I have been here numerous times. Belden Place is a bit of a zoo. If you can get past the awkward tourists looking for 'French food' the food is decent, but nothing special. 

As for French staples, the Hachis Parmentier is just like Maman used to make. The escargot are delicious and the onion soup not bad.

Don't forget the dessert: the Isle Flottant is a nice light end to dinner.
author: Akasha A.

description:
It was lunch time and we were starving, and happened to come by Belden Place and Cafe Bastille. So, we ambled in.

I love crepes! And I love deserts! So, I put one and one together and, voila, decided to screw lunch and go for a freaking awesome desert crepe instead - you know, the kind they have on Paris street corners with sugar and a hint of lime or Grand Marnier on it. The kind that you can stuff in your mouth while walking with your arms full of stuff.

Not. They didn't have any! I was totally disappointed, so instead got a desert that consisted of an almond meringue and some freaking good sauce! Wow. Glad they didn't have the desert crepe. This was the bomb. Combined with an espresso, it kept me going until dinner, when I went to another place in South Beach, but suddenly got the urge for a Mexican Hot Chocolate instead of their meal. Will write about that one later.
author: barry s.

description:
Overall, Cafe Bastille is good. The food is good, the service is good, and the atmosphere is, well, good. I recommend the scallops and the endive salad. Some of the group found the food to be just okay, and we thought the place was a little too "French," like the kind of place non-French people go to and feel that this is the real deal. 

Cafe Bastille is good though, have I mentioned that?
author: Jamie C.

description:
Cafe Bastille is a typical "petite brasserie"  restaurant. To me it's like going to Paris (I was born there) and back, sparing me the price of a ticket.

It's been now five years that I happily go to cafe Bastille as often as I can, to feel a bit at home, enjoy their Parisian menu and their super professional service. Thanks you guys for always welcoming us!
author: Del D.
