description: I had a Groupon coupon for this restaurant and decided to try it out, we had looked at the website and was hoping to eat inside.   We arrived a half hour early for our 6 pm reservation and since  hardly anyone was there  they said they would seat  us,,,even though there were several tables empty indoors  they insisted that we either sit downstairs alone or outside in the patio where only one other table was occupied.   we asked to be seated at a table for four (even though there was just two of us)  since the place was empty and the tables for two were quite small. NOOOO  they refused again , I mean NO ONE was there,  That to me indicated poor service  and we had not even received water..  With the Groupon we were allowed to order from the 3 course prix fixed courses  Both of us ordered the French onion soup  which was quite nice  and i ordered the rabbit  and my dinner mate ordered the Duck confit with sausages. Both entrees were very enjoyable  but  extremely rich  that was hard to finish.  Another couple arrived  and they tried to seat them  at a table for two right next to our table , kind of ridiculous since the restaurant was still empty  but the couple refused and they moved them to another table. For dessert  i had the Brulee and my dinner mate had the key lime mousse  both  were enjoyable but not memorable.  Finally another table was occupied about that time.  I was still confused as to why were no allowed to eat indoors  as not one table was occupied the entire time we were there...very strange.  The entire experience was over shadowed by very poor service...we had to ask for a bread plates.  The hald carafe of wine for $18  was  din other words boring.  When the bill arrived i noticed we were taxed on the entire $70  and not the amount of the coupon $39..I expected to pay a tax on the  $39 plus the cost of the wine. I called the Franchise tax board today and they told me the restaurant  was only to charge tax on the amount we paid for the service...so this restaurant is ripping off its customers,  This establishment may be audited because of this practice.
author: Ross V.

description:
The food and music were wonderful.  The busser/assistant waiter was the best we have ever experienced.  He seemed to know exactly what you needed before you even thought to ask!

Whatever you do, don't sit outside...  The tables are made so that there is no where to put your legs comfortably.  I had to straddle the table (very unladylike).
author: Melissa D.

description:
This place was cute and all, but the services was sub-standard.  The waiter was usually nowhere to be found.  Once he took our order, he disappeared.  Whenever we wanted something else -- condiments, more wine, etc. -- we had to hail a bus boy.  He reappeared to bring us the bill.  Ha!  Very poor service!

The food was pretty good, and the ambiance was nice.  Overall, it was a disappointment though.
author: Aim M.

description: I came here for a lunch time meeting and I loved the atmosphere.  We sat outside (it was such a lovely day) and had a very filling lunch meal.  I love this cafe and will definitely be back.  Its charming, cute and reminds me of Europe.
author: Sarah C.

description: Good place to do lunch on a nice day.  My lunch partner and I sat in the outdoor seating area.  The arrangement and design of the outdoor tables can be a a bit uncomfortable for a tall person, like myself, but otherwise the atmoshpere is nice.  I had a warm roasted vegetable and cheese sandwich, which came with a salad.  The portion size was perfect for lunch, and didn't leave me with a drowsy feeling when I returned to the office.  My lunch partner got the onion soup, which looked and smelled wonderful.  I'd definitely go back.
author: Damon Z.

description: There on groupon... Must say, for the groupon price plus a half carafe of wine ($15)... Plus the mandatory 18% gratuity... My total bill (including the groupon) was $80. The food was bland, my beef dish was essentially mashed potatoes, a few slivers of beef, and cheese. I can get better food at a dive bar. My bf got the rabbit... It was fall off the bone tender, but incredibly bland, not to mention it was served on a bed of spinach, white rice AND potatoes. After all my trips to France I cannot recall one instance where I was served white rice. Also, the French onion soup was watered down, the bread was incredibly soggy, and they used some sort of shredded imitation gruyere. Blah! I can get better French onion soup at a food truck. Oh, and did I mention that an hour into our meal, we had only received the soup. We were there for a total of 2 1/2 hours. Also, the desert was disgusting... Neither my bf or I could finish it... The ice crystals were a nice touch. We WILL NOT be back.
author: Christine K.

description: most of their food consists of stuff baked in cheese... 10 stars!
author: Ivy S.

description: As stated previously, I've been coming here for years at lunch.  However, the quiche has gone downhill.  I thought it was a fluke the first couple times, but 5 times later, it's sealed.  I go to  Cafe de la Presse now for my quiche.  The pomme frites at Cafe Bastille are still outstanding.
author: Kool B.

description:
went there yesterday, party of 5.  very busy.  among our orders,  a filet mignon ordered rare, and a rabbit.  
the filet came well done, and the rabbit was so cooked it was completely dry throughout.. no moisture in the flesh at all!!! it was virtually inedible. 
server did not check back during the meal to ask how things were (otherwise i could have told him about the rabbit).  my friend who had the filet did tell him and he got the order re done.. it came back rare this time, but it took quite a while to get it, everyone else had finished their dish in the meantime.    
for the costs of the entrees, I would have hoped they would take a lot more care in the preparation of them...   i will not be coming back to this place any time soon.  there are many other places where i have gotten these dishes well made.
author: dee c.

description: Came here with a date Saturday night.  Surprised that it wasn't packed.  I've dined at B44 many times, but thought I would try a different place on Belden Place for a change.  We shared the pate sampler, and then she had the cassoulet and I had the beef bourguignon.  The pate sampler wasn't anything great.  I had better at the Left Bank....which tells you something.  The cassoulet wasn't bad and neither was the beef bourguignon, but nothing memorable.  I had a caipirinah which was very small and just OK.  All in all, a decent dining experience, but nothing that would bring me back.
author: Chris C.

description:
I actually like this place the best amongst all the Belden St. eateries, sure B44 is awesome but the ambiance inside and out of Cafe Bastille just is oh so unique.

Having been there several times, the cooking and service can be uneven. I appears that sometimes they are more interested in whether their wait knows French that if they know how to wait.

The dish to order is the boudin noir, oh so succulent and delicious. I have sampled many dishes there, the seared ahi is regularly less than impressive, and the boudin noir is by far the signature dish, for me but the lamb has proven quite excellent as well.

They have had live music at night before, which is good. In theory. Except that the space is entirely too small and drowned out any conversation that could have been had.

Oh, if you sit outside make certain that you don't sit adjacent to the door that connects to the stairs. My friend's b-day lunch was constantly interrupted by people banging the door on our table-and they didn't even say excuse me!

I highly recommend it for dates-IF there isn't the blaring loud music.
author: Michael H.

description:
excellent for a nice lunch with friends. 
Really frenchy french !
terrasse / patio, comme chez nous !
author: armelle p.

description:
like a great one night stand, this place got me in quick and easy. 
the service was courteous and in and out since i relayed that i was on a time crunch. 

some solid dishes. 

1. good 'ol foie gras terrine. can't ever go wrong with that order. 

2. the halibut was absolutely divine. luscious and tender. 

3. the special complete (ham, cheese, egg crepe) with salad was forgettable. the secret is in the crepe mix. and it was not comparable to the ones i used to eat in paris. it was missing the crisp. 

4. the dessert was my hunt for the perfect floating island. a light egg white mix sitting on some english creme. chouquet's version is better but still not as light and airy as it needs to be. it should feel like you are eating air. 

disappointments aside, the next table told me that every dish they ordered, they loved. maybe i just went down the wrong path or maybe i was just chasing old memories.
author: Anh V.

description:
I have thought this restaurant was sort of special ever since I ended up there by chance and after dinner discovered that the downstairs becomes a club-with a DJ an all. That was about eight years ago. Unfortunately the clubbing days are over for now although the waiter said they are trying to restart that feature.

The food is good although not great. Last time I tried the blood sausage with pairs and roasted potatoes--a solid 4 out of 5. The service was good.

The place is authentically French. It is easy to feel that you are out of the U.S. when spending time there.
author: Boris R.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for a Valentine's Day dinner. 

We had reservations, and were seated immediately despite the crowds. The waiter took our orders a few minutes after we sat down. Our drinks came quickly, but I can't say the same about our food. It took at least 30 minutes for one serving of french onion soup, and over 90 minutes for our main dishes.

If we had been dishonest with the servers, who repeatedly tried to serve us other people's food, we would have eaten faster. 

When the food did arrive, it was okay, but not worth the price or the wait. I had the rack of lamb with potatoes and wild mushrooms. I got about four bites of meat, and the rest was fat and bone. The potatoes and mushrooms were lukewarm, meager in portion, and lacking in flavor. My boyfriend had the coq au vin, which looked like a more generous serving of food. 

I was still hungry, so I ordered the flourless chocolate cake, which was soft and delicious. 

I wouldn't recommend Cafe Bastille for special evenings, or even dinner. Perhaps this is a better lunch spot.
author: BK R.

description: Love the escargot and french onion soup. The space isn't well suited for large groups but would be great for a date
author: Karly F.

description:
4 stars because i like this place and come fairly often but many times i'm slightly disappointed - this last time i ordered the warm chicken liver salad, and the livers were ruined by an excess of vinegar in the dressing - i said nothing because i was taken as a treat and didn't want to upset my host

it's good and the waiters are cute and french (or at least are very good at pretending to be french!), but unfortunately not 5 stars
author: Nancy M.

description: Having lunch with another friend today at Cafe Bastille. Twice this week. Enjoy the atmosphere and the people there are very pleasant. The food is really good and contrarily to some other French restaurants.
author: Gwendolyn M.

description: I came here for dinner with 23 other colleagues from my company for a business dinner. I believe that café bastille offered a reasonable quality dining experience at fairly moderate prices. As far as menu choices, they'd fall under the more focused French style cuisine. Portions are relatively large for a French restaurant. The staff was accommodating to all the vegetarians and vegans. On the other hand there were no claims of certified organic and fair trade being made in the menu copy or were they verbally stated by the restaurant staff; therefore that question remains to be answered.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: Very cute setting, in a small side street with a few other quaint restaurants. The food at Cafe Bastille has always been delicious, whether for dinner or for brunch. As authentically French as it gets.
author: Catherine G.

description: We had our office holiday lunch party at Cafe Bastille. Belden Lane is in a charming alley; the food got raves from our crowd; service was friendly, fast, and efficient; the space was good for our private party; and the folks at Bastille were easygoing to work with in setting up the party, what with a lot of "unknown" factors until the last minute. We enjoyed it and appreciate it!
author: Lori Z.

description: Okay, but not great.  The crab salad that everyone raves about is not rave worthy to me.  Canned crab on top of field greens with some cherry tomatoes and avocado does not make me go wooo.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Great place, especially on a warm night (yeah, I know, not often), to have dinner on the terrace... Friday and Saturday nights have Filet Mignon specials that are to die for! Your knife will cut through it like butter... Yumm... Add to it their special black pepper sauce and loads of French fries and your tummy will thank you! :-)

Of course, they also have a great wine list, and you'll find some really decent Bordeaux for $45-$50 a bottle, which is not that unreasonable.
author: Benoit B.

description: Terrific French food.  Great outdoor seating, and the service staff does a great job!  Their lunch specials are always a good choice.
author: Chris R.

description: Love the atmosphere and really enjoyed the food. A great lunch spot if you work in the city.
author: Bradley H.

description: Pomme Frites, Mussells,........... I could visit Cafe Bastille daily for lunch and dinner.  All the staff is great, Olivier the owner greets like you are family, Benoit the barman makes fantastic drinks, Michael, Victor, Illia and Sabina (Hope that I got all of those names right), are so attentive and efficient.  Food is fantastic.  I can't wait for my next visit............. mmmmmmmm I may even go back tomorrow.
author: Rusty D.

description: I had the coq-au-vin and it was fan-freakin'-tastic.
author: R O.

description: This is place is cute. The Belden Alley has a great atmosphere so its a great place for fun and relaxing. The food at Cafe Bastille was ok. You'll enjoy the Three Pates but not the sweetbreads. The sweetbreads didn't have much flavor which was disappointing. My main dish was actually very good-Peppercorn Steak with fries. I highly recommend that. My friends had the rabbit and it was just alright according to them. Dessert on the other hand was amazing-Chocolate Crepe. If you do anything go for the Pates, the very good wine, and the desserts. The service was friendly and fast. Its expensive FYI. and for the kind of food you get it should be more reasonable.
author: Lisa A.

description: Had clams and a croque madamme here for lunch. Despite being busy for lunch your food is served fairly quick. Don't be surprised if a dish doesn't show up for a while when your table is still kinda full. They wait for you to finish one item before they serve the next. That's how small their tables are. But the croque madamme was worth the wait.
author: Glenn M.

description: The scallops were very good.  The first time I ordered them, they were frozen. I sent them back and the second time they were great.  I was a little turned off by the fact that everyone at my table ate while I sat and waited for my food and they didn't apologize or anything.  I feel like a lot of good restaurants would have given me a dessert for free or something while I waited for my food.  I was unimpressed with the service.
author: Laura Z.

description:
Walking up Bush Street you come to a small lane covered in twinkly lights with restaurants lining the street and maitre d's trying to get your business by speaking in charming French accents.  Much like Tijuana bars who try to lure you in with talk of cheap corona and margarita specials, competition is fierce here at Belden Place.  
Cafe Bastille is the first one on this strip of restaurants.  I'd been here once before for a friends privately held 30th birthday, but never for a real meal, so i suggested we walk no further and 8 of us sat down for a lovely meal. We were sat outside on a gorgeous night at a table big enough for all of us within 5 minutes which i found to be a sign that we had chosen wisely.
All of our entree's were cooked to perfection.  The medium strip steak was perfectly medium.  My roasted salmon was cooked medium rare per my request, and was served over these amazing polenta squares and topped with a goat cheese puff pastry that left my sweet tooth satisfied so when the time for dessert came around i didn't need any.  I also had a bite of the scallop pasta of the day, the portabella mushroom, as well as the duck....all of which i would have been happy with had they been my meal.
With wine, dessert for the table, and all of our entree's we left there lacking the huge hole in my wallet i had expected.  I also left there at 11:00 on a Friday exhausted from hours of drinking and eating, and opted to call it a night, but it was definitely a lovely Friday evening.
author: Lauren F.

description: For a French restaurant in the city it is okay.  The food was fine but not extraordinary. I have had better. The pre fix menu is a good deal. I had the onion soup, while the hubby had a salad. I choose the chicken skewers, with pom frites and green beans. The french fries tasted like McDonald's. The chicken was fine and the dessert was okay. My husband had the crepe with ratuoille and chicken. It looked interesting. He says it was okay. His dessert was the fresh fruit tart.  If we never go there again, I wouldn't be missing anything.
author: j m.

description: My onion soup was pretty good, though I thought the broth was a bit thinner than it should be.  My steak salad was not good.  Little to no taste on the dressing, the steak didn't taste like it had any seasoning (salt, pepper, oil, marinade, anything - no apparently not).  And there was a mound of couscous underneath the lettuce.  Either it should be advertised as steak salad with couscous or please leave it out of my salad.
author: Kiki R.

description: The interior looks a little like a Parisian Metro stop, but the tables are set too close together and the noise level can be high, so grab a table outside and try to imagine you're watching the world glide by in St. Germain-de-Pres. The food is good, at least when the kitchen pays attention. A traditional coq au vin, served with roast potatoes and mushrooms, was tender and tasty, but the classic onion soup that preceded it was so salty that I suspected too many cooks had spoiled the broth, and the dessert crepes were disappointing. Overall, I felt it was average at best, although reviews written more recently than my last visit suggest that perhaps I should return and give the place another chance.
author: Gourmet G.

description: My favorite place to eat when visiting SF. It's quaint and the food is absolutely fantastic.
author: Phillip Z.

description:
i don't know how some people can take a two-hour lunch, especially in the pretentious and all too self-important world of the financial district where the corporate drones are always running around as if everything was due yesterday. however, if you get a chance to stop running around for a few hours, jaunt over to any one of the restaurants in the belden place and treat yourself to a well deserved alfresco lunch.

cafe bastille is one of the more popular restaurants in the belden place. just don't expect anything more than an average french fare though. media naranja and i had the french onion soup, new york steak salad and crepe complete.......and i regret to inform the yelpers that the dishes were quite ordinary at best. we probably won't order them again. yet despite our experience, there's just something alluring about having an alfresco lunch on a sunny afternoon in a gloomy world of fidi. so i suppose we shall be back.......for the experience, not the food.
author: frisco j.

description:
after hobnobbing with the art crowd for first thursdays, the boy and i headed over to belden place for the first time.  i just got back from spain a couple of weeks ago and was absolutely in love with belden place.  how quaint!  how purty!

we decided on cafe bastille based on a co-workers recommendation.  at first, the boy wasn't too thrilled with the menu, but once the food started coming he was in heaven.  the beet salad was amazing (although more beets and cheese and less salad).  the escargot was great.  and the cheese plate was awesome!  for $9 you get a ton of cheese and i love me some cheese!  we shared their scallop special which was in a pinot and berry sauce!  yummy!  and then finished with a white chocolate bread pudding...it was perfect. 

of course, we spent more on alcohol than food with a nice pinot and some brandy at the end.  

i've had better french food, but i loved the ambiance here!  i felt like i was in europe all over again...with a bunch of stupid american tourists :)
author: Jessica W.

description: I love the whole street's atmosphere with the outdoor seating...especially on those very rare warm San Francisco nights.  Anyway, came here yesterday for a "business" lunch.  Our server was excellent.  She was very attentive and very French.  I had the sauteed mushrooms and grilled chicken crepe, which was absolutely yummy and split the cognac creme brulee w/ my co-worker for dessert.  The host very nicely put us under two (yes, not just one, but two!) heat lamps since we chose to sit outside and it was quite the cold day yesterday.
author: Kris L.

description: As an outdoor lunch spot on a nice day, it's great.   I almost always order the salade nicoise and sparkling water, and it's just fine.  I even like it.  I think it's been eclipsed over the years as a destination (and not just because restaurants from Chez Maman to Chez Spencer take the bistro concept much farther), but on a sunny weekday, it's still where I meet my downtown friends.  Plus I can park my scooter right there!
author: Laurel B.

description: My friend and I go there for the Hachis Parmentier, which is a fancy French name for a cheesy shephard's pie.  The bartender is very patient with us, since he normally doesn't sugar rim the Sidecar glass but does so graciously when we ask.  And all the servers speaking French and ignoring us lends a certain authenticity to the place. ;)
author: Dana B.

description: Very mixed. I don't like to give bad reviews but I've had much better French food in SF and in France where I've spent many months. We used a Groupon for the three course meal. The salad dressing was uninspired; the onion soup just okay with a slight burnt taste. The cassoulet was tasty (and probably the best thing we had) and the fresh warm bread was divine. The Boeuf Bourguignone came as an ample portion, tender beef and a flavorful sauce but it was not the richness I expect - perhaps not enough fat or salt for my taste. It seemed like a nutritionist had adjusted the recipes to be lower fat for heart health, which is not what I'm looking for on an occasional dinner out. The desserts were deceiving. Chocolate Creme Brulee and Raspberry Key Lime Mousse were actually squares of cake with some a mousse layer and were sweeter than dessert you'd find in France. I liked the ambience of the alley location and outdoor seating; inside felt quite authentic but the music was also a little loud for my taste. I appreciate restaurants offering Groupons to allow us to try them at a reasonable price and I had hoped to love this little place more.
author: Kay T.

description: I'm new to northern California so haven't eaten at very many places yet.  I found this place right here on Yelp and decided to take my boyfriend there who was visiting from So Cal.  It's on a cute little alley/street with a bunch of other restaurants.  All the restaurant have patio seating so you walk by other hostesses trying to lure you into their restaurant.  There was a jazz band playing which was nice. I ordered the linguine pasta with pancetta, spinach, mushrooms, and garlic basil olive oil.  It was delicious! The olive oil had so much basil flavor that it tasted like fresh basil leaves. My boyfriend ordered the duck which was also tasty, but I liked the pasta much more.  Cute place for casual dinner or date. However, the top floor inside does get a little loud with the band playing.
author: Irene V.

description: Definitely makes the short list for moules frites destinations.  Big, steamy bowl of mussels with plenty of yummy broth and never-ending baskets of bread with which to soak it up.  Fourth star is for Belden alley itself.  I am a forever a sucker for it.
author: L W.

description: Great vibe, awesome alleyway, and terrific wine and soup!  The bread was great and we really enjoyed this place.  My girlfriend loves French food and thinks this place is good.  Well worth visiting.
author: Bill P.

description:
The terrine de fois gras was indeed nothing special, but the baked brie in puff pastry and the marmalade and basalmic accompaniments elevated it substantially.

Enjoyed a Dungeonness Crab salad, lots of tasty thick meaty crab chunks, but the avocado and jalapeno sauces were bland at best.

The bread was excellent and the service so-so.  It was quiet when we were there and it took 10 minutes to get a menu.  I think the place is overpriced, but then again it's Belden Alley, where it's nice to enjoy a Lillet (rouge) on a warm afternoon outdoors.

Not great value, but enough pluses to make it a spot I'll probably come back to occasionally.
author: Mel B.

description: I love moules marinere.  Yum yum.  That's what I always get.  But these were slightly disappointing.  They weren't very big which is upsetting since we live in a port city.  And there was anise (or what tasted like anise) in the sauce which was overpowering on occasion.  But it was good enough to satisfy.  This would be the ideal place to come on a hot day and sit and chill.  But unlike a real French cafe in France, something tells me the restaurant wouldn't allow that.  I feel like they would want to flip the table more than cultivating a customer.  But we shall see.  I'm going to try my best not to come back to Belden Place unless it is a sunny day where I have nothing to do.  That will be the true test to see if any of them are true French cafes.
author: Alexis B.

description: We had one of the best meals here.  Cocktails are nice (only $6!  I had a couple of those, tasty!)  We had some awesome appetizers, such as the pete ($7), the escagots ($9 - we dipped bread into that garlic olive oil / butter in the escagots - irresistably good) and the onion soup ($6).  All very good.  I had steak for my main entree ($18 - which was a good portion of steak).  My friend also ordered mussles and fries.  NOW, let's RUN to the restuarant and try it out.
author: Edmond T.

description:
ah l l le caf bastille!!
i recently settled down in SF and this is a great place where i'll come when felling home sick... (i'm French and have of course high expectations when having lunch/diner in a french place).
i took my French friends there today for lunch and we had a blast : the hachis parmentier was as perfect as in my childhood memory, the andouillette with fries was delicious and the boudin noir was A-MA-ZING (i'll have it next time, just had a bite from my husband's plate).
the place made us all feel like we were in paris in the Saint Michel district : same atmosphere, same bistrot decor, same very-close-to-eah-other tables, same quality of food.
maybe a little effort on the expresso that was'nt that good but it came with a piece of chocolate, just like in France and that was just worth it!
super!
author: lucy b.

description: This is my favorite place in the entire city.  I love this restaurant.  My friends and I come here all the time and are never displeased, it is perfection.  The food is amazing, as is the setting and the service.  Everyone who works there is so cool and so much fun.  I have never been more excited to go somewhere and I feel that way everytime I go here.  This place is great, simple as that!  It is such an experience, very Euro.  You must do the whole thing, drinks, app, meal, dessert, and coffee, perfect with a group of four, makes for wonderful conversation.  Just Go!
author: Steven K.

description: DIRTY... I mean it. A couple at the next table found a bug in their bread basket. I would NEVER go there again. I don't care if this would be the best food in town or it would be the only place to get food. the food was just ok.
author: Sophie N.

description: Lovely place for lunch.  Had a beautiful & delicious salad - HOWEVER, cafe-au-lait tasted like dishwater...cold dishwater.  What gives?
author: Pippie L.

description: Great lunch deal!  I think that for two courses and a glass of wine, $20 is a steal, and the food is very good!
author: Angela C.

description: Not a bad little French place. I came here with my mom on a weeknight after work and it worked perfectly for the two of us to have a quiet dinner. The menu didn't seem to be traditional French - one the specials had mahi mahi and fried artichoke hearts, which although delicious, really didn't seem to be traditional French cuisine. The decor was a random mix of stuff tacked to the walls and the music was everything from the Rolling Stones to Fiona Apple. We were able to get a nice bottle of house wine for $28 which seemed like a great deal. All in all a good meal, but I definitely think there are better choices in Belden Place.
author: Lindsey S.

description: ...I used to be a big fan of this little belden lane nook.. but after looking around at the pseudo sheek alley...it is downright dirty!  It has a nice European feel and is great on a warm night (.all two of them per year in SF) Apparently plouf is the star player in the belden lane game.  Haven't made it there yet, but after 3 tries at cafe Bastille...the best reason to return is the hottie waiter.
author: Jenny M.

description: This place is really cute and has great French bistro fare.  Their Coq Au Vin was good, but I prefer it a bit more saucy.  I tired my date's lamb shank (wait that sounds kinda dirty) it was great the red wine sauce on it was to die for.  Really cute place to sit outside or at their cute bar for some wine and appies.  Oh yes how could I forget their foie gras and puff pastry brie combo was perfectly tasty and plated nicely.  Kinda on the expensive side, also I get they were going for the whole bistro thing, but it kinda felt forced and a little cheesy with the mosaic floors and the wood seats.  I think Amour Dans L'Four is a more authentic French cafe vibe.
author: Katie M.

description:
food 4 stars.  crab salad was fresh and delicious

coconut mojito sucked, expensive and weak

service was eh.

a little too pricey
author: kiki b.

description: Tried to get into Gitane restaurant, but the wait was way to long, so walked down the street to Cafe Bastille. Pretty much walked right in. Our server was really nice. Had a great bottle and reasonably priced bottle of wine and a soup, salad and frittes. Delicious start to a nite out!
author: Caroliina F.

description: Pomme Frites! There is also a really cool downstairs area that can be nice and intimate for your group. Food is pretty good and service was friendly and efficient.
author: Melissa B.

description: Belden is definitely one of my favorite little streets in the city and the frenchies really capitalized on it---especially on sunny days when working suits need a respite from the air-conditioned, stuffy cubicles from whence pencils are pushed.  Cafe Bastille is a quick salade nicoise for lunch, an easy plateau de fromage and and a nice glass of wine in the afternoon, and a satisfying steak frites for dinner.  Service is usually an afterthought, but come often enough and you are just like "famille."
author: Jaena G.

description: I went there tonight with some girlfriends since we wanted to dine outdoors to enjoy a nice warm night in SF. We tried to get a table outside at Plouf, but they only had a table inside. It just so happened that Cafe Bastille had an available table outside for us. I ordered the $25 Prix Fixe menu which came with squash soup, the ratatouille and chicken crepe and the floating island for dessert. I really enjoyed the sweet creamy soup and the dessert but the crepe was just okay. Overall, it was a nice dining experience enjoying good food with good friends. It felt like we were on a European vacation while dining there.
author: Lisa M.

description: Staying in the Union Square area of San Francisco last weekend and saw an article saying there was a French quarter of restaurants a few blocks northeast of Union Square so I decided to check it out. There are a number of side streets blocked off that have a number of bistros with indoor and sidewalk seating (very European). We chose to eat at Cafe Bastille in the middle of Belden Place. There are other bistros on either side of them. I think they hire French expatriates to work there. Very much the French countryside menu.  Great mussels and french fries. I had the French version of sheppard's pie and my wife had the leg of lamb. Both were great. Service was excellent. The prices were very reasonable for San Francisco. Atmosphere just wonderful. On a clear evening in San Francisco (so were talking about the fall) just magical. While we were there we noticed they had business cards for ChouChou Restaurant in the Forest Hill section of San Francisco. It is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, but requires a metro trip under Mount Sutro to get there. Ends up both restaurants are owned by the same brothers. Go figure.
author: J H.

description: I ate at this restaurant after I saw that they participated in the 2011 dine about town San Francisco. I also read reviews on yelp and decided to give it a try. I ended up waste $30 of my hard-earned money on uninspired dinner. I started with french onion soup. It was the worst french onion soup that I ever taste. Even a place like Tony Roma's makes a better french onion soup than Cafe Bastille. Even the frozen ones from Costco taste better than this. I only had two spoons of the broth and decided not to bother with it. The broth was bland, no taste and I could barely see any cheese on top. For a good french onion soup, Chez Maman at Potrero Hills still on top of my list. For main course, I ordered rabbit stew. This is the main reason I choose Cafe Bastille from Plouf. What a mistake! I am still wondering whether they served me rabbit instead of chicken. The meat tasted like chicken white meat. Dry. The creamy sauce was lack of flavor. I read the other review mentioned that the rabbit stew was too rich. Made me wonder if I came at the wrong night. Most likely since the restaurant was empty on Monday night. I decided not to bother with the desert or the wine to cut my losses. Definitely not coming back. I will try Plouf next time. Hopefully I will get a better result than Cafe Bastille.
author: Steve G.

description:
Best fries or frites in the city.   I always order the HACHIS PARMENTIER which is a potato and ground beef with cheese casserole. It is my favorite dish and it is my version of comfort food.  And, can't forget about the pate.  Love it. DELISH!!!!  Prices are reasonable and the dress code is up to you. 
Belden Place is the European alley of SF.   Cafe Bastille feels like you are in Paris.  I've never been too Paris but the wait staff all speak French and the decor is very Parisian.  I like going to Cafe Bastille on Fridays because they have a jazz trio or quartet that plays during dinner. Try to make it there for Bastille Day on July 14th where the alley becomes an all day and night party event.   Sunny days in the city can best be enjoyed having lunch or early dinner at Cafe Bastille.
author: Rose S.

description: Been going to this cafe on and off for years.  I love the location, food, and staff (some of those waiters are yummier than the food. )  I've never received anything but excellent and attentive service.  They obviously know their big business is the working lunch crowd, and they handle it well without every making me feel rushed.   Joanna is correct, the mussels are fantastic...both on the plate and the arms of the waiter (ok I'll stop now.)
author: Sean M.

description: Delicious special dish, but their casserole was bland and less than exciting. It was a big bowl of mush that really needed more texture and flavor or anything in between.
author: Nina B.

description: Cafe Bastille is always good. I have been here several times, with both clients and friends, and its always quality french style food at reasonable prices -- which is hard to find that all in one sentence these days. The cucumber and brie sandwich is quite tasty and the french onion soup is always superb, especially on those chilly days. I've also had the Croque Madame which is good, but then, how can you go wrong with cheese and fried eggs? I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Carol B.

description:
i love belden place, but i was a tad disappointed by cafe bastille when i came for sunday brunch recently.  it was cold, damp, and dreary day, so we opted in favor of indoor seating, but once inside, all the ambience of belden was lost:  sparse but inelegant decor, cramped seating, dim but unromantic lighting (not that i was looking for romance at the time :P).  

the service, though polite, wasn't memorable, and when they brought out the bread, it was just a cold (maybe even sligthly stale?) french loaf dumped on the table cloth.  we didn't get any plates!!!

as for the food....  i had the california breakfast.  the eggs were overcooked and sausage tasted bizarre (neither my friend nor i could figure out what was up with it...but at the very least, it definitely wasn't pork).  the home fries were okay, but the aioli accompanying it was hardly standout.  my friend had the "cafe bastille" (consisting of eggs benedict on an english muffin with hollandaise sauce).  it was so creamy she could barely eat more than a few bites.

after my great experiences at other belden place eateries, bastille lefting me feeling slightly miffed b/c we dropped as much cash as we would've at any of the other restaurants but what we got was far below the standard of bastille's neighbors.
author: Roshni R.

description: Mediocre watered down French food - point final.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Ruined my meal, sent it back and they made the same mistake two more times.  This place is a joke
author: User N.

description:
when i'm feeling unusually healthy, like the blood in my veins is flowing a little too freely, i go to cafe bastille and get the croque madame with a side of pomme frites with aioli.

clogs my arteries back up with greasy goodness.  mmmmm ....
author: cynthia q.

description: Service is awful, food is OK --not fantastic -(FYI if your used to fine dining don't order the duck, you'll be dissapointed) BUT I still LOVED this place. It was a little magical ;) I'm not sure if it was the cute x-mas lights everywhere or the fact that the patio seating made for great energy and felt like you were in some far-away European country .. I don't know. I had a great dinner here that had nothing to do with the food & everything to do with the vibe.
author: LaLaLolita D.

description: Came here for a friends birthday. I wouldn't mine eating here but would prefer elsewhere. I had the beef bourguignon and it was tasty but I thought it had a bit too much acidity. I would probably try something else if I were to come here again.
author: Wilson V.

description: Always a safe bet for a tasty lunch in the financial/shopping district intersection. However, if it's anything resembling nice out, it may be very difficult to get a table at *any* of the Belden Place restaurants.
author: David Y.

description: Amazing filet mignon and NY grilled steak! Just perfect! Besides those we had seafood brisque soup, which was extremely delicious, and for the dessert nougat mousse with black currant sauce. Everything was just wonderful. The atmosphere in this strip is always pleasant and our servers were attentive and the suggestions were good. Overall, I would definitely come back...By the way NY steak comes with frites.
author: Burcin T.

description: Another charming Euro restaurant outside on Belden Place.  The cheese plate was huge (and good) and my potato, ground beef and cheese caserole was good but a little plain. The fish dishes at the table looked and tasted excellent.  The waitress didn't know the wine list but made up for it by bringing out samples and we ended up with a great bottle of wine.
author: Cory G.

description: I admit it - I love Cafe Bastille. I've never had a bad meal there and I like the little-bit-of-Paris-in San Francisco vibe. The service is relaxed and friendly, and I always leave feeling satisfied with the whole experience.
author: Nancy L.

description:
This is my default French restaurant when all else fails (i.e. haven't made a reservation, no other place to think of, friends visit with no idea of San Francisco culinary fare, etc.). I have to say that the wait staff is not accommodating, but then again---they're French! The food is good, and when I say good it's not because there isn't any other way to describe it, but because it's not mediocre and it's not flashy and will not grab your attention but you will want to eat it again. I like coming here because of the seating arrangements. Being able to see the people walking into the street of Belden to see what restaurant they want to eat at brings an atmosphere reminiscent of France itself. Just be sure to be confident of your order and treat the servers as they treat you and all will be fine. The attitude of "get your order out because I have others to wait on" is fine by me because they get the "I don't care how you serve me because I'm paying and you know it and I'm American" attitude. 

Be prepared to spend for your foie gras and pinot gris because unlike France, this place can be a little pricy. I mean this because even the cheap bottles of pinot gris/pinot blanc in France are good ;-)

Oh, and don't order the chocolate crepe. Get a Tawny port instead.
author: Vince C.

description:
If you are looking for a casual 45mn lunch between two meetings in the financial district, this is the place to go. They serve good French brasserie food (steak tartare, quiche lorraine, boudin...) and the service is fine.
Don't expect anything superfancy or original.
They have a nice terrace, so if the sun is out, it is a good place to check out.
author: Philippe B.

description: Great alfresco lunch spot on a warm day.  Brightly flavored seafood bisque and the best fries ever, much better than Frjtz's.
author: Jesse Z.

description: Personally, I found the service lacking in every aspect.  Some girl spilled water on us, and our waiter came to the table twice, once to take the order and then we had to flag him down to get the bill (which he then charged another table's bill to my card.)  Perhaps I'm glad he so seldom came to the table because his hairy chest sticking out the top of his undone button shirt was revolting.  I mean really you're serving food button up and look professional.  I can't believe upper management lets their staff represent their business in such a fashion.  I can't say I'll be back but the food was okay, although service was extremely poor.
author: Ikey S.

description: Good fries and mussels.  Authentic french pretense.
author: Brent H.

description: love this place!! Last semester i went with my whole French class for our last class, it was awesome! At first it was a bummer b/c there was so many of us and not enough place to sit (the downstairs had a huge party) but once the downstairs was available we all got to sit and have a great time! The wait staff was very understanding to us having to speak French to them...(j'ai ete tres nervous). I would love to go back, i just got to convince my boyfriend...i have a birthday coming up so maybe i'll drag him along  then. good food, good prices, good people...such a great experience and when i go to France this year i'll be able to compare how authentic it actually is.. teehee...i'm sure they'll pass the test! salut!
author: Sloane G.

description: We had brunch here in The City, yesterday. Good bistro, average lamb (over done and dry),  and fairly decent mimosa. Loved the atmosphere and the location in SF City. Could do a better cleaning the dining area floors and the restroom. Parking is tough on Sundays. For the prices, we'd expect a bit more quality food preparation on a busy Sunday.
author: David G.

description: Comfy little spot on Belden Lane with a cool little downstairs for a good sized lunch crew. Everything seemed pretty nice, they had really good crisp beer but their croque monsieur was sort of - meh. Maybe if I would've gotten to sit outside in the warm sun I would've bumped up my review... Everyone else in our party seemed to really like their meal, so I'll come back, sit outside, get a beer and have what they were having.
author: Michael E.

description:
belden alley is right around the corner from my office (as are most of the downtown fidi places i seem to be reviewing!) and so it's a nice quick getaway for lunch.  i've never been to europe so i can't speak to the authenticity of the "european alley" feel, complete with restaurant hosts trying to lure you their way like barkers at a carnival.  but it is always fun to play "whose accent is fake" with the servers...

anywho, bastille is a favorite standby.  in fact, surprisingly enough, i have yet to try all the restaurants in the alley despite having worked in the same office for almost 6 years now...probably because i can't get past bastille's french fries!  i don't even bother to look at the menu (okay maybe a quick glance just to go through the motion) nor do i really care what the quiche of the day is, i just always order it simply because it comes with french fries (and a side salad for a smidge of healthiness).  doesn't hurt that the quiche is usually yummy anyway! =)
quarters are cramped and you may overhear more than you cared to know about your table neighbors, but c'est la vie, no? the fries alone deserve that extra star =)
author: Jen P.

description: I been coming here for 6 years and I love it, the ambiance and the food. The food is a little pricey but it's worth it and what else would you expect from a restarUAnt in the financial district. I would recommend this to any one
author: Victor G.

description: So my friends and I just ate here for a going away lunch for a friend of mine who is moving to Italy. The food was fine, nothing to write home about. I was disappointed by the french onion soup, but since I just had a cup of it at Absinthe, I may be jaded. All in all it was an unmemorable lunch until our group was just finishing up our meals. As my friend was taking the last bite of her lunch, a cockroach ran across the table. I was totally disgusted.
author: Marguerite N.

description:
The good: fast, friendly, knowledgeable service; cozy European-style location and trappings; nice wine list.

The bad: the food is mediocre and, for the price, should be considered just plain bad. My duck was old, dry, uninspired, and too heavy on the truffle oil; the crab cakes too small and over-spiced; the crepes Suzette were rubbery (and I suspect made with pancake mix); the foie gras was over-priced for the amount and quality. Ugh, I can still taste that horrid duck.

Conclusion: Considering the price vs. the quality of the food, I will definitely never go here again. I encourage you to do likewise.
author: Frey V.

description: Anything on Belden Lane is a lovely place to dine.  I love outdoor dining, especially at night.  I love the lights and the crowd.  It's a great date place too.  The staff is also super nice.  You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, so I would ask the waiter for the most popular dish.
author: Joanne H.

description: The french onion soup was awesome, mussles were average, everything else was below average.  Tried teh special of the night (steak), coq au vin, lasagna. all were nothing special.  However, the staff is very nice and accommodating.  Bottom line- you get what you pay for.
author: p w.

description: This place is French down to the cigarette smoke while you eat.  Everyone French smokes.  Aside from that, I like eating in this lively alley outside while the heat lamps are turned on and the wine is prolific.  The atmosphere is nice when there are a lot of people out enjoying themselves.  At nighttime the red glow is quite delightful.  A lot of French people really do come here.  Speaks to the authenticity.
author: apple r.

description: Great place to sit outside on a sunny afternoon either extending a liquid lunch into happy hour, or getting a headstart on the evening crowd. This also seems to be the only place that stays open on Belden on a Saturday afternoon, so is an ideal spot to hit once the Union Sq shopping fatigue hits. Gets pretty packed but service is prompt, friendly, and sprinkled liberally with tidbits of French (but none of the attitude) which is always fun. The food, on the other hand... My steak was a bit chewy, the bread was slightly stale and the fries were a little anemic. The wine was nice though. Definitely wouldn't prevent me going back, the scene is so pleasant, and maybe I just haven't found their piece de resistance yet.
author: Stuart J.

description: I think the coolest thing about belden place is the outdoor seating that makes it look like a block of paris in SF so the best time to go would be when it's nice out.  I haven't been disappointed with anything I ordered.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Awesome location.  Quiche was good, friends crepe was perfect.  Mussels were also solid but felt that the flavor got a little tiring after about 6.  Sunday afternoon late lunch/brunch fo shooo
author: Andrew T.

description: I visited Cafe Bastille for breakfast today and was very pleased with my food. I ordered French Toast, which came with fresh berries and an English cream. It was lovely!!! One thing that I did not like about this cafe is that it was a little bit too dark and hard to find in the alley!
author: Customer C.

description: Make reservations on Bastille Day, and don't eat here unless you're looking to impress a girl or practice your french
author: Lane K.

description: Great Frites!  The steak was okay.  The atmosphere is great outdoors.  Very european.  A little crapmed, though, on a nice day.  The lunc steak was a bit pricy for lunch at $20.
author: Zach T.

description:
I cannot say I had a great meal but I did have a great time! It's just a wonderful setting for a fun group meal. There were 10 of us and we got seated fairly on time and our outdoor seating preference was honored. The waiter we had seemed quite impatient though when we asked for wine recommendations and just in general. Also, a couple of us decided to share so after placing the orders, two of us switched seats. When the food came out, the busboy got confused for a minute and instead of asking for our help and remaining calm, he rolled his eyes and was quite annoyed.

The wine was OK but I expect that at French restaurants as I've got more of a California wine palate. I split a salad with my roomie and it wasn't bad but nothing super exciting. I can't even remember what was in it - that's how memorable it was...then we split an entree as well as the lamb shank they advertise on their website wasn't available and it's what I wanted. I think we split the scallops? Gee, I can't remember what the meat was but that there were carrots and steamed new potatoes involved. Somehow scallops rings a bell...just for the record I wasn't drunk or on drugs and this dinner took place a little over 3 days ago...the only thing I remember clearly is the unfriendly wait staff and the ambiance which was awesome. I loved sitting outside on a small crowded street - I was born and spent a lot of time in Europe so this sort of dining really appeals to me. I'll definitely go back to Belden Place but not to Cafe Bastille.
author: Kat J.

description: One of my old favorites, you can never fail with the mussels and frites. Yummy yummy yummy. On a sunny day this is the perfect place to go for a lovely long lunch. It's located on Belden lane which can get quite crowded after work also. If you come here don't bother getting anything but the mussels, they are divine.
author: Cathy T.

description:
Came here on Saturday night for my sister's birthday. Although it was a nice night, we asked to sit inside because it's quieter, warmer, and doesn't smell of cigarette smoke like it did outside. The waiter and waitress were a little hard to understand because of their French accents. We had a party of 5 and four of us ordered the pre-fixe menu which came with soup or salad, an entree, and a dessert for $25. 

2 of us had the Tomato Basil soup, which was nice and creamy. 2 had the French Onion soup. The soup was a little lighter than usual soup, and had more cheese than usual. I ordered the crepe with ratatouille and chicken, which was pretty good. It had a lot of vegetables, which I like. My friend ordered the crepe with chicken and mushroom, which came with a cream sauce, but I liked mine better. Tip: The crepeps come with a little side salad on the plate, so you can order the soup and still get a salad with your entree! Two people had the beef bourgeouine, which just looked like a beef and vegetable stew. I think they said it was pretty good.

For dessert, two of us ordered the strawberry tart, which was delicious. It was light and drizzled with nutella. Two people ordered the flourless chocolate cake, which basically tasted like chocolate ganache.

Minus stars: Since the downstairs is a little narrow, it was a tight fit with the table on the other side. They seated a table of 13 directly behind us and the waiters barely had enough room to squeeze between my chair and the chair behind me. Which led to the constant kicking and bumping of my chair while I was eating. If they knew the party of 13 was coming, they could have sat us somewhere else. We were the only 2 parties in the entire floor. 

Also, they had the little tealight and candle holders from Ikea. Which probably sets a nice atmosphere, but is probably a fire hazard. There were about 3 times when the waiter/busboy was pick up plates that I swear his sleeve was almost going to catch on fire.


All in all, the food was pretty good, but the cramped space and constant bumping in an otherwise available room hurt their rating.
author: T C.

description: Belden Place is definitely a very European spot. At Cafe Bastille, I had the mixed greens salad and the coq au vin, which were both good. Nothing life altering, especially for the price.
author: Alexander S.

description: J and I have come here several times to have drinks and a light bite.  Tonight was no different and we had kir and la basilic along with the escargot and goat cheese with raisin compote.  Yum.  I like coming here early and just chilling at the bar.
author: Pelle Y.

description: I've only tried the crab salad, it's great. Will need to revisit and try other items on the menu in order to provide a full review.
author: Tonia D.

description: Good food, but the service is slow...slow....SLOW!!!!  It took about 30 minutes to get our order, another 40 to get our food out, and another 30 to get the check!!  Total, almost two hours to eat!  We were considering dessert, but due to the pace of the service, we decided to forget it.  The bad thing is, only one other couple was there!
author: Carrie-C N.

description: I've been to Cafe Bastille several times and have yet to have a bad meal there. The food and drinks are good and the location is just darling.
author: Kim V.

description: Overrated.  Excellent alley conversion--largely initiated by owners (great job!)  Decent food and service, but nothing special.  I don't think they would be particularly successful in their home country, but they know how to capitalize on being French in the US.
author: Gran A.

description: Belden Street is charming.  Cafe Bastille is not. Quality of raw ingredients is second rate e.g. fish, steak, etc. quality not up to the price of the food.  ($25 NY steak was swimming in sauce to hide the fact that it was fatty, stringy and thin).  The place could use a real cleaning.  Service is spotty.  Yes, the French are known for leisurely meals, but 2 hours before we were asked for our entree orders?  Red wine served way too warm, a sin for a place that claims French roots and accents, with a weak wine list particularly given SF.  If you drink enough and squint your eyes maybe you can pretend for a moment that this some Quartier Latin or Left Bank bistro.  But once you open your eyes...  avoid!
author: Evan Q.

description: I had such a great time at this restaurant last night. We had a fantastic bottle of wine, the sommalier (sp?) even came over to compliment our choice. We sat in the basement as it was cold outside. We were being loud, and it wasn't a problem. The waiter was attentive, and all the food was great. I'd definitely go again. 4 stars, cause it was my first time here! 5 if I go back and have the same experience.
author: Kristen O.

description: I used to work off of Belden Lane, so going back there is reminiscent of my early SF days...I love Cafe Bastille, not only for it's atmosphere (I feel like I'm in France), but for their muscles, french onion soup and pommes des frites! Go there with friends, have a few bottles and apps, it's delightful!
author: michaela w.

description:
went to dinner with a couple of girl friends. Decided to visit Belden Place. After reviewing several menus...and one of the girls being not much of a fish eater we settled on Cafe Bastille.

The food was okay....we had the Ahi appetizer and then the mussels for an entree and the flour-less chocolate cake for dessert.

the mussels were definitely the highlight of the meal...so light and fresh.... everything else were merely okay....

the outside ambiance made up for it...it really does a make you feel like if you are in Europe.
author: Joy Y.

description:
We went to Cafe Bastille for dinner after our massages at Burke Williams.   The lights were pretty, but the outdoor seating was not comfortable.  Table and chairs were too cramped! My purse fell into a puddle of water. I was not happy about that. Plus I did not have any place to put my shopping bags. 
 
We both had the Dine about Town menu special.  (salad or clam chowder/filet mignon or pasta/flourless chocolate cake or floating island.)  

The food was ok. Nothing to rave about, but nothing really to complain about..well maybe the floating island dessert. It was not good. 

The special salad consisted of all greens with one slice of tomato and olives.  My husband had the clam chowder.... not too heavy... It was ok. 
The filet mignon was good.
author: vernice l.

description: Good for some foie gras and sparkling wine. It can feel a little bit crowded.
author: Angela K.

description: French onion soup and dungeness crab salad.  Haven't been able to move past these two items on the menu.  It's a go-to for working-weekends in the FiDi. (ie take out)
author: K W.

description: Cafe Bastille and all the Belden Place restaurants are kind of a tourist trap, with poor quality food and products at a quite expensive price. It is said they all share the same desert kitchen for example. A good proof of scalability.
author: Mimil H.

description: We ended up here by pure luck.  We were actually going to a different restaurant but it was closed and ended up here.  I am not usually a food critique, but these are some of the things I just want to point out.  There is no FREE refills on coke! The Steak salad is horrible.  The steak is tuff and not marinated.  Its like cutting a piece of sliced meat and then cooking it.  But the baguette was okay.  I saw the person across from us who had a Salmon which looked good but I did not try it so I can't really say!  Service was decent.  I would say its decent for lunch, but definitely not for dinner.  The place was busy when we went.
author: Jason D.

description: Delicious! Beautiful decor and cordial service. It's a little alienated from the bulk of Belden fervor, being at the very end, but it's nevertheless a memorable and extremely pleasant experience. Had scrumptious filet mignon, scallops, and tartare!
author: G. J.

description: It took about 10 wait staff people to pass us by, look at as and keep walking before anyone even acknowledged we were "the customer". The food was disappointing, soggy ravioli supposedly stuff with seafood which I could not taste.  No sugar was served with my Ice Tea or my Latte and forget about asking for non fat milk.  Very disappointing experience.
author: Tina T.

description: I went there for a lunch with my boss who paid for it to celebrate the Administrator Week.  The first thing is that it's surprisingly packed when it's already 1:30pm which is late for lunch.  I guess that most of the people there are not working on that day, except us.  I ordered tiger prawns with pasta, spinach and lemon sauce and my boss ordered mahi mahi.  Both of them were delicious and well-served.  For a late lunch, it was really good and the portion was just right to fill up our empty stomaches.  Only one thing that took the 1 star off was the noise.  It's so noisy inside, possibly because of the design and the setup of the restaurant, we had to raise our voices to make sure we heard every words.
author: Roserrele W.

description: On those rare days in San Francisco when the sun is shining and the weather is warm (and I have time for a real lunch during the work week), Cafe Bastille is a good bet.  It really is the quintessential French bistro, and I say this having sampled a good portion of the menu (and the wine list).  The service is quick and pleasant, and yes they are in fact French (if the accents don't convince you, the euro-techno music they play when the boss isn't around surely will.)  One of my fondest memories of this place was during the 2006 World Cup, when the whole place was riveted to the TV screens, cheering enthusiastically.  My only caveat - being French cuisine, the portions may not always be burly enough for American appetites.
author: Peter V.

description: I love Belden Place but and thought Cafe Bastille was just okay.  The restaurant itself is cute, situated in an alley with several other "Euro" restaurants.  We sat outside and the service was good.  The food was ok (I got a ravioli dish and the BF got the fillet mignon dish).  I think what really makes the place is the fact it's in this alley and it feels European.  I would like to try other restaurants on Belden Place though.
author: Carol S.

description: Cafe Bastille is one of those little gems on Belden Place off Bush that could easily be overlooked if you weren't looking specifically for it.  For starters, our charming waiter friend Anatoliy is there; we've known him from former restaurants.  His wine recommendations are completely trustworthy.  He gave us a beet and goat cheese Napoleon on the house which was "to die for."  A stack of beet slices layered with the cheese.  I had the marrow bones on toast points.  The bones were about 4 inches long, sawed down the middle.  The marrow could easily be spread like jam.  Rich, but oh so good.  The huge bowl of mussels mariniere  with French fries (came extra crispy as ordered) were fresh and succulent.  I ordered the Creme Brûlée which was good, but my wife had the standout winner chocolate pear tart.  The place is small, has an atmosphere of funky charm, and hit just the right note for us.  Outdoor seating with heaters too, and a large room downstairs for groups.  Convenient parking at the Stockton Street garage just a couple of blocks up Bush.
author: Thomas N.

description: What can I say except if I could give it less than one star I would!  We arrived at approximately 12:05 for lunch, not dinner, lunch and were seated downstairs where apparently you are forever forgotten.  When the waiter finally came for our order it took another 15 minutes or so to receive our soups.  The soup was good for me, however my friend said the French Onion Soup was the worst she had ever had.  Pretty sad for a French restaurant.  then after watching everyone who came in after us receive their meals, I finally had to call the waiter over and ask why a salad was taking so long.  He apologized and went upstairs and came back down immediately back with our meals.  Too little too late.  We asked for them to be packed up to go because, well we working class people only get 1 hour for lunch. (Imagine that!)  We then went back up stairs to the living and paid the check.  Another set back, very expensive especially for the terrible service.  I was handed my salad in a bag, which was boxed and not even closed, and was told to have a nice day.  Really?  Seriously? Have a nice day when an important part of my day was ruined?  I think not.  So in short...Cafe Bastille at 22 Belden Place....Do Not Go!  Not worth the time and certainly NOT worth the lots of money for sure.
author: Shirley B.

description: Here's my theory on all the restaurants lining the little alley of Belden Place in San Francisco.  This is a San Francisco version of the International Food Court at any suburban mall.  Cafe Bastille came recommened with the promise of the "essence" of Parisian sidewalk dining.  Ok, it has tables on the sidewalk and it does serve French food.  But it is overpriced, service is sloppy, and the food is not first rate.  And, if one bothers to walk inside, it looks far from clean!  Read:  tourist trap.  Cafe Bastille might work for a warm afternoon lunch if you happen to catch an entree that was carefully prepared, but don't go out of your way.  Much better places in the neighborhood to try.
author: Billy Dee R.

description:
For the longest time Bastille was my favorite little cafe in town.  I had been a long time customer of theirs from my teenage years when I'd visit my mom during her lunch hours away from her banking woes.  
  Alas, I went to France, had a taste of the real thing, and didn't return to little ol' Bastille for some time.  Its flavor had dwindled and dishes there seemed over played and its flavors underdeveloped.  For a time, I avoided it and would go to Claude (still a place I'd recommend over Bastille any day regardless of giving them the same rating).  However, recently all has seemingly changed.  
  Maybe they hired a new cook or the old one got smart but the last time I went Bastille redeemed itself in my eyes.  The onion soup was back to its old self and, out of the blue, you offered Coq au Vin.  I took a chance and never regretted it.  It was wonderful, the chicken was excellent and the dish well thought out.  I was wrong about Bastille, but it took them time.  I hope to eat there again and again in the future!
author: Scott N.

description:
La vie:
Food- Yay! I'm a fan. The escargots are a MUST. The drinks are not that special.
Ambiance- Cozy and colorful
Service- Yummy french server : 9

Joie de vivre:
Belden Place is just lovely. I'm enamored by European (especially French) culture, and this little alley is the closest I'd get to being in Europe (for now). My dining experience here was amazing. I made a reservation for 10 for my 21st birthday. We were taken to a cozy private room downstairs. The decor on the walls were appropriately French.
The drink menu wasn't all that appealing. I didn't know what to order as this was my first legal drink, and ended up with something I didn't enjoy. Poop. But that's okay because the food was amazing! I shared the Onion Soup ($6) with my boyfriend and it was a concoction of cheesy goodness. For starters, we had the Dungeness Crab Cake ($10), the Escargots ($9.25), and the Mariniere (mussels) ($13). I didn't care too much for the crab cakes but the escargot and mussels tasted fresh and delicious. My boyfriend and I shared the Grilled Atlantic Salmon served with a Risotto Cake and Sauteed Mushrooms ($16.50) and the Grilled New York Steak served with Sauteed Garlic Potatoes ($18.50). I had the steak medium rare and it was so tender and juicy. Some of my friends had the Andouillette with Mashed Potatoes ($12.75) and weren't fans. : (
Because it was my birthday, our server brought me a complimentary slice of flourless chocolate cake. It was yummy but way too rich. It was perfect though because I shared it with all my friends. And he gave me an Eiffel Tower keychain! Yay, twas a bon anniversaire, indeed. 

I'd definitely recommend this place. Bon appetit! Ciao!
author: Phoi B.

description:
this may be the biggest faux pas in french dining, but have you tried the hot dog???  i am not normally a hot dog fan, i really can't recall what even lead me to that choice.  the moules frites was my typical staple, good, solid.  but on one friday afternoon, enjoying a long lunch after a long week, after waking a little too late, feeling a little hung over, needing a little of something you don't typically order, i found myself asking for the hot dog.

it's frenchie style.  in a baguette, melted cheese, you add the dijon.  it's delicious.  

i really love this place because there are far too few patio spots and it's pretty darn close to a real french bistro.

i'm taking away one star because while i don't mind dining in close quarters, sometimes these are a little too close.  when you become bound to the chair next to you and unable to budge, it's a sign of one too many tables.
author: ellie s.

description:
I'm just adding my voice to those who like this place for the ambiance but find the food especially lacking.  IMHO, Plouf (three doors up) wins in both categories, so go there instead.

The bread was a little bit stale, but then, it was a hot and dry day (by SF standards).

I ordered the soup du jour, Cream of Cauliflower.  It was heavy and starchy.  It lacked depth of flavor.  Black pepper helped, but I held off on adding more salt.

I ordered the house special, Hachis parmentier, which is the french take on shepherd's pie (made with ground beef, not ground lamb).  It was served in its own casserole dish, but was disappointingly tepid.  The hachis was covered in a thick layer of plasticized broiled swiss cheese.  I had never heard of Hachis au gratin, and in my opinion, the cheese makes a botch of the dish.  I also prefer it when the ground beef is stewed in tomato sauce and rich with peas and diced carrots- also missed.  The dish, overall, was dry and plastic, and I could not finish it.

The side salad was good- I liked the imperceptible mist of oil&vinegar dressing.  Very light.  Very french. 

My friend had the moules marinieres.  She said that they were worse than at Plouf.

We shared the flourless chocolate cake garnished with creme anglaise and dark chocolate sauce.  Not bad, but not special.  Could have been from the gourmet freezer bin at Trader Joe's.  It didn't taste house-made.

I had a glass of pinot noir that was served at a pleasing temperature.
The decaf espresso was also very good.

The atmosphere was really nice- friendly waiters (although not attentive enough).  Belden Place is magical on a hot summer evening.

I've eaten quite a bit in France and find that the food here compares well with what you would find in a highly touristic area.  Generic, unspecial, bland, but "french enough" if this is what you are looking for...
author: Nichtdaisy E.

description: This place leaves a lot to be desired. Our dining party was seated outside at a table with an unbalanced table. A glass of wine was spilled and there were several near misses with other drinks and food on the slanting tabletop. The food is alright (but for their prices, it should be perfect). The only reason I would come back is for the ambiance of Belden Place. And I'd probably only have wine and cheese on the patio.
author: CC M.

description: I like this place A LOT and I plan to become a regular purely for my addiction of moules frites.  Not only do they speak French, they also tolerate my attempts at one of my favorite romance languages.   The prices are decent for what you get but I will pay big $$ for good grub so my opinion may not be the best on this topic.  I like that the menu is in english so people I take there do not feel intimidated to order from the very traditional brasserie fare.  I had the moule frites and the green salad.  The salad dressing was boring and not Frenchie enough for me so I'm docking one star.  The mussels were cooked in a wine and cream sauce with bits of garlic and onions swimming in it.  Although the serving size was just right for Cali standards it made me pined for my days in France and the kilos they would bring me when I ordered moules frites.  The fries that came with the mussels were average for my standards but I'm spoiled and I'm writing this review after a great meal at Two last night where I had the fries, so good.  I'm putting this place in the ranks of Cafe Claude, Cafe Bastille for moules frites and Cafe Claude for onglet, if only I had two stomachs like our bovine friends.
author: Amber L.

description: Pretty disappointing experience - service was extremely non-chalant and food was hardly spectacular - I view this alleyway pretty overrated in general, but this was even worse than I expected
author: Michael C.

description: i like this place mostly for the atmosphere. i love all the places in belden alley and if you want casual (and good) french food this works for me. sure, i've had better french food, but like i said i usually come here when i'm in the lets-dine-on-an-outdoor-patio-in-a-cute-alley type mood.
author: Michelle I.

description: My first (and most likely last) trip to Cafe Bastille was for a birthday party about 2 weeks ago.  In hindsight, I think maybe our experience would have been better had we ate outside, but we ate in the basement as a private party.  The amount of attention we got as a group was not satisfactory, asking for bread, ketchup, or even a steak knife (for my steak?!!!) barely were recognized, and I even borrowed a friends steak knife.  They had some 70s porn soundtrack or a reasonable facsimile playing at a volume too loud, I lost my voice just trying to talk to my wife across the table.  As for the food, 4 folks wound up returning the sausage dish, as the taste and smell was brutal.  There are many other places to eat at in the area, I recommend you choose pretty much any one of them.
author: Gene L.

description: a little pricey for the quality of the food. my cousin got bad shrimp, but they replaced it immediately, which was nice (but also totally expected). altogether not super memorable and the atmosphere was lacking - the tables were crowded and the restaurant was too dark, as though they couldn't decide between wanting to encourage intimacy or anonymity.
author: Betty H.

description: My book group was discussing a French novel, so I wanted a bistro that was casual yet with lots of atmosphere.  Granted, I was hesitant to make the reservation at Café Bastille after reading all the food-related reviews (it had been years since I last ate here, just for logistical reasons).  I am happy to report that everything we chose was fine and even very well executed.  As far as my entrée (moules mariniere), I was in heaven.  When the waiter took our orders, I grilled him:  "If I order the mussels, will I love them?  I mean, I don't want to be disappointed.  The broth needs to be simple but tasty and the mussels should be first-quality.  The last time I had mussels, I was sorely disappointed (Bistro Jeanty)."   He laughed, "Well, we own Plouf down the street and mussels are their specialty.  They get deliveries every day."  I decided that for $13.50, I could take the chance based on this information.  And am I really glad I did!  For weeks, I was craving good French bistro mussels.  Mine were perfect, plump; and the broth was so delicious that not a drop was left.  The soup of the day was honest and flavorful, too.  When one of us got her crème brulee, I was pleased to hear the tell-tale happy cracking sound which can only happen if the recipe and the scorching are done properly.  As far as stews, well...how can a restaurant-made stew compare to something made in your own enameled cast iron?  Once I learned how to make them myself, I never order stews or cassoulets anywhere other than my own kitchen.  And back to atmosphere.  It's like a postcard of a European outdoor bistro scene (sans US$-Euro disadvantage).  So make the trip to Belden Place.
author: Amelyn C.

description: Belden Place is a small piece of France in SF, and Cafe Bastille indeed feels authentically French, more Montmartre than Bastille.  The atmosphere is sultry and a little hushed (I went there fairly early in the eve); tile mosaic floors and French liquor posters boost the ooh-la-la factor.  The food, however, was anything but.  I was really craving steak frites, but I had to order the steak and substitute the frites for mashed potatoes--what self-respecting brasserie wouldn't have steak frites on the menu?!  Furthermore, what self-respecting Francophile establishment would offer quesadillas and chicken satay?!  Americans tend to dismiss the French's unwavering pride in their culture, but Cafe Bastille seems to have made too many concessions to America; at least they do have hachis parmentier, boudin noir, and moules frites on the menu--otherwise, the menu would look too nondescript, kinda like Dream Cafe in "Seinfeld."  My steak was alright: it hadn't rested enough after cooking that when my knife sank into the meat, juices flowed too freely.  The frites, too, were acceptable but not fantastic.  The steak frites came with blue cheese butter and creamy black pepper sauce--I got both on the side.  The bearnaise-ish black pepper sauce was delicious as a dip for the frites.  I'm slightly allergic to blue cheese so I didn't try the butter.  Perhaps Cafe Bastille can pull off other items they offer, but I wouldn't trust a brasserie who doesn't get right the cornerstone of its traditional menu.  I was too disheartened to drop more money on dessert.  For the price I paid, I could have made my own steak with dessert and a bottle of cheap wine.  I think the best bet at Cafe Bastille is to linger over drinks at the bar and enjoy the atmosphere, but no more.
author: maiko h.

description: i love love love this place!  i lived in Paris and can say that it brings me back there....the terse wait staff, the tiniest tables, the wine list miles long...i had the crepe with mushrooms and chicken and it was delicious.  i can't wait to go back!
author: Lauren V.

description: love this alley wqy style restaurant..feesl like Italy
author: cecille p.

description: it's not bad, but i'd rather be at cafe de la presse or cafe claude... just up the block!
author: Erika C.
