description: my friend i was having dinner with isn't a big seafood fan.  so she chose this place over the others (that had bigger seafood selections) along belden lane by comparing menus.  i let her pick the spot for dinner that night since i'm always in the area anyway.  good sangria and okay foie gras (felt like it was missing something).  the salmon was okay but nothing to be wow-ed over.  i tried my friend's steak and fries and it was tasty.  creme brulee was decent as well.  the service was ehhh so-so but the food came out fast and in big portions for a french restaurant. overall, felt cozier (inside) than the other places next door.
author: ally o.

description: The service was very good, but the food was mediocre at best.  The muscles had too much of a fishy taste.  I always eat muscles and I have never had problems with the muscles at Plouf; I don't understant how its sister restaurant can mess it up--the fries that came with it were absolutely the best.  The bread that was served was awful.  It  tasted stale even after I asked them to bake it so that the baguette would be crispy.  The steak was bland, I think that this could have been remedied had they placed the steak directly on the sauce and the fries on the side as oppose to the way they served it with the fries on top of the sauce (making fries soggy) and the steak on top of the fries.  I asked the waiter whether the duck had crispy skin and made it absolutely clear that I would only order duck if this could be done.  Well when i got my duck the skin was not crispy at all, when the waiter asked how was everything I told him.  He went to the kitchen to tell the chef and came back to send me apologies from the chef.  I still had to pay for it.  I think that they should have taken it off the bill or at least offer a complimentary dessert--SOMETHING!!!  The crab cakes were delicious though the sauce that came with it was not to my liking.  I would give the food one star and the service two only because the hostess was not very warm.  The waiter was VERY attentive, but did not do anything to help with the duck situation.  Don't waste your $$ here!  On the plus side the life music inside was fantastic and the musicians were very friendly.
author: A D.

description: a great restaurant fully equiped with european charm and dissent.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: I love Belden lane, in that way a New Yorker says they love something with a gleam in their eye and their best deadpan that confuses native Californians so.  If you're craving a good old European tourist trap experience, complete with menu hawkers spinning long yarns to entice the unwitting tourist to part with their precious Euros, Belden is your place, sans the Euros.  Bastille is perhaps the least offensive of the bunch, their meals are fine and the prices not entirely over the top.  It makes a great lunch spot on a warmer day, and if the servers are on top of their game it's a fine experience.  Sadly they're not always on top of their game - like Friday when I brought our 3rd business lunch to Bastille.  You'd figure with 8 staff running around right next to us, one of them would take our order within the first 20 minutes, but perhaps one of us forgot to leave the notepad of invisibility at the lab and we only decloaked when we put them away.  The other reason for a 3 instead of a 4 is the french onion soup.  French Onion soup is a childhood favorite (mmm, the thought of crispy cheese on the edges of the mini crock pot), but alas no crispy goodness here.  Just a wad of cheese in an overly thick soup with lifeless onions.  Oh well.  3 stars for you dear  Bastille.  Work on the service a bit and I'll forgive the soup.
author: San B.

description: Since I work in the Fin. District, I eat at this place probably twice a week and have had everything on the menu at least twice. The staff is great and very friendly. I like the esgargots, hachis, tiger prawns and coq au vin. If you're feeling adventurous try the boudin noir (blood sausage) which is very good, but I'd stay away from the herbed tripe sausage. Not a huge fan of the salmon or scallops (cafe tiramisu's is much better). Plus, all the girls there have french accents and are pretty sassy, which is a definite plus.
author: Pfeif E.

description: i won't even waste my intermediate conversational french speaking abilities on this bistro because it's hardly french past its name, serving sizes, food selection, staff... ok it's pretty fucking french, but it still doesn't feel like it, can't place my finger on why it doesn't yet, maybe it's everything non-french so closely surrounding it, and its non-french patrons.  anyway, the food was ok but really really expensive.  so not a good place to come after being really hungry from drinking most of the night. i'll give it its cuteness, but that's it!
author: Monk R.

description: I've been going to Bastille since I was really little every year for Christmas. The owner is from France and gets a lot of French people to work there as well. The atmosphere is wonderful and makes you feel like you are in a little French cafe (although I've never been to Frane so I can't really say). It seems like their food is pretty authentic, and their escargot is delicious, so is the blood sausage. They used to have bone marrow as well, I didn't see it on the menu when I went about a week ago, but they might still make it if you ask? I had lamb the last time I went and it was too muttony for me but their foie gras was excellent and I know from experience that their duck is as well. Their crepe suzette was pretty good, the crepe itself not the best but the grand marnier sauce was delicious and their strawberry tarte was very good. It's an authentic french place from what I can tell, in Belden Place which is absolutley charming. A great place to take a date!
author: Kristen L.

description: It's just hit or miss.  Everytime.  Ergo, 3 stars as it's just in the middle of being good and bad.  I'd give it 1 for sure if I saw a cockroach but then again after living in NYC that ain't no big surprise baby.
author: Misti L.

description: I love love love this resteraunt on the edge of the Financial District.  You will find this place between Pine and Bush in a small intimidate alley way called Beldon Place with overhead lamps illuminating the place at night.  The staff is great, they have some live entertainment and GREAT food.  I recommend the steak they serve rare.  The frites that come with the steak is also hard to come by.  Price range is in the medium, nothing extreme.  Totally worth it for the quality of service all across the board.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Not too much French about this one, except the waiter and waiting we did. While we were seated promptly and got some water it took quite a while until we were able to order. Most of the menu was not any different then what one would get in North beach as "italian kitchen" except the price was french. The wait stuff was running around like wild gerbils (2 for about 50 customers) and had difficulty keeping up with orders.
author: RBL L.

description: Aw I like this place! It's more about the entire ambiance for me than the food. I mean the food is fine but nothing to rave about. I just love Belden Place! And Cafe Bastille is a perfect little outdoor lunch spot.
author: Nicole R.

description: It's actually a 1.5 rating but rounded up.  I went here with some friends and thought it looked better in the pictures.  There was funky sewage smell that day.  Service was pretty bad.  She didn't bring the water I requested.  Since, we were a group of people, some of us paid in cash and on our cards, so when she came back, she let us know that it didn't include her tip.  Well, duh.  But she didn't let us know in a nice way.  It was more of a question.  As in something like "you know it doesn't include gratutity?"  Food was ok.  Nothing special, I had better actually.
author: giselea m.

description: We waited for an hour to get seated, even though we had a reservation.  We were told twice that the table would be ready in 15 minutes, only to have another party seated in the promised table.  The food was OK, our waitress was great, and so was the ambiance.  But I will pick another restaurant on my next trip to Belden Place.
author: Ozan V.

description: We brought group of 20 for my birthday and had a wonderful time. The food was awesome (especially the potato/ground beef casserole and mussels), the waiter was handsome, and we never felt rushed. I love Belden street.
author: regina n.

description: I had a very bad meal at Cafe Bastille. The Cesar salad tasted like the premade salads you buy in plastic containers at Safeway. The mussels were small and the broth was tasteless (too much fennel). The Pommes Frites were ordinary french fries (not the thin crisp ones you normally get in French restaurants) and the aoili was bland. The wine list is limited. Service was fine.
author: Susan E.

description: We went there to sample the beaujolais nouveau last night and settled to enjoy the wonderful toasty ambiance under those heat lamps. A great time was had by all. Except for the overpriced wine, uneven food (good charcuterie, chalky cheese plate) and obviously 2-tiered service. One level of service seemed reserved for regulars who enjoyed basic amenities such as regular wine glasses and a boisterous welcome, and those of us who were left to sip over $100 worth of wine in tiny table wine glasses, grateful that the waiter had remembered us at all. Hmmm. I'll take my bad service in Paris bistrots, thanks.
author: venus s.

description: really good food, nice place, but overpriced. it is just a nice average restaurant, with a great charm, but they overcharge a bit.
author: Cianna X.

description: To round out our adventure in the city yesterday, my cousin, who is a French food lover and I decided to go to Cafe Bastille.  This after finding out that Flor EDe Lise was closed and maybe too dressy for we guys in slacks and genes and t-shirts.  We also pondered recommendations on Facebook and looked on Yelp.  Determined to satisfy his French craving, I suggested this gem of cagfe.  Despite having only a 3.5 star rating on Yelp, there are a lot of good reviews.  Having not been down Belden Place before, I was delighted at what I saw.  It is amazing how this small, long ally packs a plethora of restaurants complete with outside dining and hosts and hostases ushering you into their cafes.  Anyhow, once at Cafe Bastille, I loved the host, who may have been the owner with his peppy, nice personality.  The only downside was that the dining room was hot, my cousin and I sweating.  Otherwise, it was an unforgettable experience.  The last time I had French food, was at the Hotel Sofatel in Redwood Shores when I was five or six and too young to appriciate it.  Fastforward to now, it was an eye opening experience.  The palm frites are crispy and greasless with a wonderful mayonesse or mustard sauce that is not overpowering.  The butter nut squash soup is smooth, rich, and naturally sweet.  The blood sausage with apples and potatos is heavenly; the sausage so tender it breaks into pieces when trying to stab it; the apples cooked just right and firm, not overdone and wilted; the potatos lightly crispy with a wonderful light sauce that cannot remember exactly what it was.  I ttried one of my cousin's pink peppercorn crusted scallops; it was light and tender, melt in your mouth with a mild, yet spicy or zesty peppercorn sauce crust.  For dessert, we swapped a little bit of each other's desserts; the crepe Sussette is sublime with light, fluffy crepes with a sweet plethora of whipped cream, citricy orange juice, and sweet chocolate.  The crembrulae is excellent with a hard, crispy caramel shell and wonderful custard filling.  Round it off with an Amstell Light for your meal and Bailey's Irish Cream with decaf coffee with dessert which is sweet and robust and you will not be disappointed.  I also must that the service is very attentive with plates always being cleared, water always refilled, and the waiter checking back not too often, but not forgetting about you.  So, for top noch French cuisine in a charming atmosphere which transports you to Paris at moderate prices, Cafe Bastille cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: We went to Cafe Bastille for a group dinner (10+ people) and wanted a place to sit outside and enjoy the gorgeous SF evening. Cafe Bastille is on a quiet alley, with lovely market lights strung over the row of restaurants along the street. The outside heaters made the evening feel very mild. We were greeted right away, and shown to our table to get settled and our waitress arrived shortly after to take drink orders. Our waitress was wonderful. She was very friendly and attentive and did well with such a large group. The menu looked so promising, that we were surprised to find that the food was really mediocre. The french onion soup was watery and had almost no seasoning, the escargot had almost no garlic or salt, the mussels were drenched in Pernod but were otherwise dry and underseasoned, and the dessert (a meringue) was huge but tasteless. The only exception was the beef bourguignon which was tender and savory and a perfect compliment to the french bread. If Cafe Bastille can work on their recipes, their ambiance and waitstaff would make this a four star place.  As is, I would skip it.
author: Julia J.

description: i admit, im years behind the curve here..... u c this is my first trip to belden place.  i wont go into the reasons y i hadnt made my way there till now, but what is important to point out for this review is that through the years, ive heard many superlatives (and no expletives) heaped on this little back alley and i must acknowlege that this could have lead me to build up maybe an unfair level of expectation upon my first meal there..... so with that cleansing of my conscience, on with the review....     as back alleys go, i have to give this one five stars.  there is little to no urine smell, parking is easy, transit access is good, and we werent hassled by any panhandlers.  i cant vouch for the presence or absence of pigeons and/or pigeon crap, since i was there at night, and the pigeons were asleep? and any potential pigeon crap would have blurred into the urban alley setting.  Note: these are especially important when youre on a date, and belden place can be a cozy romantic spot... albeit with a modicum of hard-ish city edge to it (come on... how hard of an edge can san francisco have!)     after the intial impression, and putting aside the somewhat effective affected ambiance, cafe bastille is a hit and miss proposition.  the bread was cold and hard, and could have been a day old (miss).  the waitress was cute and sexy   (hit!)  the cut of filet mignon wasnt up to snuff.  i ordered it rare, but with a truly good piece of meat, prepared correctly, a rare steak should cut smooth, you should not have to saw a steak (miss).  the waitress spoke with a french accent (hit!)  the neighbors roasted halibut looked stiff, and wafted fishy (miss).    the waitress leaned over our table to read us the nights specials, spilling out of her low cut black b.r. linen top (hit!!)  i think our waitress had hairy armpits (miss).  our waitress had a great smile (hit!).  okay... you get the idea.  im a perv with a palette.  dissapointedly, ive reached the end here w/o much conclusio
author: Curtis Y.
